story:
As a kid I would stand in front of the television screen and act out all the Disney Musicals; As a teenager I would lock myself in a room or a car to belt out the latest Sondheim score I had discovered. Even now, I mottle through tough times singing songs from Waitress and Hamilton. hahaha From a lesser known Loesser score, all the way to Les Miserables, my brain is full of the stories, music, and movement that shaped my life and opened my heart. 

Musical Theater is a very important part of my life. It has nurtured me and taught me invaluable lessons. It has a been a safe space for me to explore during difficult times. Through and through, it's in my soul. 

I dream of performing on Broadway and eventually owning my own Theater. Even in my most challenging moments, I've held onto this goal. I believe that this competition will challenge me to grow and move closer to my goals. There are industry professionals involved that will have a lot of invaluable advice along the way and this competition will force me to confront some of my weaknesses and fears as a performer. 

If you could donate any amount toward this cause, I will draw you a cool picture of your choice. lol I love drawing, so it'll be fun to make some little portraits or whatever. 

THANK YOU for reading this far. 

Much Love, 

Sonny

story:
Directed by London-based Romanian director and visual artist Cristian Luchian and performed in English by a volcanic Romanian ensemble, the show brings to life Tzara’s 'Handkerchief of Clouds' and 'Gas Heart' in a tornado of acting virtuosity, astonishing visuals and evocative music by DJ Tyrell.

When Romanians say yes, they don't just say yes, they say yes yes, in their language da da. Sounds familiar? What about now: DADA?
The dada movement was sparking exactly one hundred years ago as a revolt against the First World War whose roots, Dada artists thought, where monstrously grounded in the lands of capitalism. Dada artists believed humanity lost its values and therefore needs a cultural revolution where the old norms of society should be reimagined. But not before everything would be demolished and ashed away. 

We are embarking on a great venture, trying to bring to life some of the Romanian inspired artistic vision of Dadaism. And we are doing it by staging a collage of two plays by Tristan Tzara (the Romanian for Sad in Country), one of the founders of the movement and one of the most important pioneers of Performance Arts. We would love to be Happy in Country and to get our DADA blood boiling of creativity, and we will be indeed if we manage to produce this intriguing piece. 

We will be performing two shows with free entry at The Romanian Cultural Institute in London in October and November in celebration of the 100 years and we hope to find a home...or several...in the following year. We will also be delivering different activities related to DADA to get creative with some of you who feel adventurous this season. 

Projects like this are a niche and they don't live in the main public space of entertainment, they materialise from the community spirit and from genuine love to art making. However, this means that getting enough funds is always an issue. We have been producing this performance from our own savings and volunteering our time, and we are loving it. However, getting financially exhausted can prevent us from moving forward and promoting the performance to other audiences apart from the two representations we are performing at the Romanian Cultural Institute. Refilling our pots after spending on rehearsal times, transport, costumes, props and logistics would give us the chance to promote the performance to a larger audience and to making it available to a broader public who will ultimately connect with Romanian creativity and culture in U.K. 

You will be rewarded well for your support, we promise you. Some of our offerings include original dada art poster created by our very own visual artist director with hand crafted signatures from the crew and an exciting dada poetry jam session.

Isn't it just so DADA? 

'Handkerchief of Clouds' & 'Gas Heart' 

​Performers: Cristinel Hogaș, Cristina Haraba, Gabriel Constantin, Maria Alexe, Alin Balascan, Andrei Costin
Assistant Producer: Anca Doczi Luchian
Director: Cristian Luchian
Music: DJ Tyrrell
Video design: Cristian Luchian

“A manifesto is a communication addressed to the whole world, where there is no other claim than finding the means to cure the political, astronomical, artistic, parliamentary, agricultural and literary syphilis. It might be kind and decent, it is always right, it is strong, vigorous and logical. And by the way of logic, i find myself very nice.”  - Tristan Tzara

When: Thursday, 13 October 2016 from 19:00 to 21:00
              Thursday, 16 November 2016 from 19:00 to 21:00

Where: Romanian Cultural Institute - 1 Belgrave Square London SW1X 8PH
               Entrance is free but it is required to book your ticket on Eventbrite.
               Please note that the seating is unreserved.

story:
Running Wild, which is based upon a novel by Michael Morpurgo who is an international acclaimed author, is a grand ensemble production that is very timely for production SE Asia as the story encompasses life in England to survival in the jungles of Indonesia after the 2004 tsunami in Aceh, and the never ending conflict between human exploitation of nature and biodiversity and those brave souls who challenge such exploitation.

Checkout our Facebook page for details of our amazing creative team for props and special effects from recycled material for this production.

The envision Group, which comprises Vientiane International School students, teachers and parents, sold out each night of its productions last year of The Firework-Maker's Daughter by Philip Pullman and Table by Tanya Ronda.  We are very proud of these productions and this reflected by the audience quotes of “This production of the Table was not a school production, but a real theater production.”

As is it the never ending life of a tiny theater group, we are only able to undertake these productions with your kind donations of financial support.  While we keep costs to the bare minimum with all volunteers for the productions, we still require funds to cover costs for costumes, props, sets, and even, make-up.  This year, we started the process on a positive note as the production rights for Running Wild were gifted to us by Mr. Adamson and Mr. Morpurgo.

We need your support to reach our goal of $5,000 for this year; so do something very special and in the footsteps of President Obama and give a helping hand to something amazing in Laos.

story:
Help keep the hot pot boiling!

The story of HOT POT TALK...

In the day-to-day hustle and bustle of life, how often do we take time to have conversations with other people, much less conversations based on real connection?

More often than not, people seem to only interact with others from their own industries, be it the medical community, the theatre community, or the banking community. There are few opportunities for cross-disciplinary or even inter-disciplinary interactions, and oftentimes stereotypes and misperceptions are repeatedly perpetuated without any chance for clarification.

As such, we wanted to create HOT POT TALK: Theatre & the Arts, to explore the possibility of different worlds encountering each other. Specifically, the performance hopes to be a theatrical journey into conversation - to bridge theatre/arts and society by exploring commonalities and sharing mutual stories of ‘why’ (e.g. why do you do what you do).

Why we need your help!

HOT POT TALK has had a lot of support in various forms (shoutout to Make It Share It, Centre 42, and Paper Crane), and we are very appreciative of that, but as it is now, one month away from the performances, we are still short of a significant amount of actual funds that are needed to pay the team involved in the project. 

At the start of the project, we had considered raising ticket prices to potentially make up for this projected shortfall, but as we strongly believe that theatre, and this piece in particular, needs to be as accessible as possible (hence the max. cost of our tickets are only S$21, as opposed to S$30 or more), this was not a real option for the team. 

We were also initially reluctant to pursue crowdfunding as we wanted to push for greater support for the arts from local businesses; however, despite our best efforts, that avenue has not borne fruit.

As such, we are appealing for donations of an amount that you can spare.

We are planning to give away 3 pairs of tickets to students, but for every S$50 donation (scaled to USD$40), we will commit to offering an additional pair of free tickets for the performance to students, so that this project can also give back to the theatre/arts ecosystem in Singapore in its own way! If you would like to donate but have issues with donating in USD, please contact us @ hotpottalk2017@gmail.com.

So please, help us to:

  1. Share about this fundraising campaign; and/or
  2. Share about the performance; and/or
  3. Bring a friend (or friends!) with you to come and watch our performance! 

The details of the performance are as follows:

  • Dates: 9, 10, 16, 17, 23, 24 September 2017 (Saturdays and Sundays)
  • Time: 3pm - 5pm
  • Venue: Black Box at Centre 42 (42 Waterloo Street S187951)

You can get your tickets by emailing us at hotpottalk2017@gmail.com (there won't be hot pot, but there will be something similar at the end of the piece)!

 

We are on Facebook! - https://www.facebook.com/HOTPOTTALK/

We also have an event page on Facebook! - https://www.facebook.com/events/124941614777865/

story:
KARL NIMENI IS NOT DEAD – I KILLED KARL NIMENI is part Dada, part surrealist, part existentialist but mostly this play is influenced by, and structured on, the teachings and research of Karl Nimeni.

Charles Fleming is in crisis; nothing makes sense or allows him to follow the flow of existence. Being is becoming difficult. We meet him in a jail cell, charged with the murder of Karl Nimeni. The only evidence against him is a dream. He speaks to the audience or the jury or his god or himself. His reality has been compromised by his own dreams. We learn that he believes he is innocent because Karl Nimeni murdered him.

On this narrative journey, we meet different versions of Karl Nimeni as understood by Charles, a man he might have never met, and a dancer who represents a primitive longing in Charles, beyond rationality and logic.

Through dialogue, movement, sound and projection, we learn who Charles Fleming truly is, we discover the teachings of Karl Nimeni and we (whoever we are) leave the theatre with more questions than when we arrived. If you ask if Karl Nimeni really exists, you have to ask if you exist first.

KARL NIMENI IS NOT DEAD – I KILLED KARL NIMENI is a night play, a theatrical poem, a moment in time and a narrative dream. It is a play that is more than it seems and less than is known.

**Karl Nimeni is a pioneer and an absent mentor for everyone who goes on to explore the night, dreams and the unclear in his/her own way, between art and science.

Dancing Monkey Laboratories is fortunate and grateful for the support of Theatre Junction and the Next Stage Series. For two weeks in April, we will enter the studio and create the world of Charles Fleming and Karl Nimeni. We will dream of trees, go to the deepest, darkest, german expressionist corners of our brains, and endeavour to let mystery and curiosity guide us through the creation process. 

We have the space, the incredible creative team, and the drive, but we need your help to bring our dreams to life.

How can you support us?

Financially! Any little bit helps. Whether it's for the love of experimental and existential theatre, the love of the experimental and existential people involved, or because you love when artists get paid, your donation will go a long way to bring Karl Nimeni is Not Dead - I Killed Karl Nimeni to life. In exchange for your donation, you'll have the chance to take home a beautiful poster, or a copy of Nathaniel Schmidt's incredible original score from the show!

With a click! If you can't contribute financially, please share this campaign, the facebook event, and our website on your social media. Follow us on Twitter and Instagram! Your digital support means so much to us. 

With your body! Come to the show! Bring your parents to the show! Bring your tinder date to the show! Tickets are available through Theatre Junction and are $20 on May 3, 4, 5 and pay what you can on May 6.

Creative Team

Dancing Monkey Laboratories: Mike Czuba, Melissa Tuplin, Nathaniel Schmidt, Leon Schwesinger 

Featuring: Amy Sawka and Michelle Brandenburg

For more information about Karl Nimeni and Dancing Monkey Laboratories' work:

Nimeni, Nocturology, and the Night Play

Karl Nimeni is Not Dead - I Killed Karl Nimeni (2013)

Karl Nimeni Redux - Dreams (2017)

We Begin...A Dancing Monkey Laboratories Documentary

story:
INTRODUCTION

Here’s what you should know about me. I’m a playwright, screenwriter, and librettist. My plays have been staged throughout North America and Europe. I co-wrote the screenplay (based on my play) for the 2004 film The Woodsman. Writing plays is my way to be funny, irreverent, outrageous, political and to stage original stories that will engage the audience to reflect on stories from their own experiences.

 

HOW IT BEGAN

Last summer my wife and I took a trip to Norway. As we journeyed I wondered what the Norwegians thought of America now. Like many of you I have been troubled by the direction our country has been going in. And like many of you I asked myself, “How can I respond?” It was during my travels in Norway that I found a way to respond: I wrote my play Bergen.

 

THE STORY

Bergen is a dark comedy set in Norway in the near future. We follow a group of quarrelsome rock musicians who vow that if they don’t find a name for their band by the end of the night they will disband. The one criterion is that the name must comment on the collapse of America. While these young Norwegians either loathe or pity America, they are all drawn to its idolized ideals. During the night there is drinking, music, betrayals, erotic fantasies, and an unforeseen event that threatens the band’s survival.

 

WHAT’S HAPPENING NOW

We’re now at that sweet beginning of a production. We have our brilliant director, Kathy Gail MacGowan, and design team. We have our talented cast of young, eager actors. We’re about to begin rehearsals and discover who these characters are. We’re all very excited to begin that process.

 

OUR GOAL

Foremost, I want to stage a compelling production of the play and to generate excitement from audiences and industry people. From this excitement we can move the play to the next stage: a new home, higher production values, a longer run, and to share my story with many more people.   

 

HOW CAN YOU HELP

We need your support to help us meet our budget goal of raising $6,500. You can help us by sending us a suggested donation of $35 (or more) in our Indiegogo campaign. You can help us by spreading the word to your friends and family about our Indiegogo campaign. You can help us by spreading the word about our festival run on August 10th, 12th, 13th so that we have full houses during our shows. And you can help us by coming to our Bergen production and sharing in the excitement of what you helped create. Any support that you can offer, however modest, we will greatly honor.

story:
Short Summary

The Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the biggest celebration of arts and culture on the planet. It brings together over 450,000 audience members with artists from around the globe in over 3,000 shows at 300 different venues. The Fringe has nurtured incredible talent from Emma Thompson to Derek Jacobi, Graham Norton, and Eddie Izzard.

This year we are lucky enough to take two productions overseas to participate.

The Odyssey is an original adaptation of Homer’s epic Greek poem about Odysseus’s journey home after the Fall of Troy. Performed in iambic pentameter, the adaptation was written by Ragnarok Productions’ own Nathaniel Scott.

See Rock City & Other Destinations is a contemporary musical by Drama Desk Award winners Adam Mathias and Brad Alexander. This vignette-style musical is about connections both missed and made at tourist destinations across America.

Both of these shows explore themes of connection, journey, and humanity. They are the perfect choice for The Fringe, an event that brings together thousands of people from around the world every year.

Click here to see our full cast & crew bios.

Between now and our trip in August, we will be rehearsing, memorizing, budgeting, researching, promoting, planning...

But it costs a lot more than hard work to put two productions together and bring them to an international festival.

It costs money.

And, you guessed it! That’s where you come in.

What We Need & What You Get

It will cost us over $30,000, without airfare, to bring these two productions across the Atlantic. By donating to our fund, you can help ease the burden of what it costs to produce the shows and get us to Scotland.

Your generous donation will help us with Festival registration fees, venue costs, show rights, advertisements, sets, props, costumes, and lodging.

But wait! We wouldn't dream of sending you away empty handed. Depending on your donation, we have a variety of fun perks, including:

  • Your name in the program for both the US Open Dress Rehearsals and the shows in Scotland
  • A postcard from Scotland, mailed in Scotland, signed by the cast
  • A Fringe T-Shirt
  • A comp ticket to our Open Final Dress Rehearsal in Boston
  • Invitation to our exclusive send-off party
  • An invitation to have one of your own personal travel or landscape photographs included in the See Rock City set
  • A personalized thank you video from the cast, filmed in Scotland

No amount is too small, and no donation will go unnoticed or unappreciated. If we do not reach our fundraising goal, all funds raised will still go towards the aforementioned items.

The Impact

We are proud to be representing Boston-area theater in the worlds largest celebration of diversity, creativity, and connection. With your generosity, you will play a part in helping to bring those ideals to life.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't contribute, please consider sharing this campaign.
  • Join us for our Sing Out! Cabaret fundraiser at Club Cafe in Boston on April 20.
  • Take a Scottish Dance class! Come join us for a fun, no pressure, exploration of traditional Highland dance at Studio550 on May 19.
  • Get a team together, dust off your theater knowledge, and come play Broadway Pub Trivia in June.
  • Attend one of our US Open Dress Rehearsals July 27-29.

Please email rporderofthephoenix@gmail.com for more information on any of the above events.
story_txt:
Short SummaryThe Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the biggest celebration of arts and culture on the planet. It brings together over 450,000 audience members with artists from around the globe in over 3,000 shows at 300 different venues. The Fringe has nurtured incredible talent from Emma Thompson to Derek Jacobi, Graham Norton, and Eddie Izzard.This year we are lucky enough to take two productions overseas to participate.The Odyssey is an original adaptation of Homer’s epic Greek poem about Odysseus’s journey home after the Fall of Troy. Performed in iambic pentameter, the adaptation was written by Ragnarok Productions’ own Nathaniel Scott.See Rock City & Other Destinations is a contemporary musical by Drama Desk Award winners Adam Mathias and Brad Alexander. This vignette-style musical is about connections both missed and made at tourist destinations across America.Both of these shows explore themes of connection, journey, and humanity. They are the perfect choice for The Fringe, an event that brings together thousands of people from around the world every year.Click here to see our full cast & crew bios.Between now and our trip in August, we will be rehearsing, memorizing, budgeting, researching, promoting, planning...But it costs a lot more than hard work to put two productions together and bring them to an international festival.It costs money.And, you guessed it! That’s where you come in.What We Need & What You GetIt will cost us over $30,000, without airfare, to bring these two productions across the Atlantic. By donating to our fund, you can help ease the burden of what it costs to produce the shows and get us to Scotland.Your generous donation will help us with Festival registration fees, venue costs, show rights, advertisements, sets, props, costumes, and lodging.But wait! We wouldn't dream of sending you away empty handed. Depending on your donation, we have a variety of fun perks, including:
Your name in the program for both the US Open Dress Rehearsals and the shows in Scotland
A postcard from Scotland, mailed in Scotland, signed by the cast
A Fringe T-Shirt
A comp ticket to our Open Final Dress Rehearsal in Boston
Invitation to our exclusive send-off party
An invitation to have one of your own personal travel or landscape photographs included in the See Rock City set
A personalized thank you video from the cast, filmed in Scotland
No amount is too small, and no donation will go unnoticed or unappreciated. If we do not reach our fundraising goal, all funds raised will still go towards the aforementioned items.The ImpactWe are proud to be representing Boston-area theater in the worlds largest celebration of diversity, creativity, and connection. With your generosity, you will play a part in helping to bring those ideals to life.Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute, please consider sharing this campaign.
Join us for our Sing Out! Cabaret fundraiser at Club Cafe in Boston on April 20.
Take a Scottish Dance class! Come join us for a fun, no pressure, exploration of traditional Highland dance at Studio550 on May 19.
Get a team together, dust off your theater knowledge, and come play Broadway Pub Trivia in June.
Attend one of our US Open Dress Rehearsals July 27-29.
Please email rporderofthephoenix@gmail.com for more information on any of the above events.

story:
Welcome to our campaign and thank you for visiting! ACW Dances is an emerging modern dance company based in Arlington, VA. We're in our second full season, producing our third full-length show this April. In our short life thus far, we've had great reviews, great shows, and even greater supporters. 

ACW Dances started as a two-person company, with Artistic Director Abigail Wallace and collaborator Kerry Doyle headlining the project. We've had the wonderful composer Mark Charles Smith at our side since the beginning as well. Quickly we grew to five members and now, for our April show, we are seven. Each dancer is uniquely highlighted in the show through a combination of solo, duet, and large group choreography. We are proud to present new and re-investigated work by Abigail and by company members Liz Naro, Paula Giammarco, and Ayelet Haran. Joining us onstage will be our good friends from Alexandria, Choreographer's Collaboration Project. 

Additionally, ACW Dances is going on tour! The core company is traveling to Greensboro, NC, in May, to perform with Mark Charles Smith and two more classical guitarists. We're set to dance "Solo Suites" and "Optimal Distinctiveness," work choreographed by Abigail and set to live music by Mark.

In order to produce our April show and get to Greensboro this May, we need your help on this campaign! We are extremely lucky this year to have been granted rehearsal and performance space through the Arlington Arts. However, we do not get any financial grants, so we must rely on the generosity of individual donors to pay our artists and turn the theater lights on. Here's what you're helping us cover:

Artist project fees: $3,000
Guest artist fee, April show: $200
Travel & hotel, May tour: $400
Technical manager (lights and sound) fees, April show: $710
Publicity, marketing, and other promotional materials: $200
Show necessities such as programs, props, and costumes: $450

Grand total: $4,960

We are subject to a 7% fee on all donations, so we really need $5,350 in order to fully afford the April show and May tour. Please consider helping us in our artistic endeavor. Amounts raised in excess of $5,350 will go toward producing our 2015-16 season.

If you are unable to donate, you can still help! Please share our campaign and steer other possible donors our way. Contact us to buy a company T-shirt or tote bag so you can promote us on your own terms. DC/VA/MD locals: come to our social mixer in March and see our show in April! Tickets!

Thank you for taking the time to stop by and take a look at our project.  It is only with your help that we can produce our work.  We appreciate your consideration and generosity!  Please consider asking your employer if they participate in matching donations as this is a great way to make a larger contribution.  Our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, is able to meet all 501(c)(3) requirements for tax deduction purposes. 

ACW Dances' mission is to engage with and contribute to the community, with the vision that art should be accessible to all demographics.  Through performance of new modern dance work, collaborative projects with artists of all disciplines, and open discussions, the company aims to entertain and educate while furthering the artistic discipline of modern dance.

For more information on ACW Dances, please check out the company website!

story:
'WALKING PATH - a play without words'

‘WALKING PATH’, a play about the widespread, urban beautification drive and its impact on lifestyles in Colombo City, has been widely acknowledged as a milestone in modern Sri Lankan theatre. The play communicates everything without speaking a single word.  In a context of deep polarisation in the country, the play transcends language  barriers. 

WALKING PATH premiered at the Lionel Wendt Theatre in July 2014 to rave reviews.   The Daily FT reviewed it as ‘… superb, fiendishly clever, masterly casual’, Groundviews said it was ‘ a “must see” play, a bold and insightful critique on the rapidly changing landscape of Colombo’, The Daily Mirror said it was ‘ … a brilliant metaphor that worked on many levels.’   It has also received international recognition in the form of interest from the Mumbai THESPO festival, and the International Symposium on Theatre in Ireland.

WALKING PATH will go on the boards for the final time in Colombo on 21st and 22nd November 2014, at the Lionel Wendt Theatre. The run comprises four shows including a dedicated show for students.


Challenge

Theatre in Sri Lanka is largely unfunded. This makes staging quality and experimental creative work difficult and unprofitable. Staging WALKING PATH depends heavily on the support of benefactors such as you. 

In order to be able to mount the final local production of WALKING PATH and also perform overseas, we need to raise USD 9,500.

We aim to raise USD 4,000 through this crowd-sourcing campaign.


Why support us?

By contributing to WALKING PATH you will be investing in the vision of Stages Theatre Group, a theatre group that has produced high quality original theatre in Sri Lanka for the last 15 years.  You will be contributing to something much wider and greater than a single theatre show. You will be investing in a mission to transform Sri Lankan theatre into a rich and vibrant subculture sustained by theatre-lovers, rather than through corporate or donor funding alone. 

We hope you will be part of the future of theatre in Sri Lanka!

Stages Theatre Group

Colombo

story:
Contexte

En tant que citoyens du Québec, nous nous sommes posé plusieurs questions sur la situation actuelle des relations entre les francophones et les anglophones de Montréal. Quelle est la dynamique en cours aujourd’hui et comment l’histoire l’a-t-elle façonnée? Avec la présence de plus en plus importante des allophones, comment la cohabitation entre les deux groupes évolue-t-elle?

Le théâtre playback

Peu de contextes de la vie sociale contemporaine offrent l’occasion de s’asseoir ensemble et de simplement partager des expériences vécues. Une représentation de théâtre Playback offre précisément une telle possibilité. Le théâtre Playback consiste en des improvisations à partir d’histoires que racontent spontanément des membres du public et qui sont reproduites sur le champ par les comédiens.

Animés par le pouvoir unique de réunir les gens qui caractérise leur forme d’art, les membres de Promito Playback (http://www.promito-playback.com) une compagnie de théâtre bilingue basée à Montréal, ouvriront un dialogue par lequel les anglophones et les francophones partageront leurs histoires et dévoileront certaines réalités de leur cohabitation telle qu’ils la vivent aujourd’hui.

Trois spectacles:

  • Notre projet consiste en trois représentations. Promito Playback invitera des anglophones montréalais à une représentation, durant laquelle l’accent sera mis sur leurs expériences. Dans la même veine, le groupe invitera des francophones à une autre représentation. Une troisième représentation permettra à un public formé des deux groupes linguistiques de se rencontrer. Nous les inviterons à mettre en commun leurs histoires respectives, ce que rendra possible une représentation bilingue. Promito Playback invitera après chaque représentation le public à manger, pour permettre aux spectateurs et aux comédiens de méditer sur leurs impressions, leurs émotions sur les moyens par lesquels il sera possible de poursuivre le dialogue dans l’avenir.

  • Représentation anglophone :
    Où : Église Saint-Monica, située au 6405 rue De Terrebonne
    Quand : mercredi 19 novembre à 20h

    Représentation francophone :
    Où : Centre Culturel Calixa-Lavallée situé au 3819, rue Calixa-Lavallée
    Quand : mercredi 26 novembre à 20h

    Représentation bilingue :
    Où : Théâtre MainLine, situé au 3997 Boulevard Saint-Laurent
    Quand : jeudi 5 février à 20h

Impact

Voici les objectifs de notre projet :

-Initier un dialogue entre les deux communautés sur le thème de la langue et de la culture;

-Offrir à chaque groupe l’occasion de comprendre l’ « autre » à travers la narration d’histoires personnelles et leur exécution par les comédiens.

Ce projet est le premier en son genre à créer, par un médium artistique, un dialogue public entre anglophones et francophones à Montréal. Il procède d’un projet effectué en collaboration avec l’Aquarium et le Globe : « Différences/The clash ». Financé par le Conseil des arts du Canada, « Différences/The clash » a su créer un dialogue sur le thème de la communication à travers les différences.

Les membres de Promito Playback ont joué dans divers contextes très sensibles, notamment dans le cadre de leur programme contre l'intimidation dans les écoles, la Semaine d'actions contre le racisme et la  Radicale Queer Semaine. Leurs grandes capacités de communication se sont révélées très utiles pour manœuvrer habilement dans des situations délicates.

Si vous ne pouvez contribuer, passez le mot! Si vous croyez qu’un spectacle Playback serait apprécié dans votre communauté, faites-le savoir; nous espérons pouvoir élargir notre projet à d’autres communautés intéressées du Québec si nous parvenons aux objectifs que nous nous fixons pour le présent projet. Et nous insistons, venez voir notre spectacle!

Nos besoins pour votre bénéfice

La répartition des dépenses se décline comme suit:

Location de locaux et salles de spectacles: 2000$
Papeterie, impression de programmes et documentation: 1000$
Contribution aux cachets (acteurs, musiciens, coordination): 2000$

Promito Playback/L'Aquarium et le Globe et reconnu comme un organisme de bienfaisance enregistré. Un reçu pour fin d'impôt sera émis pour chaque don de plus de 25$.

Nous vous remercions pour votre  soutien. Il nous  fera grand plaisir de vous rencontrer lors de nos spectacles.

Context

As Quebec citizens, we've been asking ourselves lots of questions about relations between francophones and anglophones in Montreal today. What is the current dynamic and how does history play into it? With the increasing presence of allophones, how is the cohabitation of the two groups evolving?

Playback Theatre

There are few public contexts in contemporary social life where people can sit together and simply share their experiences. A Playback theatre performance is exactly such a context. Playback is a form of improvisation in which audience members tell stories and actors enact those stories on the spot.

Inspired by the unique capacity of this art form to allow people to meet, members of Promito Playback (http://www.promito-playback.com), a bilingual theatre company in Montreal, will open a dialogue for anglophones and francophones to share stories and uncover some realities of their cohabitation today.

Three performances:

Our project consists of three performances. Promito Playback will invite francophone Montrealers to the first performance, during which the focus will be their experiences. In the same spirit, the group will invite anglophones to a second performance. A third performance will allow audience members from both language/culture backgrounds to meet. We will invite them to share stories about each others' realities that might never have occurred without the opportunity of this bilingual performance. Promito will host a meal after each performance to allow audience members and the team of actors to process reactions, feelings and possible next steps to continue fostering dialogue in the future. 

  • English performance: Saint-Monica's Parish, 6405 rue de Terrebonne, Wednesday November 19th, 8:00 p.m.
  • French performance: Centre Culturel Calixa-Lavallée, 3819 rue Calixa-Lavallée, Wednesday November 26th, 8:00 p.m.
  • Bilingual performance: Mainline Theatre, 3997 Boulevard Saint-Laurent, Thursday February 5th, 8:00 p.m.

Impact

Goals of our project:

-to initiate a dialogue between the two communities on the subject of language and culture; and

-to offer each group the opportunity to understand the “other” through the telling and re-enactment of personal stories.

This project is the first of its kind to create, via an artistic medium, a contemporary public dialogue between anglophones and francophones in Montreal. It stems from a project that was a  collaboration between l'Aquarium et le Globe and Promito Playback: «Différences/The Clash». Financed by the Canadian Council for the Arts, «Différences/The Clash» created a dialogue on the theme of communication across differences.

The members of Promito Playback have performed in various highly sensitive contexts such as their anti-bullying program in schools, the Actions Against Racism Week and the Radical Queer Semaine. Their strong communication skills have proven to be very effective in dealing with delicate situations in communities.

If you can't help financially, spread the word! If your community would be interested in hosting a performance, let us know; if we meet our goals this time, we hope to expand the project to any community in the province who is interested. And please, come to a performance!

Our needs

Space rental for three performances: $2,000

Administration, printing and documentation: $1000

Honoraria (actors, musicians, coordinators) $2,000

Promito Playback/L'Aquarium et le Globe is a registered charity. An income tax receipt will be issued for donations over $25 (to people filing income tax returns in Canada).

Thank you for your support. We hope to see you at the theatre!

story:
Our Story is to Change the Story!

We know how important the arts in Philadelphia are to you.  They're important to us too, but we've noticed a serious void in opportunities for women in meaningful and powerful positions both on and off the stage. This is why we created the Philadelphia Women's Theatre Festival.  We are fast approaching our 2015 Festival and we need your help!

The Time is NOW!

Your support is crucial to our success and central to our mission.We are working to build a community that honors the creation of opportunities for women in the arts, and, in doing so; we need the support of our city. Your donation will help us present performances and educational opportunities ranging in style and scope during our Inaugural Summer Festival from July 30 to August 2 2015.

We are dedicated to creating opportunities for women in the arts.

PWTF fosters and encourages women in the performing arts by offering unique opportunities for exposure, professional and artistic and personal development and a platform for performance.  We will foster and encourage women in the arts of all disciplines: directors, playwrights, performers, designers, administrators and more.

Festival events will include:

· A fully mounted original production
· Original Staged readings
· Women’s stand-up and cabaret events
· Solo performances
· Educational Workshops, seminars and panels
· Opportunities to mix, mingle and network 

Our Impact

Over the past five years, only 10% of plays produced by Philadelphia’s largest grossing professional theatre companies were directed by women and only 20% of these plays were written by female playwrights.  Since women are currently underrepresented in the arts, we envision a future wherein Philadelphia showcases the new work of women, exposing our City to the unique and innovative ideas of a diverse community of women. 

The four-day festival of public performances will include work ranging in style and scope so as to attract a wide audience, capture the attention of our community and make Philadelphia a destination for new artistic ideas and a hub for women artists of all disciplines. Affordability and accessibility will enable us to attract a multifaceted audience including students, young adults and seasoned theatre goers.  By providing both fiscal and artistic support to all contributing artists, we will ensure that the Philadelphia community has access to high quality artistry that may not otherwise be seen.

Your Contribution Will Help Us Create Opportunities for Women in the Arts

We have big dreams to create an engaging and immersive inaugural Philadelphia Women’s Theatre Festival that will provide exciting and meaningful opportunities for women in the arts.

THE BASICS:

Your contribution will help us cover the cost of marketing, printing and postage, travel, events, production costs and venue space.  Our INDIEGOGO campaign is only a portion of our total budget.  Ticket prices alone will not cover all of the necessary expenses to produce a high-quality and all-inclusive festival. 

By meeting and exceeding our fundraising goals, you will enable us to fully realize our mission to create opportunities and give real value to the work of women artists in Philadelphia.

Each donor level is dedicated to a local Philadelphia artist that inspires us to create opportunities for women in the arts.  As a thank you for your belief in the work that we do, we have some PWTF promotional stickers and buttons for you to display, invitations to exclusive Festival VIP receptions, VIP Festival Passes, signed copies of the original plays that will be presented at our inaugural festival, signed copies of a Sarah Ruhl play (ONLY 3 AVAILABLE) and an invitation to join the PWTF co-founders post festival for an engaging dinner to learn about how the Festival came to be.

Our Challenge

We have taken tremendous steps towards realizing our festival plans by developing a mission and program plan, securing fiscal sponsorship, generating a budget and timeline, forming an advisory council, developing artists applications and guidelines, securing venues and planning our official community launch party, among other tasks.  We are committed to a darn good festival, but we can’t do it without YOU!

We are dedicated.  We are passionate.  We, the founders of PWTF, are all artists ourselves.  We have promised Philadelphia a festival and we will deliver.  We want to celebrate women's voices! 


To learn more about PWTF Co-Founders and Administrative Staff, visit our website.


There are more ways than one to contribute:

Share this campaign with your friends!
Get involved as a festival volunteer!
Join us at our PWTF Launch Party on June 8th!  Register here.

We would like to thank the generous and incomparable Kim Carson of Kim Carson Photography for filming and editing our video.

story:
Introducing the Inaugural Fresh Squeezed Ounce of Opera (FSOO)

The first "mini-opera-showcase" of its kind in Austin, FSOO's focus is on new short contemporary operas, 10-20 minutes in length. Enjoy the regional and world premieres of FIVE varied, cutting edge pieces presented in an alternative space -- IN ENGLISH. 

After a competitive national call for composer submissions, this year's works have been chosen. 

And YOU will make it happen! Our total budget for this production is $7500. The City of Austin's Cultural Arts Division has pitched in $3000 that we must match, making $4500 the goal of this campaign. That's what we mean by "double your dollars," friends! Super cool.

Be there for the beginning of FSOO, and for a taste of the future of opera. Every ounce counts. 

Performance dates are:

  • Friday, April 15th at 8pm
  • Saturday, April 16th at 4pm
  • Saturday, April 16th at 8pm
Complimentary beverages available. Staged at the Museum of Human Achievement in East Austin, which has a private address. Don't worry -- we'll email it to you! Admission is by donation, and donors to this campaign get PRIORITY SEATING! Secure your FSOO seats today with your gift of $20 or more, choose your "perk" for the performance you'd like to attend, and you're a go!
You may also choose to RSVP. Find out more here. 
Produced by One Ounce Opera, and supported in part by the Cultural Arts Division of the City of Austin Economic Development Department. One Ounce Opera is a sponsored project of the Austin Creative Alliance.

Why a Short Opera Showcase?

You walk into a new brewery. Their tap wall is expansive. Dark, familiar, complex, light. You choose the sampler to satisfy your curiosity -- and turn you on to something new.

FSOO is that sampler. This year's curated program will introduce five thoughtful new short operatic works IN ENGLISH to an eclectic audience. Topics are varied, current, inquisitive, and historical. We guarantee you'll experience something fresh and unexpected.
It's no secret the popularity of classical arts has been waning. There is a need to foster creation of new American opera and give young composers and librettists an opportunity to have their works staged. By supporting FSOO, you will be contributing to opera's strong contemporary voice!

How else can I contribute?

If you would like to make a TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation to One Ounce Opera in any amount, visit our secure portal, sponsored by the Austin Creative Alliance. Again, every ounce counts!

Who is One Ounce Opera?

One Ounce Opera (OOO) of Austin, TX is a performing arts company dedicated to "re-imagining opera in unexpected spaces," placing OOO in the forefront of the alt-classical movement. Our 20+ ensemble members are curious and flexible professionals who live and work in the Austin area. The Fresh Squeezed Ounce series aligns perfectly with our mission and our passion to celebrate storytelling through the dynamic medium of opera.

OOO has been featured on KVUE, KMFA, KUTX, KOOP, KVRX, on Austin 360 and in the Austin Chronicle, and performed as part of EAST, Fusebox, SoundSpace at the Blanton, HONKTX!, during SXSW, PRIDE Austin, and the Downtown Tree Lighting. OOO was founded in 2012.

We appreciate your support, your time, and your consideration. FSOO could not exist without you! See you in April for the launch of Fresh Squeezed Ounce of Opera!

story:
From the creative minds that brought you Replicant, Open the Door: A Doctor Who themed party, End of Line Club, and many other fabulous events: The Merchants of Deva are proud to present Mirror Mirror at Norwescon 39!

We’re celebrating 50 years of Star Trek with original-series-style decorations, food, drinks, and a live DJ that would get even Evil Spock out shaking his booty on the dance floor. How could this event get even better? Try this: It’s all for charity! 

That’s where you come in: in order to create this one-of-a-kind retro experience, we need your help. Your tax-deductible contribution will enable us to rent the suite, pay for food and beverages, and set up the room to represent the final frontier in style.

All of our donors at any level will have access to our donors-only behind-the-scenes Friday night party. This is your one chance to party with the Merchants themselves before the big event on Saturday night, but unlike Saturday's party all amenities offered on Friday night will be complimentary! (That’s right, totally free.)

Whether you’ve already been at one of our past Norwescon parties or you’re just hearing about us, this is your opportunity to have a great time and support a great cause. We love putting these parties together, and we want to share that feeling! Imagine looking out at a room with a few hundred of your fellow geeks, all having a night they’ll never forget because of YOU.

So straighten your Spock ears and grab your communicator. We promise to set our phasers to STUN.

story:
About the Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble:

The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble is a contemporary dance company that specializes in commissioning new music for dance and incorporating musicians into the visual imagery. Sharing the stage and the focus, our dancers and musicians break the boundaries of traditional ensemble interaction. Performance works include original choreography and music as well as improvisation by all performers, creating a spontaneous performance environment where anything can happen. The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble is known for innovative format, bold subject matter, and wide range of music spanning from classical to jazz to avant-garde and experimental.

2016-2017 Season of Performances & Projects

October 13-15, 2016 The Dance & Music Conversation, The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble at the Texas Dance Improvisation Festival, presented by Sam Houston State University, Huntsville, TX

The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble will teach “The Dance & Music Conversation,” a workshop that shares our unique process of cultivating dancer and musician interaction in performance as part of the Texas Dance Improvisation Festival, presented by Sam Houston State University.
 

Saturday, December 17, 2016 at 5 p.m IN AND OUT OF THE SHADOWS, Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble Performs at the Mark Morris Dance Center, 3 Lafayette Ave, Brooklyn, NY

In celebration of the release of Tim Hagans new CD Faces Under the Influence, A Jazz Tribute to John Cassavetes, the Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble will premiere a new production of IN AND OUT OF THE SHADOWS, our work set to the small ensemble arrangement of LELIA from the Faces Under The Influence. The work, which premiered on film as part of ARTCAST, will be configured for live stage performance with an expanded cast and new costumes. IN AND OUT OF THE SHADOWS was inspired by John Cassavetes' groundbreaking film SHADOWS from 1959 about three siblings struggling to be artists New York City, and the interracial relationship the youngest embarks on as her first experience of love.. Read Michele Brangwen's essay on the inspiration for this work.  https://artcastseason2.wordpress.com/2014/11/09/the-lelias/

In And Out Of The Shadows on ARTCAST


Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, 2017: The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble in Concert, Featuring Two Premieres. MATCH, Matchbox 2, 3400 Main Street, Houston, TX

The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble will premiere the third section in UNSANTO, a series of dance and music works that explore the changes to the food we eat and how these changes effect us. This third section will include choreography by Michele Brangwen, music by Grammy-nominated trumpeter and composer Tim Hagans, and set design and installation by Sandra Tapia Luna. The work will explore the idea of a label and its significance, and by extension what it means to exclude it. The set will include a sculpture by Sandra Tapia Luna made of labels that people from all across the country, and the communities surrounding the performance venue, have created themselves for a food that they eat. In other words labels that tell the story of an individual's relation to that food and where it comes from.

The program will also feature the premiere of SORROW, with choreography by Lindsey McGill and music by Hsin-Jung Tsai.  The work is based in part by the painter Vincent Van Gogh’s masterpiece drawing of a woman entitled Sorrow.

 

The Label Project Community Workshops In Preparation for Performances and Installation at the MATCH and a partnering gallery.  3 Locations Around Houston To Be Announced April 2017.

The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble and visual artist Sandra Tapia Luna will present 3 workshops where members of the Houston community will create their own labels for foods that they eat. These handmade labels will tell the story of where the food comes from and what the food means to each individual. The labels will then be incorporated into a visual installation at the MATCH as part of our performances. Workshops will be free and conducted in both Spanish & English.
 

June 2017: ARTCAST Season 3, Internet Television Series Featuring Dance, Music & Film Created in Houston, New York City & Vancouver.
YouTube.com/brangwendance and Brangwendance.org

The Michele Brangwen Dance Ensemble created ARTCAST, an Internet Television Series that features dance, music and film created in multiple cities. Season 1 premeired in June of 2013 and featured 4 episodes created in Houston and New York. ARTCAST Season 2 premiered in November 2014 featured 8 episodes created in Houston, New York, Los Angeles and Vancouver. ARTCAST Season 3 will premiere In May/June 2017 and include episodes created in Houston, New York and Vancouver. ARTCAST was designed to develop audiences for the arts and also to link both audiences and artists in different cities.

Summer 2017: 3rd Annual Festival of Jazz and Dance at the KoKo Jazz Club, Helsinki, Finland

story:
Hello everyone! We are the Rochester Community Players, one of Rochester’s oldest theatre groups. We have been performing since 1925, when we staged our first production of Wedding Bells. Since then we have been providing Rochester with live and wonderful theatrical entertainment. In 1994 founding member Peter Scribner created the Rochester Shakespeare Players as a subgroup of the community players, where we staged our first production of Twelfth Night. Throughout the last 22 years we have expanded our season to include two indoor productions that are staged at MuCCC, one in the Spring and another in the early Fall. Our biggest production each year is our annual free Shakespeare in the park which we stage in conjunction with the Monroe County Park Department at the Highland Bowl. We consider these shows to be our biggest undertaking of our season, and we draw on the support of our local community and our volunteer organization. Each production we mount at the Highland Bowl required a substantial amount of money to cover the various production elements. This Summer we are proud to be joining forced with the WallByrd Theater. Virginia Monte, the Artistic Director of WallByrd Theater, and the Director of Romeo & Juliet, is excited to be bringing this immortal love story to the Highland Bowl.

This Summer we are mounting an incredibly complex production, which will involve incorporating rented scaffolding towers as part of the Director’s vision. Since this is both a unique concept and a rare expense for us, we are seeking generous contributions and donations from the local community, and from you! Your donation will help to bring this production to life. We also need donations for sound equipment rental, costumes, weapons, lighting equipment and space rental, just to name a few items. We truly cannot do this without you.

Virginia’s vision doesn’t just end with the scaffolding. She envisions Romeo & Juliet as anime and Shakespeare colliding, creating a beautiful, sexy spin on one of the most classic love stories told by the Bard. We have a wealth of new young talent to make her vision come to life. The story will be set in a run down, old church heaped in scaffolding and stained glass. We even have a company turning anime prints into reality, making the costumes come to life. In fact, you can even buy one of these prints made for the show, or even have a costume made for yourself. Check out our perks for more details!
For this production we will need:
$1,000 Weapons Rental
$1,000 Fight Director Fee
$3,000 Sound Equipment Rental
$1,000 Set Rental
And this does not include all of our other expenses.

Performances are at the Highland Park Bowl in Rochester, New York and begin at 8 p.m. each evening July 15 to 30, with no shows on Mondays and Thursdays. Refreshments will be sold each night at the bowl, which is off South Avenue. Admission is free. Limited seating will be provided, so audience members may want to bring a lawn chair or blanket and bug repellant.

Refreshments will be sold each night at the bowl, which is off South Avenue. Admission is free. Limited seating will be provided, so audience members may want to bring a lawn chair or blanket and bug repellant.

story:
Crimson Square & Emerging Writer's Lab

Doing theatre can be a daunting, expensive challenge. Many self-motivated performers end up scraping budgets together from their own pockets. Many writing programs are very expensive and difficult to gain access to. Getting regular readings and feedback on a writing project can be costly and frustrating. This is not a sustainable way to create art! Why put on a show for four weeks that may take you months, if not years to financially recover from. Is there a way to make the shows less expensive? What if all these talented people had a little help? This is where we come in! 

Our Goals:

  • Fund a minimum of 5 shows per year at a professional level
  • Each show will provide the opportunity for someone less experienced to get mentorship from someone who is experienced in that role, whether directing, producing, acting, lighting, stage managing, writing, etc.
  • Create an on-going writer's lab to provide affordable and accessible regular feedback and readings on new and emerging writers.
  • Eventually, produce new works and world premieres that have developed by emerging artists from conception/writing to full stage performance.
  • We are being generously sponsored by the non-profit 501c3 Cheshire Moon (mentoring on how to successfully run a non-profit educational program) and the Beverly Hills Playhouse (providing beautiful facilities and many years of high quality training experience) for our first year. This means that your donations will count as tax deductible. And that even at the foundational level, Crimson Square's concept of mentorship and learning from those with more experience is being put into practice!

You will be providing for the opportunities and education of so many artists and new talents. Please donate today to help us create a supportive, sustainable platform for new artists to gain invaluable experience in theatre!

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We are trying to raise $20,000 (launch our first couple shows and few months of the lab) with a stretch goal of $30,000 (lock in the lab for the year and extend development to our next few shows)
  • We are giving out all kinds of incentives! But mostly, we would love for you to come to see one of our shows!!! Our swag ranges from stickers and mugs, to ad space in our program and free tickets to the entire season. Check it out and claim your swag!!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we will use what we raise to put on our first show and the first 8 weeks of the writer's lab. From there we will continue fundraising for the rest of the year.

Why help us?

  • You can be part of the development and growth of so many artists, who doesn't want to do that?!?
  • Although challenges and pitfalls as to be expected with any new venture, with guidance from our experienced mentors and sponsors, we will have support to grow and learn from any obstacles that arise.
  • You can (literally) watch us grow! From actual performances and open readings, we will have shows and showcases on stage all year round, which means you get the chance to see in real time where your contributions are directly leading to artistic growth and education. How many programs can offer that?

Risks & Challenges

Involving students with mentors means that there will be some learning curves throughout the journey. Putting on professional shows is a huge undertaking. Some shows may not be perfect, some issues may arise throughout the first year, things don't always go as planned, but each struggle has its own lesson.

  • Thankfully we are not taking this journey alone! Between Cheshire Moon and Beverly Hills Playhouse, our project has lots of good guidance.
  • Each step of the way, we are reaching out to someone who has successfully accomplished what we are trying to do and ask for their advice on how to do it well. Even if we run into an unforeseen obstacle, we will always turn to someone who has overcome it before and then overcome it together!

Other Ways You Can Help

Money isn't always just lying around to donate to the arts, we get it!

  • If you cannot give financially, please help by spreading the word. Social media, email, and word of mouth are some of the biggest gifts you could give us!
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools! They have made it extra easy to spread the word!

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT, WE ARE SO GRATEFUL

story:
Who Are We?

It's Not a Box Theatre is dedicated to staging devised, interactive work that explores untold stories and experiments with what it truly means to play. Our newest and most ambitious work is The Overhear Project. 

After two successful productions in Saskatoon, we have assembled teams from around the world (Saskatoon, Toronto, Vancouver, and Paris) to engage with their respective newcomer communities and Indigenous communities to find stories of home and belonging --- and people to tell them, both artists and non-artists.  

The result: four entirely unique interactive outdoor pod-plays, each with their own stories and cast. Audiences are invited one at a time to embark on an outdoor journey, guided by audio narration via a smartphone app, and encounter storytellers who will open their hearts and share their stories -- one listener at a time.

We are looking for funding from you to help us create a new community of artists and audiences! We also can't ask people to do this work for free -- we believe in paying our artists what they are worth, and that is directly where your money will go. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $12,000 to make sure that all of the artists in this project are being paid fairly. That's it -- helping real people make a living, pay their rent, eat healthy food, and not need to work multiple jobs every day. We have received funding from the Saskatchewan Arts Board that covers about 15% of our budget. In order to keep this show accessible, we also aren't setting ticket prices, but rather allowing people to pay what they want to after they have seen the show. Tickets and merchandise sales will not be enough to cover our budget which consists almost entirely of artist fees. 

If we aren't able to reach our goal, the money we do make will be split equally between the artists in each city. Any little bit will help us out.

Hopefully, the wonderful merchandise in our perks will encourage a lot of donations and we will be able to reach our goal! But we can't do it without you. Even if you don't have any money to give, please tell your friends about the show, share the campaign on Facebook and Twitter, or come see us and pay what you can afford to participate in these stories first hand.

The Impact

If we are able to raise enough funds to adequately pay our artists, the resulting show will not only have an impact on the audience who sees it, but to everyone who has ever felt lonely in an unfamiliar place. 

After the live portion of Overhear wraps in each city we will be releasing the Overhear app to the general public, allowing them to listen to any story from the show. Soon after, we intend to open up the platform to ANYONE around the world to write, record, share, and even stage their very own pod-plays -- performed and priced however they like. This has the capacity to not just create a rich digital tapestry of geotagged interactive stories, but to foster a new intimate relationship between our technology, our humanity, and our community. With enough support, we hope to inspire creativity within a new art form and help bring the world a little closer together.

Risks & Challenges

The challenges we face are that international projects are enormous, ambitious, and need a lot of time and investment to make successful. We are working in multiple languages, across time zones, and with people with different understandings of the world. We are young artists who are learning a lot along the way. We are a small company with no established physical location, no large store of funds, and this is our first foray into international production. Every $5 we raise is one less thing we have to worry about, and allows us to focus on the things we need to learn in order to make this show exactly what we dream it could be -- and don't worry, we are learning fast. We are dedicated artists experienced in various forms of independent producing.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't forget that you aren't obligated to buy a perk -- you can set your own donation amount (even $5!) and we appreciate that just as much. We understand that not everyone has cash to spare. But please consider sharing this campaign on your social media, or even attending the show in your community. We would love to see you there. Thank you so much for taking the time to read this and to follow us on our journey! 

For more information or tickets, visit our website or Facebook.

story:
Who We Are

Classical Theatre Company is the only professional theatre company in Houston, TX that produces year round classical drama. We were honored in 2016 to be one of only 7 companies in the country to be first-time recipients of the prestigious National Theatre Company Grant Award by the American Theatre Wing (the same folks who run the Tony Awards). Now entering our 11th season, CTC looks to expand its programming with more free readings, single night events, a Lecture Series, and more! But in order to keep our readings free and our ticket prices low, we need your support!

Our Mission

The Classical Theatre Company is dedicated to boldly re-envisioning classical drama on the stage, in the community, and in the classroom through engaging and enlightening plays - bringing them new life and relevance while maintaining the integrity that the works deserve.

The Skinny...

Classical Theatre Company needs some funds to get our 11th season moving. Funds are always harder to come by early in our season, and so this campaign will help us get our first production off the ground, help us to continue renovation on our facility and ensure that our Shakespeare Outreach program will continue to provide high quality programming by bringing Shakespeare out to the underserved schools, community centers, and population of Houston.

What We Need:

Some seed money to help us begin funding the first production of the 2018-2019 Mainstage Season - The Return of Sherlock Holmes by Arthur Conan Doyle. This production will cost approximately $40,000, and since only about 30% of those costs will be covered by ticket sales, the balance will need to be raised from other sources.

What You Can Do:

Donate, donate, and donate! Additionally if you have any services, materials, or other in-kind donations in lieu of monetary contributions, please contact us at info@classicaltheatre.org

The Impact

Your funds will go directly into our operations costs, both artistic and administrative. They will help provide wages for our artists and technicians as well as purchase costumes and scenery and supplies necessary for our Shakespeare Outreach program. Your generosity is what allows us to continue to bring high-quality and critically-acclaimed classical productions to our young and growing audience on our stage, and help to bring Shakespeare to our constituents out in the community.

story:
Konnectivity Contemporary Dance Company

We are a brand new Contemporary Dance Company based out of East Greenwich, Rhode Island and we are seeking the public's help to sponsor our first ever live dance performance titled "The Human Narrative" debuting Sunday April 11th. Since theaters aren't open we had to get creative and will be hosting our performance at The Barn at The Guild in Pawtucket. It is a beautiful space but completely raw which means we need to rent flooring, lighting, pipe and drape to create a "theater" experience, sound engineers etc. We are hoping that some willing donors and art/dance enthusiasts might consider sponsoring our show.

We have some perks available for those that wish to donate as a thank you.

Any help will be greatly appreciated. Any funds left over will go toward paying our company performers (who have been displaced from their cruise ships, teaching events, performances etc since Covid started last year) and future shows. We are excited to introduce ourselves to the Rhode Island community and hope to bring a beautiful and intimate performance to life with your help.

Please visit our Instagram page for details about the company and our upcoming events
Instagram: Konnectivityco

Email us for ticket information - konnectivityco@gmail.com

story:
HELP US GET TO $10,000!

We set the bar low at $7,000 because if you fall short of your goal you only  keep a smaller percentage...but we are really aiming for $10K !

**Also see our new BLACK LIGHT BEATLE  POSTER PERK INCENTIVE below**

HERE'S THE BASICS...

Erik Patterson has written a remarkable play inspired by -- but not “the story of” -- Uma’s experience.  As with all his plays, it has a serious topic at its core, but the very real, quirky characters Patterson populates his plays with provide for an extremely entertaining evening filled with moments of rich humor and powerful emotion. 

We are excited to bring this amazing play to life, BUT WE CAN’T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!!

We have a theatre space, but we still need….

     -  

     -  Costumes (six actors, multiple scenes….over 40 changes!)

     -  Designer stipends – We believe these talented theatre artists should be   compensated for their work

     -  Programs, postcards, a banner for the front of the theatre, etc.

You get the idea.  We need to raise about $10,000.00 to mount the production we think this script deserves.  We are hoping to raise at least $7,000.00 of that with this campaign. 

All gifts are tax deductible, as Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)(3).


 

THANK YOU for Helping Bring This Script to Life

Hopefully some of our perks will inspire you.  But even more important we hope supporting great theatre and this exceptional script will inspire you.  We will be grateful for any donation, no matter how small.  And, if you have no funds to give, you can still show your support: 

  - Help us spread the word.  Tell your theatre friends AND your Beatle fan friends about our campaign.

  - Share us on Facebook and other social media sites.

And don’t forget to come experience “I WANNA HOLD YOUR HAND” opening August 1st  (with your help) at Theatre of NOTE!



IF YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PLAY AND OUR TEAM, READ THIS…

Some of the greatest critical and commercial successes in the 32 year history of Hollywood’s respected acting company Theatre of NOTE have come from the works of playwright Erik Patterson. His four NOTE productions account for almost one third of all Ovation Award nominations in NOTE’s history.  His last two plays, RED LIGHT, GREEN LIGHT and HE ASKED FOR IT, both received “Best Original Play” nominations and were remounted in larger venues due to ticket demand.  ALL of his full length plays received the difficult to achieve LA Weekly “Theatre Pick of the Week.”  

His latest play “I WANNA HOLD YOUR HAND” explores how our lives can change in an instant.  One moment you’re getting engaged and a few surreal moments later you’re sitting among a group of strangers in a hospital waiting room praying that your fiancé will survive a brain aneurysm. At least, that’s what happens to Ada.  While waiting for Frank to wake up from a coma she meets Julia, Paul and Josh who are waiting for their mom to recover as well.  A tenuous friendship is born.  These characters take a look at life, death and recovery, and what all of that means when you step back out of the waiting room and try your hand at living again.

The show is slated to open at our theatre on 1517 Cahuenga Boulevard in Hollywood on August 1st, 2014 with talented director McKerrin Kelly at the helm. Our design team includes, William Moore Jr. doing scenic design, Boscoe Flanagan designing lights, and Tony nominated sound designer Cricket S. Myers providing sound. 

 

IF YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ABOUT OUR BEATLES PERKS, READ THIS…


The Beatle related items were collected by one of our producers, who was an avid fan back in 1964, the year “I Want To Hold Your Hand” was released.  These are all guaranteed 1960’s originals, not reproductions.  As so many items are unique, perk categories are not cumulative, items offered are specific to that price point only, and once they are claimed that category is finished. 

Here are some details about the perks:

BEATLE TRADING CARDS, all originally purchased in 1964, each card delivered in a protective plastic sleeve.  The first Beatle Trading Cards issued by Topps were B&W (series #1) with Blue facsimile autograph of one Beatle, followed by Series 2 & 3 all in 1964 at the height of “Beatlemania”.  Special “Hard Days Night” and color cards also followed in 1964. These cards are 50 years old, and were collected by a child, so condition is not “mint.”  Most cards are in fairly good condition, however.  Cards with obvious damage (folds, writing, and tape residue from childish attempts at displaying them) are offered in a separate category. 

PIECE OF NUMBER 10 MATTHEW STREET, LIVERPOOL: – The building housing the original Cavern Club, the “cellar full of noise” the Beatles played so often before international fame hit, closed in 1973 and was demolished to make way for a subway ventilation shaft (for a train line that was never built!). A “facsimile” opened across the street, and when our Beatle obsessed producer visited the new club in August of 1974 and the manager brought him across the street to show him the remains of the original building.  The manager unlocked the fence so our producer could take a small chunk of brick from the rubble.  Chips from this unusual souvenir are being offered in three perks: “I Love John”; “I Love Paul” and “I Want to Hold Your Hand”.

ORIGINAL PICTURE SLEEVE– Framed.  (45rpm record not included.)  The sleeve shows some signs of age and wear, and a small hole where Woolworth’s had stapled on a price tag (see photo, under the “H” in “THE”)

Theatre of NOTE is a 501(C) 3 tax exempt institution, so your donations are tax deductible.  You will receive a donation letter, but we are required by law to deduct the value of the merchandise sent.  For perks involving Beatle Memorabilia, we will deduct 20% from the donation total for merchandise value.  Some of the individual cards may actually be worth a lot more (see http://en.wikicollecting.org/the-beatles-trading-cards) but setting exact values on collectables is difficult.



BLACK LIGHT BEATLE POSTER PERK INCENTIVE

The first person to win any one of the following perks also gets this classic (ca 1970) black light poster featuring The Beatles:
--THE I LOVE GEORGE
--THE I LOVE RINGO
--THE I LOVE JOHN
--THE I LOVE PAUL
--THE I WANT TO HOLD YOUR HAND

There is only one poster.... so only the FIRST person to claim one of these five perks gets this.... (pretty cool eh?) 
Note: The poster is NOT mint condition, it hung on a wall in the 70's, there is tape residue on the back and some loss of paint along the edges from being rolled up for storage (see photo below) but overall in pretty nice shape for it's age.

HAND” explores how our lives can change in an instant.  One moment you’re getting engaged and a few
surreal moments later you’re sitting among a group of strangers in a hospital
waiting room praying that your fiancé will survive a brain aneurysm. At least,
that’s what happens to Ada.  While
waiting for Frank to wake up from a coma she meets Julia, Paul and Josh who are
waiting for their mom to recover as well. 
A tenuous friendship is born. 
These characters take a look at life, death and recovery, and what all
of that means when you step back out of the waiting room and try your hand at
living again.
The show is slated to open at our
theatre on 1517 Cahuenga Boulevard in Hollywood on August 1st, 2014
with talented director McKerrin Kelly at the helm. Our design team includes, William Moore Jr. doing scenic
design, Boscoe Flanagan designing lights, and Tony nominated sound designer
Cricket S. Myers providing sound.  
  
IF
YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ABOUT OUR BEATLES PERKS, READ THIS…

The Beatle related items were
collected by one of our producers, who was an avid fan back in 1964, the year
“I Want To Hold Your Hand” was released. 
These are all guaranteed 1960’s originals, not reproductions.  As so many items are unique, perk categories
are not cumulative, items offered are specific to that price point only, and
once they are claimed that category is finished.  
Here are some details about the
perks:
BEATLE TRADING CARDS, all originally purchased in
1964, each card delivered in a protective plastic sleeve.  The first Beatle Trading Cards issued by
Topps were B&W (series #1) with Blue facsimile autograph of one Beatle,
followed by Series 2 & 3 all in 1964 at the height of “Beatlemania”.  Special “Hard Days Night” and color cards
also followed in 1964. These cards are 50 years old, and were collected by a
child, so condition is not “mint.”  Most
cards are in fairly good condition, however. 
Cards with obvious damage (folds, writing, and tape residue from
childish attempts at displaying them) are offered in a separate category.  
PIECE OF NUMBER 10 MATTHEW STREET, LIVERPOOL: – The
building housing the original Cavern Club, the “cellar full of noise” the
Beatles played so often before international fame hit, closed in 1973 and was
demolished to make way for a subway ventilation shaft (for a train line that
was never built!). A “facsimile” opened
across the street, and when our Beatle obsessed producer visited the new club
in August of 1974 and the manager brought him across the street to show him the
remains of the original building.  The
manager unlocked the fence so our producer could take a small chunk of brick
from the rubble.  Chips from this unusual
souvenir are being offered in three perks: “I Love John”; “I Love Paul” and “I
Want to Hold Your Hand”.

ORIGINAL PICTURE SLEEVE– Framed.  (45rpm record not included.)  The sleeve shows some signs of age and wear,
and a small hole where Woolworth’s had stapled on a price tag (see photo, under
the “H” in “THE”) 
Theatre of NOTE is a 501(C) 3 tax exempt institution,
so your donations are tax deductible. 
You will receive a donation letter, but we are required by law to deduct
the value of the merchandise sent.  For
perks involving Beatle Memorabilia, we will deduct 20% from the donation total
for merchandise value.  Some of the
individual cards may actually be worth a lot more (see http://en.wikicollecting.org/the-beatles-trading-cards) but setting exact values on
collectables is difficult.BLACK LIGHT BEATLE POSTER PERK INCENTIVE
The first person to win any one of the following perks also gets this classic (ca 1970) black light poster featuring The Beatles:--THE I LOVE GEORGE--THE I LOVE RINGO--THE I LOVE JOHN--THE I LOVE PAUL--THE I WANT TO HOLD YOUR HANDThere is only one poster.... so only the FIRST person to claim one of these five perks gets this.... (pretty cool eh?)  Note: The poster is NOT mint condition, it hung on a wall in the 70's, there is tape residue on the back and some loss of paint along the edges from being rolled up for storage (see photo below) but overall in pretty nice shape for it's age.

This campaign is over but if you would still like to support our project, you can contact us at: bbagatourian@gmail.com

http://www.kpfk.org/index.php/programs/51-michael-slate/8037-tmss-140418#.U1GHfaJgySo

 

As Featured on TRUTHOUT! http://www.truth-out.org/speakout/item/22898-the-time-of-our-lies-howard-zinn
