-----------------------------------------

WE NEED ONE SMALL ACT TO GET US TO THE

THE EDINBURGH FRINGE FESTIVAL 

AUGUST 1, 2014
---------------------------------------------------------

        

 A Play About the Life & Times of
Howard Zinn

The piece unravels through Zinn's personal story as it brings to life the stories of other soldiers of war, examining whether there can possibly be better solutions to mankind's problems. It draws upon various Dickensian and Orwellian characters whose comments are interwoven into the narrative along with puppets, multi-media and Butoh dance. The format is loosely that of Greek Tragedy with lyrics from Howard's work for the chorus to rap as he struggles to represent the voice of the people. We follow Zinn's story as the primary narrative beginning with the bombing of a village in France during WWll and how he continued on his life's journey from there.

"A wonderfully imaginative play that uses my father's words as the unifying thread. Songs, nursery rhymes and tapped-out rhythms add a playful lightness and humanness that illuminate the horrors of war."  
                                                                Myla Kabat-Zinn


                            2 Minute Interview by Bianca with Howard

WHAT WE NEED:

5 ACTORS, 2 PRODUCERS, A DIRECTOR, A PLAYWRIGHT AND A STAGE MANAGER to travel Edinburgh and live there for 30 days and perform each night! We need to pay for our venue, lights, puppets, props, music, and videos to put on the play. And we need to eat. That's it!

Edinburgh is the leading theater showcase in the world and we really want to put out Howard's message to the whole world! We think we can reach our goal, but just in case we dont, we will put on the play here in the United states of America which will still be nice.

PLAYWRIGHT

I'm a playwright who had the honor of working with Howard Zinn before he passed away. When I first met him, I said I wanted to do a play that turned entertainment into news as so much news was entertainment. He shook my hand and we were off. He saw the first draft and said:

"Bianca, of course with a play, so much depends on how it is staged before, who is performing, etc. But what you have here is both lively and substantive." 
                                                          Howard Zinn

DIRECTORJosh Chambers was the Artistic Director & Resident Composer of Fovea Floods Theater from 1996 – 2008 where he created over 30 productions. 

"Having directed Howard before, I share his desire to connect with our ancestry and dig deep into history."
                                                                 Josh Chambers 

PRODUCERS
Michael Blaha and Nigel Miles-Thomas have been taking plays to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival for over 14 years. In fact they had a hit play there last year. Here they are and if you want to read more about them: 
                                                   Fringe Management Site

SONG CLIP:"A Sailor Went to Sea, Sea, Sea" :30

        SONG LYRICS FROM THE PLAY:

               Who are you making war against?

             The tyrant or his people?

             Because the people of Iraq,

             and the people of Afghanistan,

             are people like us.

             People like you and me.

             Like the kids in school

             on every Main Street.

"The term 'just war' contains an internal contradiction. War is inherently unjust, and the great challenge of our time is how to deal with evil, tyranny, and oppression without killing huge numbers of people."
                                                            Howard Zinn

Theater forces an audience to come face to face with issues, there is not mute button here. Howard wrote three plays himself as he realized the impact of his words. We can do this together. One small act is all it takes!


  1. Forward link to friends
  2. Share! Share! Share!  (use share tools above)
  3. Tweet
  4. Pray
  5. Share it on your Facebook page
  6. Make some noise for us!

::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::QUOTES:::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::

"Exciting project.Very clever title! Howard would chuckle."  

David Barsamian, ALTERNATIVE RADIO
http://www.alternativeradio.org


"Howard would sooooo appreciate this project!"

Paul Alan Smith - Howard's Hollywood Agent


"We need to decide that we will not go to war, whatever reason is conjured up by the politicians or the media, because war in our time is always indiscriminate, a war against innocents, a war against children. War is terrorism, magnified a hundred times."

Howard  Zinn

THE WORLD IS MADE OF SMALL ACTS.

ANY SMALL ACT WILL DO.

HOW DID GREAT MOVEMENTS START?

THE PEOPLE SAW IT THROUGH.


                                          JOSH CHAMBERS BIO.
Josh has also produced his original plays Dollbody, Goose/Goose, Paul Pry (Saratoga Stages, Saratoga Springs, NY), Mount Weather (DC Arts Center, Washington, DC), & Bull Spears (CSV, NYC).  In 1999, he co-wrote & directed A Sleep of Reason Creates Monsters with Scott Feldsher for the 1st Annual Chekhov Now Festival at Access Theater, NY. In the fall of 2002, he co-wrote & directed Not in Our Name – "An Evening of Conscience" at The Great Hall, Cooper Union in NYC, which included Edward Asner, Danny Glover, Tony Kushner, Marisa Tomei, Wallace Shawn, Andre Gregory, & Howard Zinn. In June 2003 & June 2004, Chambers was guest artist with LAByrinth Theater Co. at their summer intensive, where he directed workshops of Brett C. Leonard’s Guinea Pig Solo, & Alice Tuan’s Hit. At CalArts, he directed Erik Ehn’s Book of Tink, Monteverdi’s Orfeo, an original adaptation of Hamlet entitled "A Toy in Blood”, & his own adaptation of Ibsen’s Ghosts.  In 2004, he directed the world premiere of Erik Ehn’s Medusachrist at the REDCAT theater space in LA. For Perfect Disgrace, in Boulder, CO, he directed Brian Bauman’s Elegy for a Mid-Shipman, & Porridge. In 2008, he directed & composed his own adaptation of Miss Julie at Sledgehammer Theatre, San Diego, as well as the Gold Star For Robot Boy extravaganza for acclaimed rock band Guided by Voices in NYC. In 2009, he directed Big Bro / Lil’Bro by Jonathan Ceniceroz for Company of Angels at the Alexandria Hotel, & an original adaptation of Moliere’s Tartuffe for The Theatre at Boston Court, Pasadena. In Jan 2013, Chambers presented the first installment of his original play, Speed Curses, at the Collar Works Art Space in Troy, NY.

                                  COLLAGES BY JOSH CHAMBERS

story:
Just Me

My name is Marsalis AnderSon-Clausell.  I am a freshman in high school with a 4.0 GPA.  I am newly 15 years old and I have been blessed with classical ballet training for 8 scholarship seasons at Metropolitan Ballet Theatre.  This audition year, I earned a five-week full tuition, room and board to attend the Orlando Ballet School this summer.

My mom is so proud of me, however, as a single of three children: me, my twin brother and little sister - she can not afford the transportation and daily money support.  She has promised to get me there, even if she has to walk to Orlando, FL from Atlanta, GA.  (And she probably would), but I want to help her help me.

Need

My mom is a bookkeeper and she is willing to give receipts to anyone who donates.
She told me to tell you exactly what the money is for.....

  • Proper replacement of dance apparel (shoes, tights, shirts and dance trunks)
  • Car travel from Roswell, GA to Orlando, FL (including gas, overnight hotel stay)
  • Car travel back home for my mom and family
  • Money for me to have access to while I am in Orlando, FL (for emergencies and necessities)
  • Car travel and hotel for my family to return to Orlando to watch my final show
  • Car travel to get home

Impact

My mom works really hard, but it is hard to make ends meet.  We talked about this fundraising with a friend for a long time before my mom finally agreed to do it.  

Dancing at Orlando Ballet School this summer will be a dream come true.  This is my first time away from home and I am nervous, but I am ready.

My heart is classical ballet.  As long as there are theaters and an audience, I will dance.

Other Ways to Help

I know that you may not be able to contribute, but would you please take one second to pass this along to a friend who may be willing to assist in my 2014 Summer Intensive at Orlando Ballet School.

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this.

story:
The Project Rushmore Theatre Company  is a non profit committed to exploring the American Spirit. The Company brings to life the voice of America, in its many forms, presenting plays that offer inspiration and insight into the American culture.
We take inspiration from the Works Progress Administration of the 1930's (WPA). Like that program, we aim to create jobs in the Performing Arts.
Last year we produced the NY Premiere of Jane Anderson's THE QUALITY OF LIFE and Paul Rudnick's VALHALLA.
Project Rushmore believes strongly in giving back to the community. We presented a benefit reading of E-MAIL 9/12 by Midge Guerrera whose proceeds went to the National September 11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center.
THE PLAYS
This year Project Rushmore is presenting the NY Premieres of EXQUISITE POTENTIAL by Stephen Kaplan and WORLD OF SINATRAS by Seam O'Connor both Directed by Sydnie Grosberg Ronga. 
 In EXQUISITE POTENTIAL all parents think their children are great. Alan Zuckerman just happens to think his 3-year-old son, David is the Messiah. Thirty years ago , Alan and his wife, Laura, visited their rabbi to verify David's possible divine nature.  Thirty years later, David has grown up and the answer to his father's question is revealed. EXQUISITE POTENTIAL is a funny and probing look at the bond between parent and child. Cast:  * Bob Ader, *Matt Biagini, *Rachel Evans, and *Vince Gatton.
In WORLD OF SINATRAS it's the 60's, Vietnam, the assassinations, sex, drugs,civil rights and rock n'roll  burn up the American streets. In suburban New Jersey young Sammie Murdock struggles with boyhood, adolescence and an alcoholic father who threatens to tear the family apart.  In WORLD OF SINATRAS a hard and bitter resolution is earned by all in this tender, volatile, and at times , wildly funny play. Cast: Justin Cimino, *Danielle Degado, Sarah Elmaleh, Dennis Ostermaier, and *Jeff Rubino.
* Members of Actors Equity Association
WE NEED YOUR HELP
Any contribution that you are able to make will assist us in bringing these two amazing plays to life. NO DONATION IS TOO SMALL! There are countless expenses inherent in producing live theatre and the economics of doing so means that ticket sales don't come close to covering costs. And with generous support from champions like you, Project Rushmore can reach their goal allowing our projects to soar.
Your donations will help the Company pay for such things as :
Theatre Rental
Licensing Fees
Insurance
Scenery
Props
Lighting
Costumes
Programs 
Publicity
OTHER WAYS TO HELP
We need your help in spreading the word of our fundraising campaign! Wether you are able to donate, or not, please assist us by encouraging friends, relatives and colleagues to visit our fundraising page here on Indiegogo. Check out our video at the top of the page for information. Sharing our quest will make all the difference. 
Thank you so much for taking the time to review our project. Won't you consider donating now, to help with our success. No donation is too small or too great. Your support will be greatly appreciated and means the world to us. 
Sincerely
Adrienne Doucette / Founding Artistic Director
PROJECT RUSHMORE THEATRE COMPANY - EXPLORING THE AMERICAN SPIRIT!
EXQUISITE POTENTIAL by Stephen Kaplan and WORLD OF SINATRAS by Sean O'Connor both Directed by Sydnie Grosberg Ronga will be presented in Repertory July 15th through August 3rd at the Arclight Theatre in NYC. For more information and to make reservations go to projectrushmorenyc.org or call 212-927-6765

For more information and to make reservations go to projectrushmorenyc.org or call 212-927-6765

story:
We're almost there!!!

Only a few hours left and we're still pushing till that finish line. Please donate and share, we're gettin there!

*********************************************

THANK YOU SO MUCH to all those who have donated thus far! Please keep sharing!


Swerve Dance Company  kindly invites your support and contributions  in reaching our objective of $17,500, to assist in funding our first year of operation. Please take a moment to read on, and help us to meet (or exceed) our goal! 

Your support is critical in fulfilling our mission objectives.....EVERY amount helps.

EACH DOLLAR DONATED, HELPS PAY A DANCER FOR A PERFORMANCE, PAY FOR OUR TRAVEL EXPENSES, PAY FOR A COSTUME AND MUCH MUCH MORE!  EACH DOLLAR DONATED HELPS US SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT OUR SHOWS AND HELPS US BUILD OUR AUDIENCE BASE! 

In other words - your donations are making it possible for us to come onto the scene swinging. With only a few dollars, you are making it possible for local artists to live our dreams!

The Impact

Each year dance companies struggle to maintain and expand upon their programming while providing an adequate level of compensation to contract workers, dancers and employees.

Historically Dancers have been the worst paid artists (next to poets) and we are working hard at Swerve to change this (Yes even Dancers need to eat! We want to provide fair salaries for our working artists!)

No one goes to a dance performance to see the lighting/sound technician however they are almost always the highest paid person working the show. Ironically the dancers (the stars of the show) are most often coming in last place.

This fundraising campaign will be used to directly help us to pay small performance honorariums to our dancers (some of whom have invested thousands of dollars and hours into their training, but have never been paid to perform), as well as fund rehearsal space, costuming, and production costs.

Think about donating to this project in this way... by making a contribution to our campaign:

YOU are helping to directly pay a Dancer for performance!

YOU are helping to provide a costume or prop to a dance production!

YOU are ensuring the continuation of contemporary dance as an artform in your town!

YOU are keeping Swerve Dance Company creating and performing dance works in your community!

YOU are showing that you believe that local art is important and has value.


Generosity from people like you can make a real difference to our performers, the quality of our productions, and to the potential reach of our company. 

Check out our fabulous perks for campaign supporters!

For more information on the Swerve Dance Company please check out our website at www.swervethecompany.com.

If we do not reach our entire goal via indiegogo, we will continue to fundraise via events and parties until our goal is reached.


Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate financially?  Volunteer your time!  We are always looking for ushers, administrative help, production help, etc.  Get involved today!

Contact Cera Byer at swervethecompany@gmail.com,

Another important way you help:  HELP US SPREAD THE WORD ABOUT THIS CAMPAIGN!  Please share this information on your social networking sites, via Facebook and Twitter, through emails, and word of mouth!

story:
The Night Shift produces intimate theater in New York City focusing on the fundamental beauties of performance and story. We want to encourage an audience that’s as tightly knit and invested in what we’re doing as we are.

Our first production is:

DANNY AND THE DEEP BLUE SEA: AN APACHE DANCE

by John Patrick Shanely

Under St. Marks

March 6th-17th

 To ensure the success of our first undertaking, we ask for the emotional and financial support of those who understand and may share our intent. The hardest year for a business to survive is its first. We need you to act now! Your support allows us to consolidate our fan base, build our local reputation, raise the visibility of the company and become eligible for seed capital only available to more seasoned groups. The Night Shift has purchased the performance rights to the play, we’re marketing our production now, and we’ve acquired our performance space. If our $3,000 goal is reached, we promise to offer 3 performances with free admission. If we reach $4,000, we promise to offer free admission for all performances!

 Check out all the perks you can get if you donate to this campaign!

  • Authentic Wild Alaskan Smoked Red Salmon
  • A hand crafted heirloom quality made to order Comb-Back Windsor Chair
  • Premiere tickets to a Manhattan Theatre Club show

And there are many more perks that can be yours just for making what we’re offering possible!

We are a company that acts as a springboard to launch the careers of up-and-coming artists. The Night Shift is a home where artists feel fulfilled and inspired in their work.

Even though there are scores of companies in New York City competing for attention, venues and resources, we champion deserving FSU/Asolo alumni and other enterprising individuals who contribute to the community that we’re nurturing.

With your support, The Night Shift members will have the opportunity to educate and reach out to communities by creating work outside of the corporate mind-set. Using the tools they know best, The Night Shift strives to remind ourselves and others of our greatest likeness—the human experience.

If current circumstances do not allow a donation to this campaign, we understand. Please help in another way! Share this site with anyone and everyone you think would be interested in giving. And visit, share, and “like” our Facebook page! 

Thank you,

The Night Shift

Danny Jones, Katie Cunningham, Derrick Olson and Ron Kagan

story:
I was accepted into the Orchard Project 2013 Core Comapny this week, and am proud to say I could not have done it without the help of all my great mentors, fellow collaborators, and theatre patrons in the greater Albuquerque community.

Because of all of you, I will be spending 5 weeks in the Catskills of New York this summer workshopping a project of my choosing. The ideas and gears are churning and all I need is a few funds to reach my goal to get there and make the best damn art a girl can make! 

Here's a link to the program so you know I'm not skamming you:

http://www.exchangenyc.org/orchardproject

My long term goal with developing this new work during the summer is to bring it back to this community that has given me so much vitality and breadth in my art, and share in the collaboration of theatre making. 

I'm asking for $1,000, particially for costs of the program and for travel expenses. The pay off? I'll be bringing this unforseen project back into our Albuquerque backyard!

Again, I can't thank everyone enough for their sincere support throughout my years learning, working, and loving every minute of it here in Albuquerque. 

 

Sincerely, 

Stephanie Grilo

story:
Charming Monsters

Is a provocative new play written by Aaron Rothermund, and produced by Afterglow Theatre in the FRINGE of Toronto festival 2013.

Recently Aaron directed FACIO (Vanier College Productions 2013), INTO (New Face Entertainment 2012), And Tell Sad Stories of the Deaths of Queens (Afterglow Theatre 2012), BROZEN (VCP 2012), and AMBIGUOUS (Afterglow Theatre 2011 - winner of the Trey Anthony award.)

Charming Monsters

Written by Aaron Rothermund

Afterglow Theatre

CAST -

Kevin Rees - DAVID

Jamie Sampson - CATHERINE

Roselie Wiliamson - CASSANDRA

Lea Russell – CLAUDIA

Eve Wylden - LILITH

Kathleen Goodleaf - JEFFERIES

Kyle Mac – HENRY

CREW –

Aaron Rothermund - Director

Bryan Hall - Prod. Manager (LX, Props, Set.)

Sam Aylsworth - Costume Designer

Bob Wiseman – Sound Designer 

Any donation will help, and move us toward the goal of rental of space, equipment, pay fees, build sets, props, costumes and allow for a small artist honorarium.

Please consider donating to independant Canadian theatre and recieve awesome perks.  You can also have your name in the program as a Glowing Patron of the arts! 

If you are able to help in any way I would appreciate it. Pass on this link, campaign, spread the word and make some noise!

story:
Less than 1 month to go until opening night! 

This year’s Not-Two Is Peace Dance event is pivotal for the future of this unique collaboration.

 

THE EVENT

Over July 22 and 23 in a spectacular multi-media event at Florence’s Bargello Museum—one of the city’s most prized historic buildings—the grace and talent of dancers and musicians will combine with Adi Da's Art.
 
Not-Two Is Peace is an adaptation by the Florence Dance Company of the masterpiece book by world friend Adi Da. Not-Two Is Peace is part of an ongoing collaboration between The Florence Dance Company and the Art of Adi Da,  that began in July of 2008 in a Piazza in Florence, Italy. Since then 3 major ballets that have been performed in Italy in the course of over 50 public shows. This now continues in 2012.

The Florence Dance Company

The resident company, and producers of the Florence Dance Festival now in it's 23rd year, is The Florence Dance Company. Artistic direction is led by its founders Marga Nativo and Keith Ferrone.  The choreography for this event is by Keith Ferrone, with Mario Ancilloti directing the orchestral ensemble. Original music will be contributed by premier Florentine composer Andrea Portera and by Naamleela Free Jones, who will also perform live.

By helping to support this event at this crucial time you are helping us to bring the whole ballet to a level that will go well beyond the Renaissance City of Florence, Italy with the creation of a 3D film in one of Italy's most majestic theaters, Teatro della Pergola, which is already on the planned schedule for 2013. 

Not-Two Is Peace Dance film in 3D

We have recently joined forces with an award-winning 3D filmmaker, Dado Valentic. Not-Two Is Peace Dance will be recorded as a ninety-minute 3D feature to be screened in theatres internationally. Heading up the team for the 3D film of Not-Two Is Peace will be Dado Valentic and London Director Terry Gross. Both are considered to be the UK’s top 3D specialists. Dado’s past work includes Harry Potter movies. Filming the performance is a natural albeit, until recently, wholly unexpected, extension of the work’s multi-media ethos. We are looking forward to some compelling results!

Once we have pre-production financing, with any excess funding we can move forward with the promotional trailer to seek broadcaster financing for the feature-length film we are set out to create.  In order for us to deliver the quality documentary film, we need funding. With your funding help through Indiegogo, we'll be able to move forward on this film with less of a funding hurdle. 

HOW TO SUPPORT

With arts funding being cut in cities all over the world, and pretty drastically in Italy, it will take a community to actually keep the show on the road. Crowdfunding on Indiegogo is a model that ties in with some of the keys messages of the book Not-Two Is Peace bin that this is an "everybody all-at-once" model that has the potential to make great things happen, or where a collective of small ripples can make the wave.

Your funds will help with production costs for the July 23rd Not-Two Is Peace
Dance event so that the event is successful.  Initial funds will go directly the cover essential production costs, including lighting, performers and promotion.  What is raised here through Indiegogo is our last chance to make this happen. Your support will directly help complete the production in order to bring this incredible performance to the world this July, along with supporting the future of this collaboration. 

In exchange there are many wonderful incentives such as a beautiful image from the dance fabricated in Glass which is 3 feet wide by 4 feet high.   With great perks on offer in return for your support- this is a fun and easy way to take part.

Three ways to help

  1. By contributing $1 - $1,000, and gettting yourself a great perk!
  2. Spreading the word & sharing the campaign
  3. Making a one off donation and become a patron of the event

It starts here, with you.

On behalf of 'The Team', we welcome your participation and thank you for your support. We look forward to connecting with you on the site, and please feel welcome to get in touch if you have any questions or comments.

Grazie Mille,

Ric, Luke, Sophia, Renee and everybody who has participated in this event.

www.dapeacedance.com

FIND US ON FACEBOOK

FOLLOW THE EVENT ON TWITTER

 

You can enjoy some of the previous performances here

http://youtu.be/fUnwCTm6n4Y

http://youtu.be/8GR53mw1i0U

...and here: 

http://youtu.be/EDFj8ErdLt8

story:
FUZE 2014

We need your help!

  • We are the England's largest student run Fashion, Dance and Music Event that has raised over £65,000 for charities worldwide since its establishment.
  • This year's show, 21st and 22nd February 2014, is set to be the best yet and we hope to raise as much money as we can for our chosen charity, Anti-Slavery International.
  • FUZE is run solely by students of the University of Bristol, entirely for charity. It not only allows us to showcase our talents through performance, but enables first-hand experience at producing a large-scale event for the many hands involved behind the scenes.
  • Each and every year the show is a huge success due to the generous support of you, our sponsors, family and friends. 

Without you FUZE 2014 would not be possible

  • We start with £0.00 as we gain no funding from the University itself and therefore to ensure the event is a success we need some support to get started! We appreciate even the smallest donations.
  • The committee needs to ensure a positive and wide reaching audience and your money will help support our promotional activities in order to sell out both nights. 
  • Additionally your support will go towards the deposit for our beautiful venue. The event is held in Bristol's iconic Brunel's Old Station. 
  • With your help in supporting FUZE, we will not only be mounting a prestigious event, but more importantly, we will be supporting and raising awareness for the incredible work of Anti-Slavery International.
  • In 2014 Anti-Slavery International will be marking its 175th anniversary, a stark reminder that slavery is still prevalent around the world. As one of the UK's slavery hub, Bristol students want to raise awareness to the plight of those still enslaved.

The Impact

  • FUZE 2014 is the most eagerly anticipated event in the Bristol University calender.
  • Over its 11 year history, FUZE has grown in reputation in calibre and because of your support we hope to increase its prestige this year.
  • We hope to see you at the event, so you can see for yourself the hard work and talent of the students involved in the event. With your help it is on track to be a fantastic show!
  • So please, take a look at our video and thank you in advance for your time and generosity.

More!

Our 2000 strong audience over the two nights and huge on campus publicity through our pre show events ensures significant exposure to our key sponsors. If you believe that your company would benefit, please don't hesitate to get in contact. We would love you to get involved!

story:
We're participating in #GivingTuesday initiative from 12 am PST to 11:59 pm PST on December 3rd. For every $20 contributed to our campaign #Indiegogo will contribute $1 to our campaign. Please share the news with your family, friends and neighbors.

About Us! 

Founded in 2009, P.E.A.R.L.S is a community based program focused on empowering and mentoring girls, aged 5 -1 8 in Washington, DC. Our after-school programs focus on character development, community service, academic excellence and health and fitness. Our goal is to reduce teen pregnancy by 10% by 2023 while encouraging our sisters to be Powerful Educated Ambitious Respected Liberated Sisters.

Over the past four years, we’ve managed partnerships at Cesar Chavez Charter School - Parkside Campus, Hart Middle School, Fort Davis Community Center and Center City Charter School - Capitol Hill Campus. This school year, we’ve added Cesar Chavez Charter School - Capitol Hill Campus and SEED Public Charter School to our roster. 

Why do we need the P.E.A.R.L.S Monologues??? 

We’re bringing the P.E.A.R.L.S movement to the theater with The P.E.A.R.L.S Monologues: For Young Girls Who Wear Pearls and we need your help to raise a portion of the funds, to start the development and production phase.

These intimate and personal stories will bring awareness to the challenges teen girls face and their efforts to overcome them. We, their parents, teachers, administrators, youth advocates and peers, need to hear these stories. They need to make some noise, so we can hear and better understand them. 

There will be 5 performances in Washington, DC, starting in the Spring 2014 and a grand finale at the 2014 DC Capital Summer Fringe Festival.

Our monologues are:

  • Leave Me Be (bullying)
  • Single Young Mom (teen parenting)
  • Black & Blue (teen dating violence)
  • Nickles & Dimes (poverty and homelessness)
  • SistaMom (raising siblings)
  • No, Not There (sexual abuse)
  • Jump In (gang violence)
  • Beyond (college bound)
  • My Parachute (LGBT)
  • Daddy’s Girl? (abandonment, single parent household)
  • Mirror, Mirror (self-esteem, puberty)
  • Turn Up (substance, alcohol & drug abuse)
  • Picture Freak (social media, sexting & online dating)


This is how we want to say thank you…..(see our great perks to the right).

Here’s how your generous contributions will be disbursed for the development and production stages:

$15,900 - Hire production staff and creative staff, purchase costumes, equipment, props

       ​and travel expenses.

$8,950 -  Rent space for auditions and rehearsals and secure venues.

$2,450 - Marketing and advertising.

$2,700 - Administrative and overhead expenses.

Help us make more noise!!!

We would sincerely appreciate it, if you make some noise about us. Share our campaign via Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, with your family, friends, co-workers, friend of friends, everyone. 

Website: http://www.pearlsinc.org/

Instagram: http://instagram.com/pearlsdc#

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/PEARLS

Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/pearlsinc

Vimeo: http://vimeo.com/dcpearls

story:
Mazzilli Dance Theatre has been invited to perform its latest production ‘For How Much?’ at the International Dance Festival in Beijing (China). We need your help to raise money to cover the cost of performers’ flights and visas (9 people).

About the Festival:

The Beijing Dance Festival is an international dance festival held annually in Beijing, China. Together with the Guangdong Modern Dance Festival in Guangzhou, China Dance Forward in Hong Kong, the Beijing Dance Festival forms the biggest nation-wide contemporary dance platform aiming to promote creativity and exchange. Organized by Beijing Dance/LDTX, the next edition of the Festival is scheduled to take place from July 14-26, 2013 in Beijing http://www.beijingldtx.com/Dancefestival-EN.html

Dance Camp, as part of the festival, will take place from July 14-20 (MDT will be teaching classes during the Dance Camp)

About the work and Mazzilli Dance Theatre:

‘For How Much?’ is choreographed by Annarita Mazzilli with original score by composer Andy Higgs.

Using a mixture of live and recorded music this dance theatre piece raises questions about human trafficking for forced labour, and how what we buy affects the lives of others. Originally commissioned by the International Organization for Migration U.K. (IOM) as part of their Buy Responsibly campaign, this piece takes inspiration from the lives of the people who have worked under forced labour in India, Africa, South America and parts of Europe and from the sculptures by London-based artist May Ayres and her critique of consumerism and capitalism. http://mayayres.com/index.html

The work has been already successfully performed at The Blue Elephant Theatre, the Belfry (St John on Bethnal Green) and at The Place Theatre.

"A powerful and deeply human choreography, performed with energy and emotion, For How Much? is thought-provoking and moving." London Dance

The piece has been supported by ‘One Billion Rising Festival’

Mazzilli Dance Theatre aims to make dance more accessible to non-dance audiences with work which references reality in both its themes and movement vocabulary. It also aims to develop awareness and challenge audiences’ perceptions of the society we live in through the medium of dance and theatre. Its work often uses costumes to create a connection between the ordinary, everyday world and the more abstract world of dance. www.mazzillidancetheatre.com 

Why you should help:

  • To raise awareness on the issue of human trafficking and slavery beyond Europe and especially in a country like China.
  • To reward and allow the company to say thank you to all the performers involved in the production, for all their hard work and dedication to the piece, its subject matter and the company.

Morena De Leonardis, Ester Escolano, Nacho Garoz, Arwen Hobday, Donovan Morris, Lina Pettersson, Lizzie Streeter, Andy Higgs have been working on this project for no money for more than 1year.

  • To promote and expose European/British art/dance overseas and create opportunities for future collaborations and exchanges.
  • To support the future of an emerging Dance Theatre Company, the work of the choreographer and the people involved.

An incentive for you:

To the first 10 donations of minimum £50:

A Free ticket to our next show + a free dance class part of our seasonal workshops

To the first 10 donations of minimum £30:

A free ticket to our next show

To the first 20 donations of minimum £20:

A free dance class part of our seasonal workshops

To any donations from education organisation of minimum £100:

A free dance workshop of 2hrs at your institution

To any donations from local/small businesses of minimum £100:

Your logo to be included in all our publicity material for the festival in China and on MDT website

To any donations from bigger business of minimum £200:     

Your logo to be included in all our publicity material for the festival in China and on MDT website

To any one that would like to give us support in-kind please contact us on mazzillidancetheatre@yahoo.co.uk

Mazzilli Dance Theatre would like to thank all the friends, people and organizations that have supported our work up to this point and also would like to thank in advance all the ones that will allow us with their contribution to participate at the Beijing Dance Festival. We really need your help and any penny counts.

For more info about our work or on how to help us please visit:

 www.mazzillidancetheatre.com

Or contact Annarita on mazzillidancetheatre@yahoo.co.uk

story:
WITHOUT THEATER, COMMUNITY AND LOVE 

WE CAN'T HEAL THE WOUNDS of Suicide

The Emerson Theater Collaborative and New York Playwright, Suicide Activitst, Producer and Actor, Josh Rivedal express our commitment to finding a solution to Suicide by creating the I AM WORTHY PROJECT.

Problems are temporary. Suicide is permanent.  

Using Theater to find the solution is the cure.

 I AM WORTHY PROJECT

On April 5th -7th , 2013 The Emerson Theater Collaborative will embark on a three day educational seminar & performance by Joshua Rivedal (The Gospel According to Josh) - A one man show that encompasses a 15 character, 7 song show, about a small town boy who follows his dreams to Hollywood despite the tempestuous relationship with his pious father. Along the way he must navigate his religious upbringing, an escape to New York, his starring roles in two reality TV shows,and ultimately his father's tragic suicide.

This weekend movement will begin the conversation about suicide prevention awareness that will continue on monthly basis within our surrounding communities. 

This is a community wide event open to all

Our goals are ambitous!

To provide an educational outreach arts community program that brings about awareness, prevention and educational solutions for the treatment of suicide prevention. It is our hope to use this production to show how theater arts can be use as an educational outlet to educate people and save lives. Suicide is an epidemic, and we realize more than ever the need to have a conversation within our communities, to help heal the wounds associated with suicide. The need to look at the root causes of this epidemic is of valuable importance to all of us. 

To enlist the help of our community, educators, business leaders, law enforcement and elected officials to open the door to educating themselves and others about suicide. To provide the help, nurturing, love and guidance for youth, adults, military veterans, law enforcement and other professionals who cannot find a way out.

We believe we can we win the battle by using theater to open the door.
 
The funds raised will go to producing "The Gospel According to Josh", educating our patrons, and communities about suicide, and its devistating effects. The funds will also provide QPR training for those patrons, business leaders and teens who wish to help save lives.
 
We ask that you take a moment to help the Emerson Theater Collaborative and Josh Rivedal to find the solution to this devastating epidemic.  We thank you in advance for your contributions to help us heal the wounds of suicide. LOVE heals and WE are all WORTHY of it.
 
 
ABOUT EMERSON THEATER COLLABORATIVE
 
The Emerson Theater Collaborative is a professional theater company whose mission is to serve youth, under-represented communities and artists with an emphasis on diversity. The Emerson Theater Collaborative’s goals include reaching inner city youth through educational theatrical programming, to support our local communities by providing free admission to our performances to low-income families and donating profits to humanitarian causes.
 
ABOUT JOSH RIVEDAL

As an actor, Josh has appeared on stages from New York, to Chicago, to Orlando and has worked with Broadway and TV vets, Kelli O'Hara and Piper Perabo. His voice has been heard in numerous national TV commercial campaigns. Additionally, Josh has served as producer on several New York City theatrical productions. He is also owner of Artful Coaching Resources, a business and career coaching and consulting firm for arts professionals and small business owners. Josh also serves on the board of directors for the New York City chapter of The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention and the advisory board for Elijah's Journey, a Jewish Response to Suicide and Prevention.

REVIEWS: Other Reviews

Show Business Weekly Says

"The Gospel is a personal yet lighthearted show about one man's 
journey to discover his own fate and identity. The fact that there is a slew of songs and caricatures thrown in makes for a smooth and amusing ride."

WANT TO HELP BUT CANT DONATE?

  • HELP US SPREAD THE WORD!
  • TELL YOUR FRIENDS AND FAMILY - To come out and Support this Project.
  • COME AND SEE THE PRODUCTION AND JOIN THE CONVERSATION

 

Don't forget to check out the video! 

 

Peace,
 
Camilla Ross and Josh Rivedal,
Partners in healing

story:
I am Alaina Viau. I work professionally as a stage director, conductor, producer and stage manager of opera and classical music. I am passionately interested in everything that the world of classical music has to offer. And I love every aspect of theatre! My most inspiring education came from working at the Royal Opera House (ROH) in London UK. There I attended every event from opera to ballet. I savoured the world's best productions and artists.

I started this company to do something really different with opera and other staged works. After experiencing the creativity of the Royal Opera House, in London UK, I felt that Canada really deserves the same.

I don’t want to copy what I experienced; I want to add a unique voice to the international stage. I want Canada to have something to say about Opera in the 21st century. Canada is known for having incredible artists but rarely do we get the international recognition. To be recognized we need to push the envelope with a new ideas. No copying, no regurgitation, no recreations. We need to explore new creations. The talent exists to create new performance art and Loose TEA is the vehicle and platform to express these new ideas and herald in a new movement of Opera experiences.

ABOUT LOOSE TEA Music Theatre

Savouring the delicious diverse flavours in a cup of fine tea inspires the senses. LOOSE TEA Music Theatre is a new company who is exploring the flavours of music from the refined traditional with the excitement of diversity.

LOOSE TEA draws its strong inspiration from the mechanics and artistry of a score mixed with the influence of talented musicians to create new affecting sounds. LOOSE TEA is a creative exploration of how opera and theatre can interact with each other. This is a company that focuses on the "nitty-gritty" of character - a concept where music comes from the depths of an actor's analysis and their journey on stage.

We seek to collaborate with artists in all disciplines to explore different textures and flavours. We want to explore the boundaries of a work to see how far they can be pushed while still maintaining the integrity of the original intention.

The productions aim to be accessible to a broad audience. The talent is spectacular. The artistic direction imagines a world that has never been experienced before. With our brilliant production team on deck, LOOSE TEA is able to embark on an incredible journey that will be sure to leave the audience begging for a second cup.

 

Our Team

LOOSE TEA, like any performance art form, exists to helps us understand and experience life in a way that no other medium can. Music is a universal language. Singing uses the most basic of human communication – the human voice. We have a dedicated, talented and experienced performers and production team for this inaugural presentation for LOOSE TEA.

Let me introduce you to them:

PRODUCTION:

Director/Producer- Alaina Viau

Music Director- Jen Tung

Language coach- Steven Leigh

Assist. Producer- Tessa Dickison

Assist. Producer- Claire Vignon

Assist. Director- Ben Wardle

Costume Designer- Maureen Russell

Lighting Designer- Oz Weaver

Production Manager- Alan Viau

Tech support Stuart- Baulch

 

CAST

Carmen- Cassandra Warner

Don Jose- Ryan Harper

Micaela- Lisa Faieta

Escamillio- Gregory Finney

Zuniga &Une Vielle Gitane- Keenan Viau

Garcia & Lillas Pastia- Candi Zell

Frasquita- Tessa Dickison

 

Where we need help

All funds raised will go to the production of this musical presentation. Here is the budget for the show:

Item Budget
Space $1,700.00
Set/Props $750.00
Lighting Rental $500.00
Lighting Designer $500.00
Costume $600.00
Costume Designer $750.00
Language Coach $750.00
Stage Manager $1,000.00
1 Equity Mezzo $3,000.00
1 Equity Tenor $3,000.00
2 non-equity singers $300.00
2 actors $250.00
Music Director $1,000.00
Artistic Director $1,000.00
TOTAL $15,100.00

 

PERKS:

Every donation can be directed to any line item in the budget. Your donation will be acknowledged in the program and online for the donated line item at the following levels:

Bronze: $25

Silver: $100

Gold: $250

Platinum: $500

Angel: $1000

 

For example,  Lighting supported by John Smith (Silver), Jane Booth(Gold)

Angel funding will receive recognition in sponsoring the show on the program.

PLEASE PROMOTE OUR CAMPAIGN TO SUPPORT A NEW ARTS VENTURE - TELL YOU FRIENDS AND FAMILY!

story:
Catie Cuan Dance would love to invite you to be a part of our first Philadelphia performance and Fall season!

Founded in the spring of 2013, Catie Cuan Dance (CCD) is a Brooklyn-based contemporary dance company.  Often drawing inspiration from literature, visual art, and technology, CCD is also known for their visceral, powerful movement coupled with custom musical scores.  CCD includes dance artists Catie Cuan, Liz Beres, Cassandra Cotta, and Hannah LaBonte. 

Since its inception, CCD has performed at several New York venues, including The Tank, The Actors Fund Arts Center, the Williamsburg Art and Historical Center, and Speyer Hall.  Their fall season includes performances at Triskelion Arts and GreenSpace in New York as well as their first show in Philadelphia as part of the 2013 Philadelphia Fringe Festival!

We are thrilled to be showing our work in Philly and need your help to make it a success!  Your support will enable us to produce the highest-quality show for our company's city premiere.  This performance will serve as the launching ground for planning an entire Northeastern tour and allow us to share our unique artistic works with even broader audiences.   

We ask for your support in producing three new movement pieces for this show!

We have an ambitious goal of finishing three new pieces, "byzantium, sentient", "Gloaming", and "Aberration Stage" by September!  Your generous funding goes to many show-related elements, for example:

  • $5 covers half an hour of studio rental time
  • $10 covers a full hour of studio rental time
  • $25 outfits one dancer with a costume
  • $50 contributes to our festival participation fee
  • $100 pays our professional show videographer or a dancer's stipend
  • $200 rents part of our performance venue
  • $500 produces half our show!  

We are so excited to offer several contribution perks, including:

  • Features in our program
  • Company cards, photographs, and video materials
  • Hard copies of performance footage and musical scores
  • Invitations to the show and private company rehearsal
  • Co-producer status on our website and all performance materials!

Success in Philadelphia would help us launch many future shows and a full Northeastern tour!

With many winning performances in New York and several more to come, we are looking to reach even more audiences across the North East!  Join us as we set off on this happy and challenging journey!

 

There are also many other ways to help!

Reading through this project is an amazing start!  

We would love your help in getting the word out about our show.  Please invite your friends via email, Facebook, text, snail mail, faxes, pages, etc. to...

- Donate to our campaign here on IndieGoGo!  Sharing this campaign is a giant help!

- Buy tickets to the show via Brown Paper Tickets: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/433648

- Visit our website at catiecuan.com

- View some of our previous work by clicking "Gallery" above

 

Please keep in touch and send us a note with any questions, comments, or thoughts. We would love to hear from you!  

Many endless thank yous in advance and cheers to Philly and beyond!

- xo, CCD

story:
“Talk to me about Shame” is a multimedia solo performance that draws on traditions of story telling and audience participation to transform the experience of shame from one that is isolating into one that is empowering, community building, and healing.

We are very excited that the piece will be produced this August as part of the New York International Fringe Festival!  It is a great opprotunity for the piece to reach a wider viewership and further advocate for tolerance, self-love, and connectivity!

And we can't do it alone!

We are hoping to raise $2,000 to help get us to the Fringe Festival. These funds will go directly toward covering the cost of registration fees, rehearsals space, publicity, and production materials. Our pockets are dry so we turn to you with open hearts to aid us in bring this piece to life!

Any amount that you can contribute would be apperciate enormously.  If you aren't in a position to help out financially, fear not!  Feel free to spread the word about the project and fundraising campaign to anyone who may be interested.  

Together, we can create a space where we celebrate shame, build community, and nurture love toward ourselves and each other!

Thanks so much for your involvement!

story:
EL SINDROME DUCHAMP/ THE DUCHAMP SYNDROME

Hola, soy Antonio Vega, co-director artistico de Por Piedad Teatro Foundation, una compañía de teatro mexicana con base en Nueva York. Después de varios años de producir teatro contemporáneo en la Ciudad de México, el año pasado debutamos en Off Broadway con la obra Working on a Special Day en el Teatro 59E59; la crítica nos fue muy favorable y ahora nos emociona anunciar nuestro siguiente proyecto binacional: El Síndrome Duchamp, una que habla sobre la soledad de un conserje inmigrante en Nueva York.

 Hello, my name is Antonio Vega, I am a performing artist and the artistic co-director of Por Piedad Teatro Foundation, a Mexican based Theatre company that reacently starting activities  in New York City.   After a long history of making international theatre in Mexico, we co-produced with The Play Company,  our first  Off Broadway play Working on a Special Day at 59E59 .  We got great reviews from the New York Times, The Village Voice, The Time Out New York, etc. Now we are excited to announce our next project: The Duchamp Syndrome, A one man Show about the Solitude of a Janitor in NY.

 Estamos lanzando esta campaña para producir la primera etapa de este proyecto que consta de 12 funciones (8 en México D.F. y 4 en Guadalajara)  de este espectáculo unipersonal que combina el teatro de objetos con stand up comedy, títeres y otras técnicas.

 We are launching this campaign to fund the first stage of this one man show:  12 Lab performances both in Mexico City and Guadalajara. The Duchamp Syndrome is a a piece of contemporary theatre where toy theatre, stand up comedy, improvisation and puppetry come together.  Where a cockroach comedian, a Chinese fisherman,   an I -Robot  Roomba and a Janitor are the main characters. A piece about solitude but also a homage to the greatest American comedians and the amazing city of New York.

  Tu generosa contribución nos ayudará a levantar este proyecto para así continuar la mision de nuestra compañía: Producir teatro contemporáneo de calidad y relevancia en México y en Estados Unidos; promover la colaboración binacional  y el entendimiento mutuo entre ambas comunidades.

Your generous contribution will help us make this project possible and to carry on with our mission of creating a bridge of mutual artistic collaboration between Mexico and the US and to generate links at every level by opening means of communication that allow for mutual understanding.

 

What We Need & what you get/ Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes.

Necesitamos 8,500 dólares que servirán para el pago de creativos (Diseñador de audio y video, iluminación, escenografía, vestuario) y   para la construcción de escenografía, títeres, utilería y demás gastos obligados de toda producción.

We need 8,500 US dollars that will go towards designers and builders (Audio, Video, scenery, costumes) fees.

Cuando no estoy en escena o preparando algún proyecto, estoy en mi restirador pintando o dibujando, por lo que he decidido donar algunas piezas originales únicas para aquellos amantes del arte que nos quieran apoyar (https://www.facebook.com/Funky13art). Además hemos preparado diferentes paquetes de beneficios que incluyen  la impresión de su nombre en nuestro programa de mano, boletos gratis para la función de estreno y algunas sorpesas más.

When I am not on stage or working on a new play, I am painting or drawing and I will give away my original and unique pieces  as perks to our generous collaborators. You can also earn  free tickets for the play, your name on our playbill,  and more.

 Other ways You Can Help/ Otras formas de ayudarnos.

Si no te es posible colaborar económicamente pero quisieras ayudarnos a levantar  nuestro proyecto, puedes hacerlo compartiendo nuestra campaña con tus amigos.

Otra forma de colaborar es comprar boletos para la obra.

If you can´t collaborate economicaly but you want to help, you can do so by letting other people know about our campaing.

 

More about my theatre company/ Más sobre Por Piedad Teatro:

POR PIEDAD TEATRO (MEXICO CITY): Based in Mexico City, has established itself since 1999 as a creatively relevant company by developing meaningful and profound theatre with a specific emphasis on contemporary international plays, that are both cutting edge and of high artistic quality. Among other productions: In New York: WORKING ON A SPECIAL DAY by Ettre Scola at 59E59 Theater a co-production with The Play Company and HECHO EN MEXICO, a series of public reading of Mexico’s most brilliant new playwrights. In Mexico: THE GOLDEN DRAGON by Roland Schimmelpfennig, LADIES AND GENTS by Paul Walker, PLAYING THE VICTIM by the Presnyakov Brothers,, Sarah Kane’s PSYCHOSIS 4.48, CRAVE and BLASTED, SOME EXPLICIT POLAROIDS by Marl Ravenhill, THE COUNTRY by Martin Crimp, GRACE AND GLORY by Tom Ziegler, and INTERIORS by Woody Allen.

story:
Short Summary

This year I have the honour of being invited to perform at the 8th Annual Fire Dance Expo in San Francisco, and I need your help to get there. I am one of only two Canadian male solo fire spinners invited to perform this year. As an Indigenous artist I am proud to represent Canada and our Indigenous people. I hope you can help me make it there.  

What We Need & What You Get

Airfare: As of March 25th, return flights from Toronto to San Francisco for April 25th are approx $500. This is all I am asking for, help getting there and back.

The perks listed for this campaign come from my love for my art form. As a professional fire spinner I have a number of videos of my public performances and some promotional videos as well. Donations of $50 or more receive increasing video rewards and my sincere thanks.

If I do not reach my full funding goals, I will put whatever is raised towards the cost of airfare. Every little bit helps, so please give what you can.

The Impact

I grew up on a reservation in Northern Ontario called Constance Lake. When I was there I dreamed of seeing the world and of doing great things with my life. I have traveled Canada extensively and feel it is one of the most beautiful places in the world. Now is my chance to make my first ever journey out of Canada. It is also a chance to represent my people at a renowned fire event. I hope that this accomplishment will inspire the youth of my community, and other communities, to pursuit their dreams.

As a fire spinner I have put immeasurable hours of practice into my art form over the last 4 years. I love what I do and I am working hard to make it my living. Performing at the Union Square Fire Dance Expo would give me great exposure for my career. More importantly, it will give me the chance to do what I love for a crowd of 1000s on an international stage.

The 8th Annual Union Square Fire Dance Expo the largest free-to-the-public, legal fire dancing show in the western hemisphere featuring 92 artists in 41 acts creating a 2 hour program and will be held on April 27, 2013 in San Francisco. It is put together by The Temple of Poi. Check out the Facebook event here: https://www.facebook.com/events/217815698362643/?fref=ts. Please also visit The Temple of Poi website: www.templeofpoi.com. 

I have performed at a number of events across Ontario and have always given it my all. I love what I do and I love to entertain. I am really excited to take my passion and skill to the stage in San Francisco. Please help me get there. Every little bit counts, so please give what you can. Thank you so very much.

You can like The Pyroneer on Facebook: www.facebook.com/ThePyroneer

You can follow me on Twitter: @thepyroneer

And you can check out some of my videos on Youtube: www.youtube.com/thepyroneer

 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help by sharing this campaign widely. The more people that know about it, the better my chances of reaching my goal in this short time frame. Thank you very much.

story:
Get Struck by Cupid’s Arrow at First-Ever

Valentine’s Day-Themed Dances for a Small Stage

Beloved Vancouver dance series honours the year’s most amorous day with original performances inspired by love

Vancouver’s dynamic performance series returns this winter for its 28th installment, featuring three days of intimate and enchanting performances in celebration of Valentine’s Day. Dances for a Small Stage 28 runs at the Legion on the Drive from Feb. 14-16, 2013.

Inspired by the whimsical celebration of Valentine’s Day, the series’ immensely talented line-up of local and national dancers will examine all angles of the universal emotion of love – the good, the bad, and the ugly.

“We designed our 28th Small Stage performance in celebration of Valentine’s Day and love in general,” says MovEnt Artistic Producer Julie-anne Saroyan. “Featuring a series of pieces inspired by the emotion that has touched us all, Dances for a Small Stage promises to be an unforgettable evening where truly anything can happen. Bring a date, grab a drink, and enjoy an entertaining night at the Legion on the Drive!”

This February’s three-show run will feature some of Canada’s most impressive and electric performers and choreographers, including both fan favourites and Small Stage first-timers. With dance backgrounds in ballet, contemporary, jazz, and tap, performers include Billy Marchenski, Alison Denham, Donald Sales, Arash Khakpour, Clare Twiddy, Meagan O’Shea, Dayna Szyndrowski, Karissa Barry, and sisters Yeva and Thoenn Glover.

 

About Dances for a Small Stage:

Since its inception in 2002, Dances for a Small Stage has wowed audiences by tearing down formalities and creating intimate, raw scenarios in which to experience dance. The popular series is renowned for bringing unique and innovative contemporary dance, inclusive of all disciplines, to a rough–and–tumble cabaret setting. 

Over the years, more than 200 artists have performed on its 10-by-13-foot stage to packed crowds who enjoy the series’ raucous celebratory atmosphere and cutting–edge choreography. Urban, dynamic and full of imaginative and diverse programming, the Small Stage series has become a mainstay of the Vancouver arts scene with its inventive approach to live dance-theatre. For more information, visit www.movent.ca.

story:
Who is KERL?

KERL is us! A Toronto based improv/sketch team consisting of Kristina Alexis, Emily Stang, Roo Ster, and Lara Fara; Four friends who met while studying at Second City, and made each other laugh so much, we decided to team up and make lots of other people laugh too!

What do we do?

We make people laugh!
In our first year, KERL played dozens of improv shows all over Toronto, gaining fans and having fun. For our first anniversary, we presented a preview of our sketch work - which completely sold out!
Now we’re working on a full 60 minute review - Five shows in one weekend, complete with theatrical visuals, choreography, and of course, enough laughter to make you pee yourself.
 
Show Dates:
Thursday June 20 at 8pm
Friday June 21 at 8 pm
Saturday June 22 at 2pm & 8 pm
Sunday June 23 at 4pm

What do we need?

  • The girls of KERL work for free, but not everybody does!

We need to be able to pay our wonderful production team for the incredible amount of time and energy they’ve invested in our show. This includes our dynamic director, our terrific tech team, and our phenomenal photographer/videographer.
Goal: $175

  • We also need show things!

A lot of our sketches go from “hilariously funny!” to “I’m laughing so hard I’m crying and peeing at the same time!” with a few props and costume pieces.
Goal: $100

  • We need to not be in the dark!

Lighting is expensive, and while our requirements are minimal, we do need to rent a few things (it seemed impractical to have the audience all shine their cell phone screens at us the whole time)
Goal: $225

Are there perks?

You bet! Every contribution level has a perk... And they’re all personalized! You’re helping four girls who really want to make people laugh, and we want to say thank you to each and every one of you.

How else can I help?

Lots of ways!

  • Generate buzz! Tell your friends, family, coworkers, neighbors, pets, and mail carrier about us.
  • Like us on our Facebook page, follow us and retweet us on Twitter, or share our indiegogo campaign
  • If you’re somewhere near Toronto, come see the show! We’d love to say hi, and make you laugh.

What do we do?
We make people laugh!In our first year, KERL played dozens of improv shows all over Toronto, gaining fans and having fun. For our first anniversary, we presented a preview of our sketch work - which completely sold out!Now we’re working on a full 60 minute review - Five shows in one weekend, complete with theatrical visuals, choreography, and of course, enough laughter to make you pee yourself.
 
Show Dates:
Thursday June 20 at 8pm Friday June 21 at 8 pm Saturday June 22 at 2pm & 8 pm  Sunday June 23 at 4pm
What do we need?

The girls of KERL work for free, but not everybody does!
We need to be able to pay our wonderful production team for the incredible amount of time and energy they’ve invested in our show. This includes our dynamic director, our terrific tech team, and our phenomenal photographer/videographer.Goal: $175

We also need show things!
A lot of our sketches go from “hilariously funny!” to “I’m laughing so hard I’m crying and peeing at the same time!” with a few props and costume pieces. Goal: $100

We need to not be in the dark!
Lighting is expensive, and while our requirements are minimal, we do need to rent a few things (it seemed impractical to have the audience all shine their cell phone screens at us the whole time)Goal: $225
Are there perks?
You bet! Every contribution level has a perk... And they’re all personalized! You’re helping four girls who really want to make people laugh, and we want to say thank you to each and every one of you.
How else can I help?
Lots of ways!

Generate buzz! Tell your friends, family, coworkers, neighbors, pets, and mail carrier about us.
Like us on our Facebook page, follow us and retweet us on Twitter, or share our indiegogo campaign
If you’re somewhere near Toronto, come see the show! We’d love to say hi, and make you laugh.

story:
My collaborators and I have been developing and dedicated to this controversial piece about pornography for five years, against all odds. Because of the unique blending of Butoh dance, text and multi-media, this play has required a lengthy process due to its experimentation with multiple forms.

With your generous support, this multi-media performance that tackles how our human communication has been altered through the pornographic lens, can be mounted in it’s full manifestation!

Working closely with adult star, Brittany Andrews, and performance-art legend, Penny Arcade, we have carefully and boldly crafted the text to include everyone’s experience within pornography- including the role of the viewer. That is why YOUR voice, feedback, and contribution is so important to this show. With content being censored more and more, we must take a stand together to support work that is dedicated to going to the dark and illuminating places we are often scared to go to.  

I cannot wait to share this experience with you!

xoxo

Raquel

story:
This show is part of the 2014 Fresh Fruit Festival. The Fresh Fruit Festival is presented by All Out Arts to celebrate the LGBTQ community’s unique perspective, creativity & diversity, and to build links between the LGBTQ artistic communities, be they local or international. The show will be presented at The Wild Project, one of downtown theatre's most up-to-date and beautiful theatres, on East 3rd Street in the East Village.

THE BLUE DJINN by Tom Rowan (Kiss and Cry, The Second Tosca, Faye Drummond) is a tender and magical one-act play for two actors.  It begins at four in the morning.  Alex, a shy, youngish, would-be composer, arrives home in his small studio apartment after a night out dancing.  With him is Blue, a sexy go go boy from the club.  What appears to be a casual if somewhat awkward one-night stand soon takes a very unexpected turn, when Blue tells Alex that dancing is just something he does for extra money: his real vocation is altogether more special and surprising.  Before the end of the night, Alex will have to decide what it is he really wants out of life.

The play has original music by Martin Hennessy.  It is directed by Joshua Warr and stars Sean Hankinson* and Carrington Vilmont*.

*Member of Actors Equity Association. AEA approved showcase.

The play is part of a triple bill of one-acts collectively entitled LEGENDS. Performances will be Friday, July 18 at 9 PM and Sunday, July 20 at 12 Noon at The Wild Project, 195 E. 3rd Street in Manhattan.

The Fresh Fruit Festival provides a very economical way to produce a one-act play. Our show is being presented as an AEA-approved showcase.  Your contribution will help us pay stipends to the cast and staff, obtain prop and costume pieces and an electronic keyboard, and provide production photos and other publicity materials.  This little play has had a long journey to New York (by way of Outworks at Louisiana State University), and your contribution large or small will help make a dream come true.

We are committed to opening the play; all funds contributed will go towards the production, whether or not we make our whole goal.  Contributions of $20 or more will earn a credit and a thank you in the program; anyone contributing $200 or more will be listed as a co-producer.


Other ways to help:

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please forward this to your friends and help us get the word out about our show!
  • Use the indiegogo share tools!

story:
Hey everybody, my name is Jennifer Jajeh. I’m a writer and performer and have been touring the country for the last 2 years with my tragicomic solo theatre show: "I Heart Hamas: And Other Things I'm Afraid to Tell You".

Yes, the show has a crazy title. I know. And yes, we've gotten tons of media praise (check out our reviews) and great audience turnout everywhere we've gone because...well, because 1- it's a good little show and  2- how many people are talking honestly, hilariously and provocatively about Palestinian identity and what's happening on the ground in Palestine? (Plus, the title makes sense once you see the show.)

The show was developed with Director W. Kamau Bell (Comedy Central, "The W. Kamau Bell Curve"). We've been profiled in the SF Chronicle, NBC Bay Area, NOX Magazine, WBAI NYC, the Chicago Tribune, Village Voice and Flavorpill to name a few. And ZYZZYVA, the journal of West Coast writers and artists, published excerpts from the show in its Spring 2010 issue. 

So why should you donate to our little show? (Obviously, I like numbering.)

1-Because you're tired of the overprocessed and recycled stories Hollywood is churning out that don't reflect any sort of reality you recognize AND you'd like to help bring alternative voices, specifically a Palestinian woman's narrative--a particularly fresh, sassy, and humorous one at that-- to the table.

2-Because without your support we won't be able to rent the theatre, print our postcards and posters, pay our lighting guy, rent rehearsal space, work with our director, make a new ASK A PALESTINIAN sign, etc etc. Essentially without this $5000 we will not be able to make the LA shows happen. 

3-Because you want one of the cool gifts in the sidebar.

Want to learn more about us? There are video clips of the show on our Youtube page and tons of info on our website. Thank you for your support and for reading this far! And please help us spread the word about the campaign. 

And no, we don't really know anyone from Hamas. But in case you're still scared, you can always donate anonymously ;)

story:
Our Story

We are a group of Toronto based artists self-producing the play OTHER PEOPLE by Pulitzer Prize Finalist and writer of Dying City, Christopher Shinn. We have assembled a team of award winning artists and rising stars to tell this incredibly honest and moving story about the struggle to connect and make art. Please become a "Friend" to the Mutual Friends Co-op and help us make our dream of this play a reality.

Mutual Friends Co-op in collaboration with Mercedes Grundy will perform the play in a limited engagement January 18th to January 28th, 2012 at the beautiful Tank House Theatre in the Young Centre for Performing Arts in the Distillery Historic District.

The Play

OTHER PEOPLE tells the story of three ambitious young New Yorkers who struggle with sex, desire and their art over Christmas in the East Village. Stephen is a frustrated "blurb writer" and aspiring playwright waiting to hear about a grant. Petra is Stephen's roommate, a wannabe writer who has recently returned from working as a stripper in Japan. Mark is Stephen's ex, a successful screenwriter fresh out of rehab, now a born again Christian crashing on Stephen and Petra's couch and struggling with his attraction to a mysterious young hustler named Tan. What ensues is a heartfelt and hilarious look at love, sex and friendship.


"Shinn writes with graceful compassion about people trapped inside their own skins unable to make sense of their lives."- The Guardian

 

"Edgy, troubled characters, sharply realistic dialogue, and a distinctive milieu."- Times of London

 

"Writing like this is rare."- Independent


The Artists

The production is directed by Dora Nominee Aaron Willis, one of the creators of the hit shows Yichud and The Gladstone Variations, who, together with Julie Tepperman, was named one of "Toronto's most respected theatre duos" by NOW Magazine.

Leading the cast is Genie nominee and two time Gemini Winner Tatiana Maslany in the role of Petra. In 2010, Maslany won the World Jury Prize at the Sundance Film Festival for "Breakout Performance" for her performance in the Canadian coming of age drama "Grown Up Movie Star". Maslany was last seen on stage in the Dora nominated Canadian premiere of Bert V. Royal's Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead.

The cast of OTHER PEOPLE also features Ben Lewis as Stephen (Dog Sees God, "Degrassi", "Scott Pilgrim vs. the World"), Dora nominated Brendan McMurtry-Howlett as Tan (The Overwhelming, Sia), Indrit Kasapi as Mark (Boys in the Band, Still Life), two-time Dora winner Mike McPhaden as Man (Poochwater, Requiem for A Hotel), and Dora winner Richard Lee as Darren (Forbidden Phoenix, Banana Boys).

Mercedes Grundy is producing the show in collaboration with Mutual Friends Co-op.

The show will be stage managed by Monika Seiler with Technical Director Suzie Balogh, Lighting Design by Jennifer Lennon, Set and Costume Design by Kat Misztal-McCubbing and Sound Design by Lindsay Naft.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This play requires a big enough stage to accommodate the various locations outlined in the script. The Tank House Theatre is the perfect venue to realize our vision for this piece as well as to ensure the comfort of our patrons. The theatre is very costly and ambitious given our modest budget, which is funded by our Co-op members and generous supporters. That's where you come in! Any amount you can spare will help us offset the costs of the theatre rental, and allow us to give you the best show possible.


In exchange for your generous donations, we are offering a variety of exciting "Perks"!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about our show and this campaign on FACEBOOK and TWITTER. Check out our easy-to-use sharing tools at the top of this page!


*PLEASE NOTE: Your donation will appear on your Paypal/ Credit Card Statement as "Lemontree Theatre Creations"

story:
Blueprint: How it all came together

Over three years ago Marisa Marquez began writing scenes for New York based theater group, The Collective.  After discovering the scenes started to string together to form the inhabitants of a community, the world of GATED began to take shape.  After major rewrites, sacrificing characters and sadly a few trees (don't worry we recycle) the foundations of a play started to build. Originally 29 characters and actors - GATED has developed into a woven ensemble piece featuring 7 actors playing 24 characters.  This newly crafted, original play was accepted into the popular Midtown International Theater Festival (MITF).  In just weeks the new GATED will premiere in the heart of the New York City theater district with an amazing cast, stellar designers, a top notch director and stage managing duo, and a troupe of phenomenal producers.


Foundation: What the show's about
GATED: The American Dream – SOLD
The mortgage bubble bursts but the residents of Northern California’s newest luxury GATED community have far bigger issues. This humorous drama pries open the gates of these McMansions to expose their flawed inhabitants. Using an ethnically diverse cast of 7 actors to portray 17 residents, they tackle this newly born dysfunctional suburbia. The illusion of the American dream and the perfect home is torn down by the realities
of suicide, mental disorder, child abuse, Iraq, erectile dysfunction and keeps this community GATED.

We have a limited run of only 5 shows in July, check out showtimes at midtownfestival.org

and Buy Your Tickets today!


Building Materials: Where your money will be going
Independent theater is an expensive venture. Passion and kindness keep small productions like this running. With your donation, another costume can be made, another program can be printed, another show can go on. 

This is what your generous donation will make possible:

Rehearsal Space / Publicity / Travel Stipends / Props / Costumes / Programs / Stamps/ Set Construction/ Printed Materials and more…

Construction Crew: Who is involved

Director: Danny Williams
Playwright: Marisa Marquez
Managing Producers: Satomi Blair, Pete Anderson
Stage Manager: Kim Braun
Lighting/Set Designer: David Goldstein
Sound Designer: Ann Warren
Costume Designer: Hanadi Khurma
Prop and Graphic Design: Christine Calabro
Leviathan Lab Producer: Ariel Estrada

Starring: Erin Adams, Andrew Eisenman*, Christopher Kloko, Marisa Marquez, Austin Mitchell, Megha Nabe & Susan Quinn

Production Companies:  Isa Company, 4 Hawk Productions, Leviathan Lab 

 

HELP US BUILD:
Your donation is a crucial building block in helping to create and produce this new work.  So is your presence, come support us and see GATED in July!

Word of mouth is also great way to give us a boost - tell friends and family about our fundraiser and show!  Become a part of the GATED community on Facebook for updates and pictures.


Tweet us on Twitter or send an email to gatedplay@gmail.com we would love to hear from you!


Thank you for all your support,

The Cast and Crew of GATED

story:
Why do we want gas?

Suitcase Shakespeare is driving into this fourth season of touring condensed physicalized Shakespeare.  Featuring maskwork, acrobatics, live music, dance, stage combat, and more, we combine physical theatre with classical theatre to create 'Theatre that Moves.'  We adapted a 5 actor, 55 minute production of Hamlet which opened last year in Chicago at the Den Theatre, featuring a blend of non verbal storytelling with some of the most famous poetry in the English language, accompanied by an original soundscape created by Arne Parrott, who also plays the title role.  Our Hamlet was just accepted into the Kansas City Fringe Festival, amidst 50 other acts from around the nation for five performances between July 19-29.  

Kansas City is over 500 miles from Chicago.  It is the farthest we've ever traveled, and for the longest stretch of time.  And gas prices are... eccentric at that moment.  

The set is built, the costumes are ready... we just need our dang cars to go.  Please help our cars (with us in them) get to Kansas City!

 

Some cool things if we get to go to Kansas City:

  • A new audience in a new state!  They get to see our work for the first time! 
  • We get to share our work and network with artists from all over the country. 
  • We can get reviewed. Professionally.
  • We can have access to schools and libraries in the area to bring our unique perspective of classical theatre to a new generation through school shows and workshops.  This fundraiser would help deduct those traveling expenses from the cost to the school or organization to host us.
  • We get to step away from our day jobs for two weeks to just do Suitcase and let our dream job BE our day job.  

 

We now need to get the $ to get us there: 

  • Gas and traveling (over half of this fundraiser is just for gas to get us there and back again.)
  • Fringe Festival fees
  • Publicity (so people in KC know we're coming!)
  • And anything left over goes to our actors, so they don't starve.  

 

What You Get for giving us gas. 

We have various gifts for filling our cars and our hearts with your support.

Please check out our gifts including a fun and Shakespearian voice mail greeting that will bump up the classiness of your voice mail inbox, and exclusive backstage footage of the show!  

For those special folks that dig deeper, we are creating a very limited number of specially handmade "Patron of Honor" favors, featuring swatches of fabric from some of our past productions. You can have a piece of our past for helping us with our future!  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough.  If a dollar is too much to give, please consider doing one of the following for free to help us on our way!

  • Share this campaign with everyone you know!  There is a share button!  Please!
  • "Like" us on Facebook and follow our antics on Twitter.
  • Write a letter of support for our work!  Please email your support to suitcaseshakes@gmail.com!  What show did you see?  Where was it?  What did you like best about it?  Your support helps us share our work with others.
  • Have old fabric, boots, weird whatits that you don't want in your craftroom/basement/attic/garage?  Please consider donating!  Email us at suitcaseshakes@gmail and we will figure a way to collect your treasures!
