story:
*Mission: To take the LIVE "Breakfast Show with Adam-O!" to the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah from January 19 through January 22.  Peformances will take place at Park City Yoga Studio.

Our goal is to bring more quality LIVE entertainment to Sundance. What better entertainment than a wonderful Kids Show for the whole family that can be enjoyed in between movies! 

"The Breakfast Show" is a live talk show for kids, featuring dancing, sing-a-long songs, pies in the face and endless cereal for all. The ringmaster of the show is Adam-O (Adam Shenkman), who with a bounce in his step (and in his spit curl,) is the titular mascot of the most popular sugary cereal in the milky way!  

Please sponsor "THE BREAKFAST SHOW with ADAM-O" at the 2013 SUNDANCE FILM FESTIVAL!!!

Here are the expenses we'll incur:

*GAS (3 cars):  $1,000

*MOTEL (3 rooms):  $1,000

*PROMOTIONAL MATERIAL & FOOD:  $500

*TOTAL WE ARE ASKING FOR: $2,500

Created by Adam Shenkman, "The Breakfast Show" began in April of 2010 at The Strange Theater. Having outgrown The Strange, the show moved to the 96-seat Bootleg Theater for a highly successful 3-month run in the spring of 2011.  Then followed summer shows at the Comedy Central Stage (in 3D), the Silver Lake Jubilee, an 8-week run at the world-famous Echo in Echo Park and HM 157's Summer Solstice Festival. The Breakfast Show is currently working with Naked Faces Productions to develop the T.V. show! 

Previous Press Coverage:

"Top Five Rockin' L.A. Events You Can Bring Your Kid To" -LA WEEKLY
http://blogs.laweekly.com/westcoastsound/2011/02/attention_punker_parents_five.php
Show Write up from LA Weekly - http://www.laweekly.com/events/adam-shenkman-special-childrens-breakfast-show-919523/

 

GUESTS INCLUDE:

World Famous Storyteller "David Lunch" - Chris Dotson

Chef Kazui - Kazu Nagahama 

Uncle Chickster - Chickster Shenkman

Inky the Centaur - April Hava Shenkman

Bingo the Milkman - Bj Averell

Oona Mars & The Puppet Band - Marilyn Shenkman

Earl, The Children's Show Set Repairman - Jason Pickar

Crew: Tim Schwartz, Austin Shenkman & Nicole Daddona

Starring Adam Shenkman as "Adam-O"

Flyer Art By: Zackary Stover

 

THE BREAKFAST SHOW -- "THE MOST IMPORTANT SHOW OF THE DAY!"

 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!

story:
Who We Are

TE San Pedro Rep offers the Southern California community a unique alternative to the typical L.A. theater experience. A wholehearted celebration of empowered artistic innovation - from every background and medium, TESPR strives to reawaken the creative spirit in each of us. 

True to its name, TE San Pedro Rep is an artistic paradise - a caring, dedicated community fully invested in the work of every inspired craftsman. We joyfully embrace the interdisciplinary nature of performance, utilizing every aspect of human experience to delve further and further into the unknown. Through intelligent and fearless exploration, TESPR is committed to reexamining the fundamental works that have defined performance from Ancient Greece to Modern America. We knowingly stand on the shoulders of giants, casting our vision forward into a new era of American performance.

We remain committed to fueling the next generation of American art, creating visionary work that rattles the foundations of modern performance.

The Campaign

The Goal: $2,000 to transform our Teaching Theatre into an EXPANSIVE, INNOVATIVE, NON-PROFIT ORGANIZATION!

The 2014 STARS of TESPR Campaign will outfit & expand our OUTDOOR STAGE for the upcoming season and bring innovative SOUND support to our new theatrical home: matching our THEATRICAL VISION with TECHNICAL PRECISION. 

Last season's STARS helped bring our MARKETING, LIGHTING, and SET-BUILDING dreams to life by providing vital construction tools, our first lighting board, additional lights and dimmers - and a laser printer that empowered us to market, promote and increase our exposure throughout Southern California.

TE San Pedro Rep stands at the precipice of a most exciting time in our development: AMBITIOUS THEATRICAL WORK matched by increasing TECHNICAL ABILITY + 501 (c)3 NON-PROFIT STATUS will introduce DYNAMIC, TRAIL-BLAZING ARTISTIC PROGRAMS... 

But we cannot reach our goal without YOU - our community of devoted theatre-goers, supporters, and creators!

Will you add a STAR to brighten our way?

Other Ways You Can Help

The success of this project lies in the sense of community it inspires. We believe in the power of community. It is an ever increasing force, a will that can do things that no single person - no matter their talents - can achieve on their own. Put simply, we are Believers. Optimists. Enthusiasts. We invite you to share in our dream - that together we can build an artistic paradise of devoted, passionate, and FEARLESS artists, boldly pushing the boundaries of performance throughout the world!

story:
My life has been dedicated to ballet since I started dancing at 3 years old; I danced professionally when I was 15, left dance at 19, and came back at 30 to have a second round of ballet career in New Mexico and California.  Since retiring from performing the second time I've been choreographing. It's been fantastic so far!

My most recent show (see gallery for clips), Miranda's Storm, had 2 sold out shows, and we were asked to perform the piece at the renowned ODC Theater.  I'm choreographing a new piece for Bay Pointe Ballet right now, and the dancers are wonderful.

I was accepted to the National Choreography Intensive this summer as 1 of 5 Project Tier choreographers. It's an awesome opportunity for me to expand my knowledge of choreography, and to work with world famous choreographers. This workshop will give me new tools to use and help me hone my skills as a choreographer.  I'll be working with advanced ballet dancers for 10 days to create a new piece. My work will be critiqued several times during the 10 days by master teachers and choreographers. This is really a unique experience, and one I don't want to miss!

Right now I'm teaching 21 dance classes a week, including my classes at the Institute on Aging and classes for people with Parkinson's Disease. It's not the most lucrative career, though very satisfying in every other way. I'm asking for a small percentage of the tuition as part of this campaign.  Every bit will help offset the total cost of this great program. Tuition for the program is $1100 (food and lodging is separate).  Raising $550 will mean I can teach focus on my choreography a little more (and teach perhaps a bit less), before the program begins in July.

Your contribution, be it $10, $100 or a "good luck!" is deeply meaningful!

story:
Short Summary

  • We, the Bachelor of Fine Arts seniors of the WMU dance department, are producing our graduating presentation concert this spring from April 15 through April 19 in Studio B of the Dorothy U. Dalton Center.  Our graduating presentation is the culminating project that represents our choreographic and performance studies that will allow us to move on and formulate dance careers of our own. 
  • We are a close-knit group of seniors that differ in terms of aesthetics and interests relating to dance, but we all share an immense passion for the art form. Dance allows individuals to explore the physicality and athleticism of the human body while simultaneously expressing personal creativity, which we hope to accomplish through our graduating presentation.  

Please Help Us!

  • Our goal is to raise $2,500 through our Indiegogo campaign  
  • Contributions will go towards various costs such as costumes, videography, photography, and a guest choreographer to create an original work for our last dance together as college seniors
  • Any amount of contributed funds would be extremely beneficial!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please spread the word about our campaign to other friends, family, and lovers of dance
  • We hope you can join us and see your support utilized through our work on April 15th-19th in Studio B (third floor) of the Dorothy U. Dalton Center on Western Michigan University's campus

    THANK YOU!!!!

story:
For 20 years, Native Voices has encouraged and supported Native American artists to have their voices heard on stage. And now, we need your help with our biggest production to date: Off the Rails by Randy Reinholz (Choctaw), an adaptation of Shakespeare’s Measure for Measure. 

Because the 2014-2015 season marks a milestone in the history of Native Voices, we decided to focus on a very important issue in our nation’s history through this year’s theme, “Legacy and Loss: Stories From the Indian Boarding School.”

Important? Yes.  Heavy? Not in this production. Think Blazing Saddles meets Shakespeare—with Native Americans taking the reins. 

There are a lot of moving pieces involved with producing a play this big and over the top, including set design, costumes, projections, sound, and lights—not to mention our talented group of actors, designers, and musicians who have been known to dance, sing, juggle, and tumble into our hearts. 

Your Indiegogo gift will help fund these elements and allow us to tell this story like it has never been told before. And in return, our generous donors can enjoy fun and exciting perks, like a hand-crafted, one-of-a-kind ham and cheese sandwich while sitting in on an Off the Rails rehearsal in the Autry’s Wells Fargo Theater or a chance to join the cast and play Buffalo Bill or Annie Oakley!

Native Voices at the Autry is the only Equity theatre company devoted exclusively to developing and producing new works for the stage by Native American, Alaska Native, and First Nations playwrights.

We invite you to be part of the fun and celebrate our anniversary year by pitching in to support this groundbreaking production.

Why This Play Is Significant

If you’ve never heard of Indian boarding schools, you’re not alone. This topic is typically absent from our nation’s history books yet the schools affected generations of Native Americans in unimaginable ways. Culture and identities were stripped, languages lost, lifelong friends were made, and unions were strengthened.

The U.S. government created boarding schools in the late nineteenth century. The goal, as proclaimed by founder Henry Richard Pratt, was to “Kill the Indian, and save the man.”

Off the Rails dramatizes the polarizing national tensions in an audience-friendly way by combining knee-slapping comedy, vibrant music, and a set that transports theatregoers to 1886—the era of Buffalo Bill's Wild West. Learn more through our campaign video.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, you can help our cause by sharing our Indiegogo campaign with your friends and family through social media. Every bit helps!

Thank You

Your generosity supports our mission to bring together the stories of all peoples of the American West, connecting the past with the present to inspire our shared future. Thank you.

A portion of your contribution may be tax deductible. Please consult your tax advisor.

If you live out of state and won’t be in Los Angeles to obtain your perk(s), let us know and we'll donate them to a local youth organization.

Off the Rails Credits

Written by Randy Reinholz (Choctaw)

Directed by Chris Anthony

Executive Producer: Jean Bruce Scott

Video Credits

Produced by Spencer Weitzel 

Directed by Elisa Blandford and Maren Dougherty

More About Us

Native Voices at the Autry

Native Voices at the Autry is the only Equity theatre company devoted exclusively to developing and producing new works for the stage by Native American, Alaska Native, and First Nations playwrights. Founded in 1994 by Producing Artistic Director Randy Reinholz (Choctaw) and Producing Executive Director Jean Bruce Scott, Native Voices became the resident theatre company at the Autry National Center of the American West in 1999. The 2014–2015 season celebrates the company’s 15th year at the Autry and its 20th anniversary advancing Native theatre. The company provides a supportive, collaborative setting for Native theatre artists from across North America.

This season, the company established the Native Voices Artists Ensemble to more fully take advantage of the extraordinary talents of its Native actors, writers, musicians, and directors. The Ensemble is devoted to developing new work in a collaborative process as well as supporting Native Voices’ ongoing focus on the work of individual playwrights. Native Voices at the Autry is a member of Actors’ Equity Association, LA Stage Alliance, and the Dramatists Guild, and is a Constituent Theatre of Theatre Communications Group (TCG), the national organization for the American theatre.

Autry National Center of the American West

The Autry is a museum dedicated to exploring and sharing the stories, experiences, and perceptions of the diverse peoples of the American West, connecting the past to the present to inspire our shared future. The museum presents a wide range of exhibitions and public programs—including lectures, film, theatre, festivals, family events, and music—and performs scholarship, research, and educational outreach. The Autry’s collection of more than 500,000 pieces of art and artifacts includes the Southwest Museum of the American Indian Collection, one of the largest and most significant of Native American materials in the United States.

story:
Short Summary

In 2013, on a whim, I threw out an idea to the popular OC Comics Scene group on Facebook and the local internet immediately exploded with interest. My hands were forced and I created my first IndieGoGo campaign for the first Orange County Standup Awards. It went above and beyond my expectations and I don't see why we can't do that again. And again. Every year. Forever. 

This year's event will be held on February 26th at STAGEStheatre in Fullerton, CA

What the award show actually is:

  • A party disguised as a roast disguised as a classy award show! Nobody will be crowned "Funniest Comic" because that's not what this show is. There will be occasional genuine moments of praise, but primarily, these are categories you wouldn't want to be nominated for. 
  • Comedians from all over Orange County and beyond will descend upon STAGEStheater in Fullerton. They will be greeted by a red carpet, photographers, media, a host, an announcer, trophies, a trophy lady, a slide show with fancy graphics, a keynote speech and catering! And more, probably!
  • Tuxedos and fancy dresses are not required, but highly encouraged. Don't be a schlub! 
  • Comedians will know that they have been nominated, but will not know for what category until they're in the theater and the show is rolling. 
  • The night's theme, as with last year, "We Family!"


What We Need & What You Get

If you're a local comic, that's great that you want to present or are hoping to get nominated. But we're not planning anything unless we know for sure that you will be there. And money is the most persuasive and articulate form of RSVP. 

Here's how it all breaks down:

  • Bare minimum to make this work is $400 (theater, staff, awards & photography) but there is no reason to stop there. 
  • An additional $200 gets us free Thundergoat Tacos for the entire night. 
  • Indiegogo & Paypal want about $50 total. (Obviously more if we make more.)
  • The more funding, the more outlandish this event gets.
  • $12 Pre-Sale Tickets get you in the door. If you are a local Orange County standup comic, we'll consider you to present and/or "win" - if we think it fits. We just need the pre-sale to at least know you're coming. 
  • $14 tickets will be available at the box office the night of the event. We'll be glad to see you. We'll likely talk about you. You won't present or "win" anything. 
  • $25 Pre-Sale Tickets get you and a +1 into the event. You are also automatically guaranteed a Technical Achievement Award which will be handed out at the top of the show, in a category that roastfully fits you. Additionally, you will be eligible to "win" in other categories as well as present - because we know you will be there. If your +1 is another Orange County comic, they will gain entry, but no personalized Technical Achievement Award.
  • Own a business? $75 gets you add space on our red carpet photography backdrop! 


The Impact

There is no charity attached to this event, but...:

  • It will be heavily photographed. Fancy dressed comics holding awards (fake as they may be) all hanging out with each other having a great time will not only raise awareness of our scene but perhaps bring us together?
  • Recent new year resolution comics won't have to wait so long at open mics.
  • "Winners" can totally use their award credit in their show fliers!
  • Most importantly of all, we will be handing out the prestigious Johnnie Flowers Lifetime Achievement Award to an individual who has made an amazing impact in the local comedy community.


Other Ways You Can Help

Share this event with other local comedians. 

Admittedly, this is event is pretty "inside baseball", so I can't imagine anybody outside our festering scene giving a damn about all this. And rightfully so.

But if you're feeling generous...  

  • Repost!
  • Reblog!
  • Retweet!

Thank you for your time!


-Erik Wargo / @erikwargo

The more funding, the more outlandish this event gets.
$12 Pre-Sale Tickets get you in the door. If you are a local Orange County standup comic, we'll consider you to present and/or "win" - if we think it fits. We just need the pre-sale to at least know you're coming. 
$14 tickets will be available at the box office the night of the event. We'll be glad to see you. We'll likely talk about you. You won't present or "win" anything. 
$25 Pre-Sale Tickets get you and a +1 into the event. You are also automatically guaranteed a Technical Achievement Award which will be handed out at the top of the show, in a category that roastfully fits you. Additionally, you will be eligible to "win" in other categories as well as present - because we know you will be there. If your +1 is another Orange County comic, they will gain entry, but no personalized Technical Achievement Award.
Own a business? $75 gets you add space on our red carpet photography backdrop! 
The ImpactThere is no charity attached to this event, but...:
It will be heavily photographed. Fancy dressed comics holding awards (fake as they may be) all hanging out with each other having a great time will not only raise awareness of our scene but perhaps bring us together?
Recent new year resolution comics won't have to wait so long at open mics.
"Winners" can totally use their award credit in their show fliers!
Most importantly of all, we will be handing out the prestigious Johnnie Flowers Lifetime Achievement Award to an individual who has made an amazing impact in the local comedy community.
Other Ways You Can HelpShare this event with other local comedians. Admittedly, this is event is pretty "inside baseball", so I can't imagine anybody outside our festering scene giving a damn about all this. And rightfully so.But if you're feeling generous...  
Repost!
Reblog!
Retweet!
Thank you for your time!-Erik Wargo / @erikwargo

story:
Hello,

My name is Paul Lim and I am writing on behalf of our long awaited 2013 Gracias Choir Christmas Cantata.

Gracias Christmas Cantata is a show-stopping musical event that has touched the lives of people in over 40 countries around the world for the past 13 years. Gracias Christmas Cantata has been performed in venues like the Sydney Opera House, the Masonic of Detroit, and Madison Square Garden and in front of presidents, mayors, national ministries, and other prominent individuals. This show has really touched a lot of citizens here in Motor City and your donation is greatly needed at this time. The recession as well as the Auto Industry and the news of bankruptcy, has caused many citizens to lose hope, devastation to many homes in almost every where they turn. Tickets for this show generally run for $100 but seating for this show has always been free, YES FREE SEATING! Why do you ask are we doing this with nothing in return? Are mission has always been the same; to bring hope, joy and happiness back to the people of Detroit.


The intent of the Gracias Choir Christmas Cantata is to deliver the message of change and encouragement in their hearts to the youth and families of Metropolitan Detroit. We aim to bring the community together to witness a global phenomenon; the Gracias Choir Christmas Cantata. Your helpful donation will solely be used for the purpose of Theatre rental, equipment rental, preparation, and food. 

It’s no secret we love the holiday season. It represents a time when our homes are brighter and more colorful from all the beautiful decorations in our homes and the beautiful smiles on our faces. At Christmas, we long to fill our hearts with thankfulness and love through the time we spend with our families and the exchange of gifts and joy.

With 3 beautiful music-filled stages (Birth, Happiness, and Glory), and 1 eternal message of hope, Gracias Christmas Cantata instills in its audiences the true meaning of Christmas: the birth of hope, love, and God’s forgiveness in each and every one of our hearts. Please visit www.iyfusa.org for more information.

We thank you for your much needed support and hope that YOU as well, can join us on this most joyous and promising event. Thank You!:)

Sincerely yours, 

Paul Lim, Pastor and Member of IYF Organization

story:
Short Summary

We are looking forward to putting the labors of the second year of this show in October and are hoping that you would like to be a part of making it happen.  The Cheeky Geeky Vaudeville is a variety show including any and every facet of fandom suitable for the public eye. It will include but is not limited to: burlesque numbers, dance, and live music which are inspired by Marvel and DC comics, anime, Disney, and much more.

We are currently looking for sponsors in order to adequately meet all of the financial
needs of this event and would love to have a chance to work with advertising your establishment at our show. We have created packages to show our deep appreciation for any assistance you might be able to lend in making this event happen.

What We Need & What You Get

Packages:
$15:  Name/business logo is added to the show program for participants to view

$25:  Name/business logo is added to the show program for participants to view, and will be added to the projection screen load that will be shown at the beginning of the show and during intermission.

$75:  Name/business logo is added to the show program for participants to view, it will be added to the projection screen load that will be shown at the beginning of the show and during intermission, and it will be added to the final show poster which the business will be given a copy of as well as a DVD of the show.

$100:  Name/business logo is added to the show program for participants to view, it will be added to the projection screen load that will be shown at the beginning of the show and during intermission, and it will be added to the final show poster which the business will be given a copy of, a DVD of the show and we will create a live advertisement for you during our show in-between acts .

$150:  Name/business logo is added to the show program for participants to view, it will be added to the projection screen load that will be shown at the beginning of the show and during intermission, and it will be added to the final show poster which the
business will be given a copy of, a DVD of the show we will create a live advertisement for you during our show in-between acts , and will receive a 2014
calendar featuring all of the performers.

The Impact

We want to show the geek community that there is are safe, healthy and fun outlets to enjoy their fandoms in a creative and inspiring way by utilizing talents and abilities.

Other Ways You Can Help

Word of mouth! Sharing our campaign to raise money to help put on our little show, buying a ticket or sharing our Facebook page with others who may be interested in helping our dream grow.

story:
Hello! We are Apostrophe S and we would love A Moment of Your Time* and more than a moment of your money.

*GET IT IT'S THE TITLE OF THE SHOW 

Our Story: 

Taylor Kay and Tess Phillips were born 22 and 19 years ago respectively in St. Joseph's Hospital in Kansas City, Missouri. They still do not know who St. Joseph is but they thank him for his hospital. What a stand up guy. 

As they grew, they were given too much love, attention, and affirmation and came to believe that their opinions and dreams were worth something. They did everything together - they played on the same basketball teams, they were in the same theatrical productions, and they even ate the same food (Taylor Kay always got to chew it first though!)

Now they would like to do comedy together - they would like to do it at the Kansas City Fringe Festival - and they would like you to pay for it. (You handsome devil, is that a new ascot?)

Our Time Your Money: 

But this is America - land of capitalism and TRADESIES! So - based on what kind of donor you are, you will get cooler things than less cool and/or rich (OH NO PROBLEMATIC EQUATION OF WEALTH WITH SOCIAL STANDING) people and maybe one of those things will be stronger sentence structure who knows. 

To the right are the kinds of donor you can be and your just rewards (done in time increments because TOPICAL)! 

Real Talk: 

We are funny, we are loud, and we are in love - with each other and our city and this crazy thing that we want to do. Any little contribution helps to cover production costs and other expenses that come with mounting an original show in a festival like this. Thank you - sincerely - for this moment of your time.

story:
SO MUCH IS HAPPENING!!

**PLEASE NOTE... Because we do not yet have our own 501c3 status, we are working under fiscal sponsorship of Mesa Encore Theatre. Your receipt will come from that organization, but the funds will come to us.**

The Bridge Initiative successfully launched in 2015 through a generous grant awarded by Arizona Commission on the Arts, AND due to generous donors like (and maybe including) you!  We have a lot on tap for the next year, and as we actively apply for new funding, we are once again asking for your support. 

  • Across industries, a recognition is growing that women have not received equal treatment, pay, encouragement, or attention
  • Since inception, The Bridge Initiative has produced a world premiere and countless readings by female playwrights, identified and hired numerous female directors, been asked to speak at two national conferences on gender parity, and furthered the conversation in the press both locally and nationally
  • We now aim to legally incorporate and broaden the scope of our offerings
  • We have forged alliances with other theatres across the country, and this year's new work contest winner will ALSO be read at: 

          

WAMTheatre in MA               Magnolia in OH                 InProximity in NYC


What We Need...

Here are our anticipated expenses:

Filing for incorporation & 501c3     $540
Promotion (swag, printing, marketing)     $450
Gala (space rental, insurance, printing, etc.)  $1,085
New play workshop:
        * Actors (8) & stage manager  $1,000
        * Director, asst dir (& musical director?)  $1,200
        * Printing      $150
        * Out of town artists (travel, per diem, housing, car)   $2,500
                                                                         Workshop TOTAL=  $4,850
                                                                                             TOTAL=  $6,925
*We currently have approximately $1,200


...and What You Get!

Perks for your donation, in addition to our heartfelt thanks, include:

 


  • Tickets to Building Bridges: A Gala Celebration, November 12th, 6pm-9pm Helen K. Mason Performing Arts Center, 1333 E Washington St, Phoenix
  • Reserved seating for our gala
  • Bridge Initiative T-shirts and hoodies
  • Dinner hosted by Bridge leadership and one of our featured artists
In the happy event that we could surpass our goal, not only will we be able to pay our artists a stipend, but we will be closer to offering a true professional wage for their time and talents and we can build towards a "Bechdel Test Fest" of new plays in the spring and our ultimate goal of a full production in the coming season.

**NOTE: Children are welcome at our gala. If you have a little one who you know can be trusted at this kind of event, please bring them. Cost: under 5: free. 5-18: $10. Children's tickets available at:  http://mesaencoretheatre.com/shop/building-bridges-gala-celebration-child/


The Impact

With professional theatre and theatre artists becoming endangered in Phoenix, as well as a continued dearth of female voices represented onstage in the Valley of the Sun, the need for The Bridge Initiative is more pressing than ever.  Your funds will help us:

  • Workshop a new play, bringing another female playwright's words that much closer to her premiere production 
  • Provide the rare opportunity for Arizona artists to collaborate with a New York director experienced in new play development 
  • Through our network, launch a new work on the development pipeline both here and with our partners in MA, OH, and NYC
  • Present low-cost and free workshops on writing, auditioning, technique 
  • Build and strengthen a community of artists who support one another and celebrate women, both locally and nationally


Other Ways To Help...

If you can't contribute financially, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Volunteer for our gala
  • Help us solicit donations for the gala
  • Share this campaign with others in your network with whom you think our mission will resonate
  • Talk about gender parity. Attend plays written and directed by women and featuring strong female characters. Tell producers that female voices are important to you.

We're all in this together and we could NOT do it without you. 

We're bridgin' it!

www.bridgeinit.com

Through our network, launch a new work on the development pipeline both here and with our partners in MA, OH, and NYC

Build and strengthen a community of artists who support one another and celebrate women, both locally and nationally

story:
Who We Are

The Classical Theatre Company (CTC), founded in Houston in 2007, is the only professional theatre company in the State of Texas that produces year round classical drama.  Due to the unwavering popularity of the classics both regionally and worldwide, CTC recognizes and fills a distinct niche in the Houston arts community.

Our Mission

The Classical Theatre Company is dedicated to boldly re-envisioning classical drama on the stage, in the community, and in the classroom through engaging and enlightening plays - bringing them new life and relevance while maintaining the integrity that the works deserve.

The Skinny...

Classical Theatre Company needs some funds to get our ninth season moving. Funds are always harder to come by early in our season, and so this campaign will help us get our first production off the ground, help us to continue renovation on our facility and ensure that our Shakespeare Outreach program will continue to provide high quality programming by bringing Shakespeare out to the underserved schools, community centers, and population of Houston, as well as expand to meet the needs of our new Junior Acting Company.

What We Need:

Some seed money to help us begin funding the first production of the 2016-2017 Mainstage Season - The Bear & The Proposal by Anton Chekhov. This production will cost approximately $30,000, and since only a portion of those costs will be covered by ticket sales, the balance will need to be raised from other sources.

What You Can Do:

Donate, donate, and donate! Additionally if you have any services, materials, or other in-kind donations in lieu of monetary contributions, please contact us at info@classicaltheatre.org

The Impact

Your funds will go directly into our operations costs, both artistic and administrative. They will help provide wages for our artists and technicians as well as purchase costumes and scenery and supplies necessary for our Shakespeare Outreach program. Your generosity is what allows us to continue to bring high-quality and critically-acclaimed classical productions to our young and growing audience on our stage, and help to bring Shakespeare to our constituents out in the community.

story:
What is the story?

We are DUNE dance school from Burgas, Bulgaria. Recently, for a first time, we took part in a dance competition - qualification to the World Dance Masters finals. The competition is organised by ESDU organisation /http://dancestar.org/ There are about 50 countries and 55000 dancers taking part in ESDU qualifications around the world. The final competition called WDM /world dance masters/will take place in Porec, Croatia at the end of May,this year. We are qualified to take part in this competition and present 17 dances in the categories Contemporary dance and Open, juniors. We were also honored with the Choreography prize on the qualification competition in Plovdiv earlier this year. 26 dancers from DUNE, age 11 to 15 are taking part in our dances. In 2015 we also won 15 first prizes, 2 awards for choreography and other prizes from 3 different national and international competitions in Bulgaria.

Here is the school website: www.dunedanceschool.bg 

What is the situation?
We can not effort the full amount of money needed for registration, travel and accommodation for the competition. It is quite a lot of money for a Bulgarian.

Why is so important for us?

This is the first real international competition where we can present our work. This year DUNE dance school turns 30 years. It started as a group of friends who were trying to identify themselves trough dance. We were a gang of a few fine kids, trying to look like our idols from the movies Flash Dance , Heavenly bodies , as well as like Janet Jackson and Paula Abdul. 　 
30 years later we are professional choreographers and dance teachers, living our dream but always fighting with the conditions in our country and city. We have transferred our love to dance in our school. Every dance we make has a history and it is created especially for the people who take part in it. It is always special.

Before starting this campaign we had disagreement in opinion. We argued if we were ready enough to compete on that level. We probably don't have the best technique in the world but we have the will We almost decided not to go because we cannot afford all the expenses. In addition to that some of the dancers have school exams at the time of the competition ........Big disappointment....... And then....we received the best lesson out of this difficult situation, and we got it from our heart. It is not important if you win or not. The only person to compete with is Yourself. If you overcome your fears and give a new meaning to your priorities. If you fight for the right to present yourself and give a 100% of you. Then you are already a winner. The dance is coming from the heart and the character of the dancer. This is the most important lesson to teach our kids - the dancers at our school.


How can you help?
We need money for:
- Competition taxes /around 2500 dollars for all the 17 dances/
- Travel by bus to Croatia /2300 dollars/
In case we not succeed to gather all the money we need, we will decrease the number of dances to present at the competition.
But we'll not give up!

How can you help?We need money for:- Competition taxes /around 2500 dollars for all the 17 dances/- Travel by bus to Croatia /2300 dollars/ In case we not succeed to gather all the money we need, we will decrease the number of dances to present at the competition.But we'll not give up!

story:
A U.S. Marine pilot comes home traumatized from a tour of duty in Iraq, his nightly dreams haunted by the ghost of an insurgent he has killed. In this modern-day tale of sacrifice, conflicted duty, and possible reconciliation, we’ve incorporated music, choreography, and design elements (including an exquisite mask hand-carved by Hideta Kitazawa) drawn from the ancient Japanese performance art of noh. See how we put it all together in Casey Preston's video, "The Making of Zahdi Dates and Poppies."

Carrie Preston’s powerful Zahdi Dates and Poppies explores the emotional cost of war, not just on those who fight, but on their loved ones and society at large. Theatre Nohgaku will perform this beautifully nuanced work, along with an English adaptation of the noh classic Sumida River, on March 30 and 31 at the Tsai Performance Center in Boston. While we do have generous backing from the Boston University Arts Initiative to mount this production, several important elements remain underfunded. We’re asking for your help!

Your contributions will help us to:

-   Hire a technical director and stage manager in Boston

-   Hire a videographer and photographer to document the performance

-  Give adequate compensation to our project director

-  Pay for insurance and travel costs

-  Pay for costume elements

-  Pay for shipping the costumes and set

Theatre Nohgaku has been mounting productions of noh-influenced works for more than 15 years, telling stories that range from Yeats’ At the Hawk’s Well to Deborah Brevoort’s meditation on Elvis, Blue Moon Over Memphis. Our members, many of whom live or have lived in Japan, are firmly grounded in noh performance techniques but have an unquenchable desire to explore new artistic territory. Zahdi Dates and Poppies, directed by Jubilith Moore and scored by David Crandall, is an exciting new collaborative effort that lives in the magic space between tradition and innovation. Please join us there!

story:
Technikz is a Christian based company that will focus on Christian morals and values as well as the use of creativity and imagination. We look to inspire the youth of today, leaders of tomorrow, to be innovators. We strive to show our young innovators that they can bring their own dreams into fruition. We at Technikz strive to create leaders.

Technikz will offer fall, winter, and summer camps along with a dance performance program during the school year for ages 5 yrs to 17yrs. Participants will study ballet, jazz, tap, African, and hip hop dance along with art, tumbling, karate, and creative expressions. We will cultivate the creativity of our participants by practicing individualized expression periods where the participants express any feelings or thoughts through any listed art form of expression. 

The funds that are raised in the next 2 months will be used to buy mirrors for our new dance space, ballet/tap/jazz shoes, new stereo equipment, and tuition coverage for 10 participants.

We would like to say thank you for assisting us in reaching those who would other wise not have the resources to take part in a program such as Technikz due to a lack of financial ability. Your monetary gifts and support is greatly appreciated.

story:
Short Summary

Seattle is on the verge of world domination. Following the exciting and surprising Seahawks Super Bowl victory, Macklemore dominating the Grammys, and impressive social policy measures it's time to ask what can we do as a community to continue this great surge of city pride, community and collaboration. In this spirit, a group of almost 20 theatre companies has joined forces to produce an unprecedented festival. Featuring productions from the largest of companies in town to the smallest, and the words of the most important playwright of the 20th century, we came up with a celebration of Samuel Beckett spanning August through November.

The opportunity for a community that’s already pretty tight knit to come together on a city wide scale and have a conversation about a single writer we all love is a rare opportunity. Beckett gets it...he gets what it is like to be human and struggle through the human condition, and say it to and for the common man. He unites us all in our common angst of what it is like to be human and survive as a human in human society.

We will feature not only the plays (such as Waiting for Godot, Endgame, Krapps Last Tape, Act Without Words parts I & II, etc), but also readings of his poetry and prose, screenings of his films, master classes on Beckett, pop-up performance events, presentations of the radio plays, and much, much more.

Seattle Beckett Festival is a sponsored program of TPS.

The Collaborators on this project include: 

Seattle Shakespeare Company (Waiting for Godot)

West of Lenin (Rockaby, Act Without Words, La Dernière Bande [Krapp's Last Tape performed in French])

Sound Theatre Company

ACT Theatre (hosting Seattle Shakespeare Company, UMO Ensemble, Endangered Species Project)

Northwest Film Forum (Films of Beckett)

UMO Ensemble

Arts on the Waterfront

Book-It Theatre

New Century Theatre Company

Theatre Influence

Seattle University

Cornish College

Endangered Species Project

Sandbox Radio (All That Fall, Words and Music)

Eclectic (Play)

Ghost Light Theatricals (Endgame)

Azeotrope

ReAct

... and more!

What We Need & What You Get

Due to the unparalleled nature of this collaboration, we as a collective of theatre companies are seeking a sum of $20,000 to fund this festival. This money will be used to build the infrastructure around the festival, as we are aiming for a collective presentation of the works, yet within the normal season structure of the companies involved. This includes:

  • Campagin through local magazines, newspapers, radio and television.
  • Creation and upkeep of website.
  • Creation and distribution of maps and punch cards for repeat visitors
  • Possible inclusion of some exciting guests.
  • Generation of awareness of the festival through collateral. 

In return, you, the audience member, will be able to see many different takes on the work of perhaps the only playwright that can bring together as diverse a selection of companies as are listed above.

Samuel Beckett Bio and notable works

Samuel Barclay Beckett (13 April 1906 – 22 December 1989) was an Irish avant-garde novelist, playwright, theatre director, and poet, who l wrote in both English and French. His work offers a bleak, tragicomic outlook on hman nature, often coupled with black comedy and gallows humor. 

He is widely regarded as among the most influential writers of the 20th century and is considered one of the last modernists (though sometimes he is considered one of the first postmodernists.) He is one of the key writers involved with the Theatre of the Absurd.

Beckett was awarded the 1969 Nobel Prize in Literature :for his writing, which - in new forms for the novel and drama - in the destitution of modern man acquires it's elevation."

  • Waiting for Godot (1954)
  • Act Without Words I (1957)
  • Act Without Words II (1957)
  • Endgame (1957)
  • Krapps Last Tape (1958)
  • Happy Days (1961)
  • Play (1963)
  • Rockaby (1981)

*Please note that all awards will be presented to you either at the location of the performance you choose to see, or at a centralized location.

This is a sponsored program of Theatre Puget Sound. Any charge associated with this campaign on your credit card will reflect this.

story:
The Voyage

I'm an emerging playwright looking for support for when I bring my new play Don't Waste Your Bullets on the Dead, to the Vault Festival 2016. 

Vault Festival is London’s biggest arts festival. Last year they sold over 30,000 tickets for the festival, which happens in a network of disused railway tunnels underneath Waterloo station. Its an amazing, atmospheric venue, so its a privilege to be selected, all I need now is to bring all the elements together.  

The Play

Don't Waste Your Bullets on the Dead tells the story of Ellen, a playwright who is wrestling with an unruly plot line both in life and on the page. A direct descendant of passengers that boarded the Mayflower ship bound for the New World in 1620, she knows there's a play in there somewhere she just can't seem to find it. "Write from your heart!" people say "You are your own best material!" But for Ellen, heeding this advice means blurring the boundaries between art and life to devastating effect.

Captain's Log

The first play I wrote, Chicken, was first performed at the Southwark Playhouse and I have since adapted the story for screen. Chicken, the feature film, recently won the Grand Jury Prize at New Hampshire Film Festival after premiering at the Edinburgh International Film Festival 2015. 

In recent years I also wrote and performed Winston on the Run, a one-man show about the young Winston Churchill, which toured to over 30 venues nationwide and played at a handful of UK festivals.

My latest play is a comedy - the first I have ever written - and presenting it at the Vault Festival is not only a great way to see the play produced but also to catch the attention of some important producers and directors in London.

Pounds, shillings, and pence

The funding I am seeking to raise with this campaign will go specifically towards ensuring that the play has an audience whilst it is at the festival and also documenting it to ensure it will have a future life, as well as contribute as much as possible to the careers of the artists involved.   

Thanks to some private investment I am only looking for £600 to cover the following expenses:

  • Targeted marketing ahead of the festival - flyers and PR consultancy 
  • A great trailer to entice an audience and document the production  
  • Photographer to document the production during rehearsals and production 

O brave new world

The journey of Chicken (the first play I ever had performed) from a week's run at an underground fringe venue to an internationally screened, award-winning feature film proves that events like Vault are the breeding ground of our world beating creative industries.  

What you would be contributing to is the future of whole company of brilliant, emerging artists, all of whom have the potential to go on to extraordinary things and who have been brought together to tell a great story. 

High Seas

Although the team at Vault have supported us so much already, for any emerging writer, it's a massive undertaking to bring a piece of new work to a festival.

Thanks to some private investment and the support of Vault Festival I am in a great position, but I need to make sure that I reach the audience I know the show deserves, and honour the future of a great new play.

Thanksgiving

If you aren't able to contribute then that's fine! Instead you can come on board on Facebook, tweet me @freddie_machin or using the hashtag #dontwasteyourbullets, and if you can, come along to the show!

#VaultFestival

February 10 - 14 at 21:30 

Saturday 13th matinee at 16:30

story:
WHY?

The story of these three sisters and the way they are forced to face themselves in the wake of their father's death speaks to how we all seek to reconcile our pasts with our futures.
Times change but families don't. 
Empires rise and fall, races are extinguished, war and peace wage on and on... and the love and dysfunction of family are timeless.
This production is set to take place in a historic library as an homage to Chekov and in an effort to use unconventional space to immerse audiences for a more satisfying encounter. 

WHO?

Cup-A-Jo  Productions seeks to function as a collaboration of Pittsburgh artists working through different mediums to explore the boundaries of theatre, creating a more visceral experience for its audience.
A few of our incredible artists on board:
John Gallagher (Producer) - is one of the most steadfast and versatile figures in the local Pittsburgh film and theater community. He has been a close friend of Joanna Lowe for many years and “The Sisters” is his second collaboration as producer with Cup-A-Jo Productions.


In 2004, John graduated with a Certificate in Film Production from Pittsburgh Filmmakers. Over the past fifteen years, he has produced numerous award-winning and critically acclaimed independent film projects including two features, numerous shorts, a pilot for a sketch comedy television show and a live action web series. His post-apocalyptic short film “2032” won for Best Cinematography in the 2010 Pittsburgh 48 Hour Film Project and his zombie web series “Dead Patrol” starring Joanna Lowe as Lieutenant Ann Brigham won a 2010 Creech Award for Best Production.

 John continues to develop his own film projects and support the work of other independent artists in both film and theater in the local Pittsburgh community.

“I have been a big fan of Joanna for many years and I am very excited to help her make her dream for “The Sisters” come true. It’s going to be an amazing play!”

Art Deconciliis (Director) - has been acting and directing for a number of Pittsburgh theater companies for more than 30 years. He recently completed his 105th acting role at Little Lake Theatre Company, his “home base”, where he has been a part of over 143 productions and serves as a Board member and instructor. A 2007 Pittsburgh Post-Gazette Performer of the Year, Art is also an active voice-over artist in both the US and Canada. He is looking forward to his first project with Cup-A-Jo Productions and excited about working on this contemporary adaptation and the challenge of working in a non-traditional setting.

Maighread Southard-Wray (Cellist) - has been playing Cello in Pittsburgh for the past ten years. She has recently performed at St Andrew's Episcopal church in Highland Park, where she is Head Chorister and is a member of the parish choir. Also a local actor, Maighread just performed in Prime Stage’s The Crucible, as Mary Warren, along with Joanna Lowe.

Maighread is delighted to be working with Cup-A-Jo Productions for the first time, and looks forward to the challenge of pairing cello with a modern adaptation of Chekhov's Three Sisters.
Joanna Lowe (Artistic Director/ Marcia Prior) - founded Cup-A-Jo Productions in 2004 with the idea that she could do anything with the talent and resources around her in Pittsburgh - over the years, it's only proved more and more possible; her greatest hope is to continue making excellent art in and supported by Pittsburgh with Pittsburgh artists. In her lack of spare time, she raises an incredible daughter, is one of the premiere spoken word artists in the city, directs, teaches and writes. 
Gayle Pazerski (Olga Prior) - is honored to have the opportunity to share the humanity of The Sisters with so many gifted artists. Having performed in The Three Sisters as a college student, she is eager to revisit the story with 15 extra years of (wonderful, terrible, hilarious, tragic) life to her credit. 
Jenny Malarkey (Irene Prior) - "As well as an actor, I am also a teacher. I teach in a unique program called Creative Dramatics through The Pittsburgh Public Theatre. This program focuses on pairing a city school with a suburban school, and brings together two completely different groups of students- racially, economically, socially, etc... We first meet with each school individually as we play games and do activities that help build confidence, creativity, teamwork, etc... Then both schools are brought together, and through the art of storytelling, they discover they are able to overcome their differences and find they might not actually be that different at all. At the end of our time with them, the students put on an abridged version of a Shakespeare play, and get to perform it for their friends and family in the bigO'Reilly theatre. This program continually shows me why the arts are such a vital part of our schools. It reminds us to think, and feel, and open our arms to those seemingly different than us. Even as we get older, I find these skills are just as important. So, I greatly look forward to getting the chance to work with old friends and new as we begin this crazy adventure together."
Stanley Graham (Andrew Prior) - A Pittsburgh native born in Carrick studied theatre first at CCAC South Campus for two years before his acceptance into COPA at Point Park University. A recent graduate of the program with his B.F.A in Musical Theatre, Stanley was able to have plenty of performance opportunities at the university and throughout the Pittsburgh area. Stanley is so exited to be working with this company on a modern telling of the great Chekov Classic.
Jessie Goodman (Nancy Pecket) - was raised in Pittsburgh and has been going to plays, concerts, and other local cultural events since she was a little girl. Inspired to cultivate the art of live performance and encourage audiences to reflect on the human experience, Jessie received her BFA in Acting from Shenandoah Conservatory in Virginia. She is interested in promoting the multifaceted woman in her work, specifically when it comes to breaking gender roles and looks stereotypes. After going to New York for a stint, Jessie is thankful to be back in the secure city of Pittsburgh. She is now pursuing her Master’s in social work at the University of Pittsburgh in order to help people on and off the stage more effectively. As a member of Pittsburgh Playback Theatre, Jessie is excited to open up dialogues within the community on difficult issues and allow people to watch their stories come to life on the spot. Jessie plans to bring more gripping, challenging plays to Pittsburgh and will find a way to get them out to diverse groups of people. 
Everett Lowe (Gary Sokol) - Everett believes in the transformative power of the arts—they’re still changing him for the better. A collaborator at heart, Everett thrives—both as an actor and director—wherever passionate artists come together under a united vision. He’s always looking for a new challenge. Everett absolutely loves Pittsburgh and the diverse community making this city what it is.
Jason Spider Matthews (Vincent Antonelli) - is an actor, director, and teacher originally from Washington DC, trained here in Pittsburgh at Point Park University, and then went to NYC to spread his wings.  Now back in the Burgh' he is happy to be a part of this production.
Samantha A. Camp (Nurse/Paramedic) - Samantha’s recent credits include: Mrs. Frank in The Diary of Anne Frank, Julie in A Delicate Balance, Clytemnestra in Agamemnon and Amanda Wingfield in The Glass Menagerie. Those roles all were super line-heavy - not allowing Samantha to indulge in one of her absolute favorite activities: backstage knitting. She would like to thank Joanna and Art for giving her the opportunity to get the last few hundred rows of that blasted sweater done. She was twice named Best Actress in a Drama (once a tie) by the Tacoma News-Tribune (for Artie in Eleemosynary and Tamora in Titus Andronicus). Samantha recently moved back to Pittsburgh after 12 years on the Other Coast. The Sisters is her 145th show as an actress (and counting). Check out www.samanthacamp.net or become her fan on Facebook. Thanks, as always, to The Bruce for pomegranates.
Michael Petyak (Fight Choreographer) - Petyak's stage credits include work at the "Dickens of a Christmas" at the Crosley Theatre in Sarasota, Florida, Pennsylvania Renaissance Faire, Great Plains Theatre (Abilene, KS), Between Us Productions (NYC), Bob Junior in Who’s Bob Friendly? at the Pittsburgh Fringe Festival, and just directed Sweet Tea and Cadillacs for the Pittsburgh New Works Festival. When he is not doing stage, Michael is a professional stunt man/actor that recently worked on the new series “Outsiders” in Pittsburgh where he doubled Joe Anderson, and also Calum Worthy in the upcoming feature film, Repicate. He received his BFA in Music Theatre, Magna Cum Laude from Shenandoah University in 2012. He is a proud member of SAG-AFTRA.

WHAT WE NEED

A SPACE: 
"A man walks across an empty space whilst someone else is watching him, and this is all that is needed for an act of theatre to be engaged." - Peter Brooks
Cup-A-Jo Productions has performed in all manner of spaces, traditional and non, whether chosen for the production or whether we've had to make a challenging space work to fulfill our goal. This time, we've chosen the location specifically to enhance the play and the audience experience.
The Sisters, set in an ivy league university, will be mounted in the Carnegie Free Library in Carnegie, a beautiful historic landmark; our production will take place specifically in the Lincoln Gallery, surrounded by rare Lincoln photographs. It calls to mind a classic era appropriate to Chekhov as well as implying the educational atmosphere of the play itself. 
The majority of the money raised will be used to finance access to our unique space, because as Peter Brooks has said, that is really all that we need.
PAY:
Being an artist is hard. We do what we do for the love of it. Love, however, rarely if ever pays the bills and we'd love to show our collaboration of artists that they are worth more than their efforts by giving them something tangible as appreciation. We need your help to do that. 
ENVIRONS:
Eloquence is the final touch. First, we get a space. Next, we support our artists. Then, we add the flourish. The final touch to make your experience unforgettable, to make your senses tingle, your heart pound, your mind spin. As we said, this is a production with live music, wine, and fists. Aren't you curious?

HOW YOU'RE HELPING

You are supporting Pittsburgh artists. You are saying "yes" to experimental art. You are aiding in presenting challenging ideas and explorations. You are encouraging a theatre company that strives to execute unique and excellent work. You are helping Pittsburgh continue to be a city that fosters and thrives on art. We need you. 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

We understand as artists (sometimes the starving variety) that money doesn't grow on trees and sometimes it's all one can do to afford a full tank of gas. Trust us, we've all been there. Even so, there's a lot you can do to help us:
* share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, e-mail, snail mail, telepathy and smoke signal. You get the idea. Help us spread the word.
* attend our fundraiser at Hambones on December 18th from 7-9pm where you'll get to see our cast and crew entertain you and each other. Proceeds also benefit Toys for Tots because we recognize that there are always people in greater need.
* come and see the show. It's going to be amazing. We want to share it with you.

Empires rise and fall, races are extinguished, war and peace wage on and on... and the love and dysfunction of family are timeless.
This production is set to take place in a historic library as an homage to Chekov and in an effort to use unconventional space to immerse audiences for a more satisfying encounter. 
WHO?
Cup-A-Jo  Productions seeks to function as a collaboration of Pittsburgh artists working through different mediums to explore the boundaries of theatre, creating a more visceral experience for its audience.
A few of our incredible artists on board:

John Gallagher (Producer) - is one of the most steadfast and versatile figures in the local Pittsburgh
film and theater community. He has been a close friend of Joanna Lowe for many
years and “The Sisters” is his second collaboration as producer with Cup-A-Jo
Productions.

In
2004, John graduated with a Certificate in Film Production from Pittsburgh
Filmmakers. Over the past fifteen years, he has produced numerous award-winning
and critically acclaimed independent film projects including two features,
numerous shorts, a pilot for a sketch comedy television show and a live action
web series. His post-apocalyptic short film “2032” won for Best Cinematography
in the 2010 Pittsburgh 48 Hour Film Project and his zombie web series “Dead
Patrol” starring Joanna Lowe as Lieutenant Ann Brigham won a 2010 Creech Award
for Best Production.
 John continues to develop his own film projects and support the work of other
independent artists in both film and theater in the local Pittsburgh community.

“I
have been a big fan of Joanna for many years and I am very excited to help her
make her dream for “The Sisters” come true. It’s going to be an amazing play!”
Art Deconciliis (Director) - has been acting and directing for a number of Pittsburgh theater companies for more than 30 years. He recently completed his 105th acting role at Little Lake Theatre Company, his “home base”, where he has been a part of over 143 productions and serves as a Board member and instructor. A 2007 Pittsburgh Post-Gazette Performer of the Year, Art is also an active voice-over artist in both the US and Canada. He is looking forward to his first project with Cup-A-Jo Productions and excited about working on this contemporary adaptation and the challenge of working in a non-traditional setting.

Maighread Southard-Wray (Cellist) - has been playing Cello in Pittsburgh for the past ten years. She has recently performed at St Andrew's Episcopal church in Highland Park, where she is Head Chorister and is a member of the parish choir. Also a local actor, Maighread just performed in Prime Stage’s The Crucible, as Mary Warren, along with Joanna Lowe.
Maighread is delighted to be working with Cup-A-Jo Productions for the first time, and looks forward to the challenge of pairing cello with a modern adaptation of Chekhov's Three Sisters.


Joanna Lowe (Artistic Director/ Marcia Prior) - founded Cup-A-Jo Productions in 2004 with the idea that she could do anything with the talent and resources around her in Pittsburgh - over the years, it's only proved more and more possible; her greatest hope is to continue making excellent art in and supported by Pittsburgh with Pittsburgh artists. In her lack of spare time, she raises an incredible daughter, is one of the premiere spoken word artists in the city, directs, teaches and writes. 

Gayle Pazerski (Olga Prior) - is honored to have the opportunity to share the humanity of The Sisters with so many gifted artists. Having performed in The Three Sisters as a college student, she is eager to revisit the story with 15 extra years of (wonderful, terrible, hilarious, tragic) life to her credit. 

Jenny Malarkey (Irene Prior) - "As well as an actor, I am also a teacher. I teach in a unique program called Creative Dramatics through The Pittsburgh Public Theatre. This program focuses on pairing a city school with a suburban school, and brings together two completely different groups of students- racially, economically, socially, etc... We first meet with each school individually as we play games and do activities that help build confidence, creativity, teamwork, etc... Then both schools are brought together, and through the art of storytelling, they discover they are able to overcome their differences and find they might not actually be that different at all. At the end of our time with them, the students put on an abridged version of a Shakespeare play, and get to perform it for their friends and family in the bigO'Reilly theatre. This program continually shows me why the arts are such a vital part of our schools. It reminds us to think, and feel, and open our arms to those seemingly different than us. Even as we get older, I find these skills are just as important. So, I greatly look forward to getting the chance to work with old friends and new as we begin this crazy adventure together."

Stanley Graham (Andrew Prior) - A Pittsburgh native born in Carrick studied theatre first at CCAC South Campus for two years before his acceptance into COPA at Point Park University. A recent graduate of the program with his B.F.A in Musical Theatre, Stanley was able to have plenty of performance opportunities at the university and throughout the Pittsburgh area. Stanley is so exited to be working with this company on a modern telling of the great Chekov Classic.


Jessie Goodman (Nancy Pecket) - was
raised in Pittsburgh and has been going to plays, concerts, and other local
cultural events since she was a little girl. Inspired to cultivate the art of
live performance and encourage audiences to reflect on the human experience,
Jessie received her BFA in Acting from Shenandoah Conservatory in Virginia. She
is interested in promoting the multifaceted woman in her work, specifically
when it comes to breaking gender roles and looks stereotypes. After going to
New York for a stint, Jessie is thankful to be back in the secure city of
Pittsburgh. She is now pursuing her Master’s in social work at the University
of Pittsburgh in order to help people on and off the stage more effectively. As
a member of Pittsburgh Playback Theatre, Jessie is excited to open up dialogues
within the community on difficult issues and allow people to watch their
stories come to life on the spot. Jessie plans to bring more gripping,
challenging plays to Pittsburgh and will find a way to get them out to diverse
groups of people. 

Everett Lowe (Gary Sokol) - Everett believes in the transformative power of the arts—they’re still changing him for the better. A collaborator at heart, Everett thrives—both as an actor and director—wherever passionate artists come together under a united vision. He’s always looking for a new challenge. Everett absolutely loves Pittsburgh and the diverse community making this city what it is.

Jason Spider Matthews (Vincent Antonelli) - is an actor, director, and teacher originally from Washington DC, trained here in Pittsburgh at Point Park University, and then went to NYC to spread his wings.  Now back in the Burgh' he is happy to be a part of this production.

Samantha A. Camp (Nurse/Paramedic) - Samantha’s recent credits include: Mrs. Frank in The Diary of Anne Frank, Julie in A Delicate Balance, Clytemnestra in Agamemnon and Amanda Wingfield in The Glass Menagerie. Those roles all were super line-heavy - not allowing Samantha to indulge in one of her absolute favorite activities: backstage knitting. She would like to thank Joanna and Art for giving her the opportunity to get the last few hundred rows of that blasted sweater done. She was twice named Best Actress in a Drama (once a tie) by the Tacoma News-Tribune (for Artie in Eleemosynary and Tamora in Titus Andronicus). Samantha recently moved back to Pittsburgh after 12 years on the Other Coast. The Sisters is her 145th show as an actress (and counting). Check out www.samanthacamp.net or become her fan on Facebook. Thanks, as always, to The Bruce for pomegranates.

Michael Petyak (Fight Choreographer) - Petyak's stage credits include work at the "Dickens of a Christmas" at the Crosley Theatre in Sarasota, Florida, Pennsylvania Renaissance Faire, Great Plains Theatre (Abilene, KS), Between Us Productions (NYC), Bob Junior in Who’s Bob Friendly? at the Pittsburgh Fringe Festival, and just directed Sweet Tea and Cadillacs for the Pittsburgh New Works Festival. When he is not doing stage, Michael is a professional stunt man/actor that recently worked on the new series “Outsiders” in Pittsburgh where he doubled Joe Anderson, and also Calum Worthy in the upcoming feature film, Repicate. He received his BFA in Music Theatre, Magna Cum Laude from Shenandoah University in 2012. He is a proud member of SAG-AFTRA.

WHAT WE NEED
A SPACE: 
"A man walks across an empty space whilst someone else is watching him, and this is all that is needed for an act of theatre to be engaged." - Peter Brooks

Cup-A-Jo Productions has performed in all manner of spaces, traditional and non, whether chosen for the production or whether we've had to make a challenging space work to fulfill our goal. This time, we've chosen the location specifically to enhance the play and the audience experience.

The Sisters, set in an ivy league university, will be mounted in the Carnegie Free Library in Carnegie, a beautiful historic landmark; our production will take place specifically in the Lincoln Gallery, surrounded by rare Lincoln photographs. It calls to mind a classic era appropriate to Chekhov as well as implying the educational atmosphere of the play itself. 
The majority of the money raised will be used to finance access to our unique space, because as Peter Brooks has said, that is really all that we need.

PAY:

Being an artist is hard. We do what we do for the love of it. Love, however, rarely if ever pays the bills and we'd love to show our collaboration of artists that they are worth more than their efforts by giving them something tangible as appreciation. We need your help to do that. 

ENVIRONS:
Eloquence is the final touch. First, we get a space. Next, we support our artists. Then, we add the flourish. The final touch to make your experience unforgettable, to make your senses tingle, your heart pound, your mind spin. As we said, this is a production with live music, wine, and fists. Aren't you curious?
HOW YOU'RE HELPING
You are supporting Pittsburgh artists. You are saying "yes" to experimental art. You are aiding in presenting challenging ideas and explorations. You are encouraging a theatre company that strives to execute unique and excellent work. You are helping Pittsburgh continue to be a city that fosters and thrives on art. We need you. 
OTHER WAYS TO HELP
We understand as artists (sometimes the starving variety) that money doesn't grow on trees and sometimes it's all one can do to afford a full tank of gas. Trust us, we've all been there. Even so, there's a lot you can do to help us:
* share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, e-mail, snail mail, telepathy and smoke signal. You get the idea. Help us spread the word.
* attend our fundraiser at Hambones on December 18th from 7-9pm where you'll get to see our cast and crew entertain you and each other. Proceeds also benefit Toys for Tots because we recognize that there are always people in greater need.
* come and see the show. It's going to be amazing. We want to share it with you.

story:
#InchByInchThePlay

What would you do if your mother died and left you the one thing she knew you hated the most? 

Bridget (Rachel Graf Evans) and Tom (Theo McKenna) return to Bridget's hometown for her mother's funeral. Bridget learns that she has inherited the house and the vegetable garden and must reconcile her own deep-seated fears about family and identity before the Garden will let her leave. 

Premiering this September at Theater for the New City's Dream Up! Festival, Inch by Inch is a poignant new play which explores love, grief, and what it means to leave a legacy. 

What We Need

  • $1500 will be going toward the festival fee, rehearsal space rental, IndieGoGo's cut, and marketing materials.
  • $1500 will be going towards stipends for our creative team and crew. Compensation for the artists we work with is important to us! 
  • $1000 will be going to our design budget (set, props, costumes, lights, plants, construction, load-in, etc.).

The Team

Rachel Graf Evans (Playwright | BRIDGET) is a feminist writer and theater artist from Westtown, Pennsylvania. She graduated from Oberlin College with High Honors in Gender, Sexuality, and Feminist Studies & Theater for her research and writing of “Vessel,” a new musical exploring the relationship between infertility and female gender identity, as supported by a chorus of Greek Goddesses. Since moving to NYC, RGE has produced two original plays (“Ravishing Medusa” at Theater for the New City’s Dream Up! Festival 2014; “Stranger Odds: A Queer Little Rom Com” at Fresh Fruit Festival 2013); sung in a myriad of cabarets (Hot Pepper Theater at 54Below; The Rigano Songbook; Don’t Tell Mama hosted by Seth Bisen-Hersh; Cranky Cabaret); and props designed all over the place (New Georges, LCT3, PowerOutNYC, Dreamcatcher). RGE studies playwriting with Arlene Hutton at The Barrow Group and composition with Ralph Affoumado. She is the founder/curator of the new theater laboratory Mots de Changer (Words of Change) and sings Bass with the Sirens of Gotham, the women’s barbershop chorus of Manhattan. She is a proud member of the Dramatists Guild. In her spare time, RGE is a cat mom, reproductive justice advocate, Quaker, and very tall. www.rachelgrafevans.com

Amanda Kate Joshi (Director) is a New York based director and producer. Regional Credits: Frank Loesser's “Guys and Dolls” (Assistant to Don Stephenson at Goodspeed Opera House); Harnick and Bock's “Fiddler on the Roof” (SDC Observer to Marcia Milgrom Dodge at the Maltz Jupiter Theatre); Noel Coward’s “Tonight at 8:30”(starring Blythe Danner), Sir Peter Shaffer’s “Equus”and “Gift of the Gorgon” (both starring Alec Baldwin) (all Associate to Tony Walton at Guild Hall, East Hampton).  Off and Off-Bway Credits: Stephen Sondheim’s “Evening Primrose” (Associate to Tony Walton at the John Jay Theatre); Oscar Wilde’s “Importance of Being Earnest”(14th Street Y); Michelle Markowitz’s “Hookups & Hang-ups” (Abingdon Theatre Company); Sarah Hammond’s “Green Girl”(Assoc. to Wendy McClellen) (The Public Theatre); Jay Hanagan’s “Softly Sara Falls” (Lookinglass Theatre); Craig McNulty’s “Welcome Home Steve” (Players Club). Festival Credits: “24-Hour Broadway Musicals”(AD), Abingdon's “Benefit Challenge Series”, Wizard Oil Productions' “Lights Up!”. She sat on the LARK Play Development Center’s Literary Wing for two years and is a reader for the Princess Grace Award in Playwriting. She was awarded an SDC Observership in 2014, and was nominated for both a National Directors Fellowship in 2015 and an SDC Mike Ockrent Directing Fellowship in 2010. She is a member of SDC and Actors' Equity.

A proud native of Chicago, Illinois, Lindsey Mandolini (Choreographer) is a professional dancer, choreographer, performance artist, and dance educator living in Brooklyn, New York. Lindsey began her formal training at the Ruth Page Foundation School of Dance, under the direction of Larry Long and Dolores Lipinski, and graduated from the University of the North Carolina School of the Arts (UNSCA) High School Program, with a concentration in Contemporary Dance. Lindsey went on to New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts where she graduated with high honors receiving a BFA in Dance and a minor in Art History. While studying at NYU, she performed in original works by Deborah Jowitt, James Martin, Sydney Skybetter, and Kate Weare. Since graduation, Lindsey has worked for New York-based choreographers including: Pilar Castro Kiltz (Ensemble Dance), Hee Ra Yoo (Yoo & Dancers), Regina Nejman (Regina Nejman & Company), Jody Oberfelder (Jody Oberfelder Projects) and most recently Erin Carlisle Norton as a company member of The Moving Architects. As a choreographer, she has presented her work at Symphony Space, Triskelion Arts, Dixon Place, and the Center for Performance Research; in addition to choreographing for music videos and live bands. Lindsey currently dances for Ximena Garnica and Shige Moriya, as a member of LEIMAY for their 2015-2016 performance season, and remains a faculty 
member at Mark Morris Dance Center for their Children & Teen program.


Theo McKenna (TOM) Recent credits include The Tempest, Romeo and Juliet, Caucasian Chalk Circle (Azdak, dir. John Gould Rubin), Love's Labour's Lost (Navarre, dir. May Adrales), and Loose Knit (Miles, dir. Lee Sunday Evans). BFA: NYU, Stella Adler and RADA. 

What You Get in the Giving Garden

Art is undeniably collaborative. Join us in this gardening space! 

We want to give you a wonderful new play; can you help us grow it? In addition to the theatrical fruit of our artistic labors, we want to reward you for your generosity! We have a Variety of Tomato Donation Levels to choose from in our Garden of Giving!

About Theater for the New City and the Dream Up! Festival

Theater for the New City (TNC) is a venue for new artists and playwrights under the Artistic Direction of Crystal Field. TNC is unique in its commitment to both high artistic standards and community service. As the cultural hub of its downtown New York City location, TNC develops new artists and inspires future audiences.

The Dream Up! Festival presents new works by various artists, and is an incredible opportunity for emerging artists to produce new work. Now in its sixth year, Dream Up! will be premiering 26 new shows between two locations, including drama, musicals, dance, aerial, improv, and more. 

Other Ways You Can Help!

If you're based near NYC (or not!), Come See The Show! Some of our donor perks include tickets, so consider reserving your seat that way or see the ticket link below.

Performances:

9/13 @ 2:00 pm
9/14 @ 6:30 pm
9/15 @ 9:00 pm
9/16 @ 6:30 pm
9/17 @ 9:00 pm
9/19 @ 5:00 pm

The Crown Theater
at The Producer's Club, 358 W 44th St (& 9th Ave), NYC

Purchase Tickets Here:
http://www.smarttix.com/show.aspx?showcode=inc01C

Like Our Facebook Page for updates, cast and crew candids, new play parties, and more: www.facebook.com/InchByInchThePlay

Regardless of if you can or can't donate money, please share this campaign wildly like a garden growing weeded and freely on every cyber platform you have (Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, LiveJournal, Vine, SnapChat, YouTube). 

Wherever you go, make sure to include our tag #InchByInchThePlay

story:
The Story, as told by our playwright

My name is Esti, and I’m an actress in New York City. Like many other actors in the city, I live a double life as a server. On one of the many long subway commutes from Inwood to my work in FiDi, I decided it was time to create my own work. I wanted to tell my story, and the story of the commuters I saw everyday on the 1 train, and so TRACKS was born.

TRACKS is set in a subway car - in your subway car - and tells your story, and the stories of riders around you. In a world of physical theatre, we follow a divorced couple on the way to their son’s graduation, and meet the strangers that come on and off the train. It’s all an ordinary day on a busy commute, especially when the conductor announces “Due to an incident at 42nd street, we are experiencing delays”… Or is it?

What We Need 

TRACKS will go up as a fully staged preview performance run at the Davenport Theatre, in the heart of New York's Theater District, October 29 - November 1st. We’re getting together an entire team - producers, a director, a stage manager, a cast of 9 actors, designers, a publicist - the list goes on - and we need your help! 

Your contribution will help fund: 

  • stipends for our talented team 
  • rehearsal space rentals 
  • props and costumes 
  • a publicist who will help kick us up a notch 
  • essentially, all things large and small which help us put on a show, and make some theatre magic happen.

Why get involved?

By supporting TRACKS, you’ll be supporting independent innovative theatrical ventures that want to diversify what’s available to the viewer, challenge established norms, push boundaries, ask difficult questions, and produce work that is relevant and represents our community and time. 

On behalf of my entire team, I’m inviting you to donate and be a part of something new, exciting, and profound.

See you in the theatre!

Esti MacInnes

Actress, Playwright
