story:
Who are we?

We are Part of the Main Productions, a predominantly female theatre company made up of young creatives, theatre-lovers, and students from around the world. Primarily based in London, we are excited to be working on this new play by Mia McCullough. Looking at socially-prescient issues surrounding reproductive rights and abortion, the play is new to the London theatre scene; we are proud to be staging its world premiere from 16 May to 18 May at The Space, a small community theatre in London. Please help us do justice to the play and the issues it raises by contributing to our crowdfunding campaign, and by coming along to the show!

What Are We Doing?

Infestation, Part One of The Squirrel Plays centres around a young couple, Tom and Sarah, who are definitely not “squirrel people”. On moving into a suburban home, they are alarmed to find that the house has an unwelcome critter in the attic. Now they must decide what to do: to exterminate or not exterminate? In this dark comedy, the unwanted squirrel in the house becomes a metaphor for the real issue dividing the couple: having children.

Part of the Main Productions believes in promoting gender equality in theatre; Infestation, with a cast of predominantly female actors, and several women in technical roles backstage, is the company's first production (and - with your help - an indicator of the company's direction in the future). The play is directed by Jessica Bickel-Barlow and produced by Olivia Munk, with Lily Taylor and Ciaran Chillingworth as assistant producers. More information on the cast and crew will be coming soon!

The playwright, Mia McCullough, is a Chicago-based writer and comedian whose works have been featured at theatres around the United States, in Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Diego. The Squirrel Plays have received staged readings around the US, most recently at Chicago Dramatists. Part of the Main Productions will bring Infestation to London for the first time, and we are excited to do so at a time when discussions about reproductive rights and abortion are perhaps more important than ever before.

What Do We Need?

We would like your help to fund the production of the play and the technicalities that make it a reality: from set design and props, to lighting and marketing, your pledges will make a huge impact on the show and the team behind it. All the cast and crew members are unpaid and working on an amateur capacity, and are contributing personal funds to the project. With a firm foundation in theatre, our team members having worked in amateur and student theatre in cities such as London, New York, Oxford, and Cambridge. We have the passion and the experience to stage a memorable production that will raise interesting questions and leave audiences wanting more. With a small amount of extra funding, we can make the show even better.

Our aim is to build a network of collaborators and creatives so that we can go on to stage more important plays such as this one, starting with Parts Two and Three of The Squirrel Plays, two fascinating sequels which will further complicate the issues raised in the first play. We would love for you to be a part of this collaboration, and to offer whatever financial help you are able to give.

Perks

We are so grateful to all those who are interested in our production. Though we cannot offer physical perks, we will enthusiastically acknowledge all those who pledge £10 and above on our social media outlets; pledge £20 and above, and get the title of associate producer; pledge £50 and above and get a free ticket to the show on a night of your choice.

Praise for the Playwright

“McCullough has a strong gift for the apt metaphor, as well as the operatically grotesque/comic visual....Ultimately, McCullough's intelligent, probing and compassionate play leaves us with a disquieting sense that humans have commodified the business of death for millennia” (Review for Chagrin Falls, Chicago Tribune)

“McCullough’s dialogue is straightforward but often contains vivid depictions of tenderness and terror that occur offstage to great effect” (Review for Since Africa, Theater Pizzazz)

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone can afford to donate, but you can still help if you like the sound of our project. Please follow our progress here and on social media, share our posts or a link to this page, and tell anyone you think might be interested! Thank you.
story_txt: Who are we?We are Part of the Main Productions, a predominantly female theatre company made up of young creatives, theatre-lovers, and students from around the world. Primarily based in London, we are excited to be working on this new play by Mia McCullough. Looking at socially-prescient issues surrounding reproductive rights and abortion, the play is new to the London theatre scene; we are proud to be staging its world premiere from 16 May to 18 May at The Space, a small community theatre in London. Please help us do justice to the play and the issues it raises by contributing to our crowdfunding campaign, and by coming along to the show!What Are We Doing?Infestation, Part One of The Squirrel Plays centres around a young couple, Tom and Sarah, who are definitely not “squirrel people”. On moving into a suburban home, they are alarmed to find that the house has an unwelcome critter in the attic. Now they must decide what to do: to exterminate or not exterminate? In this dark comedy, the unwanted squirrel in the house becomes a metaphor for the real issue dividing the couple: having children.Part of the Main Productions believes in promoting gender equality in theatre; Infestation, with a cast of predominantly female actors, and several women in technical roles backstage, is the company's first production (and - with your help - an indicator of the company's direction in the future). The play is directed by Jessica Bickel-Barlow and produced by Olivia Munk, with Lily Taylor and Ciaran Chillingworth as assistant producers. More information on the cast and crew will be coming soon!The playwright, Mia McCullough, is a Chicago-based writer and comedian whose works have been featured at theatres around the United States, in Chicago, Los Angeles, and San Diego. The Squirrel Plays have received staged readings around the US, most recently at Chicago Dramatists. Part of the Main Productions will bring Infestation to London for the first time, and we are excited to do so at a time when discussions about reproductive rights and abortion are perhaps more important than ever before.What Do We Need?We would like your help to fund the production of the play and the technicalities that make it a reality: from set design and props, to lighting and marketing, your pledges will make a huge impact on the show and the team behind it. All the cast and crew members are unpaid and working on an amateur capacity, and are contributing personal funds to the project. With a firm foundation in theatre, our team members having worked in amateur and student theatre in cities such as London, New York, Oxford, and Cambridge. We have the passion and the experience to stage a memorable production that will raise interesting questions and leave audiences wanting more. With a small amount of extra funding, we can make the show even better.Our aim is to build a network of collaborators and creatives so that we can go on to stage more important plays such as this one, starting with Parts Two and Three of The Squirrel Plays, two fascinating sequels which will further complicate the issues raised in the first play. We would love for you to be a part of this collaboration, and to offer whatever financial help you are able to give.PerksWe are so grateful to all those who are interested in our production. Though we cannot offer physical perks, we will enthusiastically acknowledge all those who pledge £10 and above on our social media outlets; pledge £20 and above, and get the title of associate producer; pledge £50 and above and get a free ticket to the show on a night of your choice.Praise for the Playwright“McCullough has a strong gift for the apt metaphor, as well as the operatically grotesque/comic visual....Ultimately, McCullough's intelligent, probing and compassionate play leaves us with a disquieting sense that humans have commodified the business of death for millennia” (Review for Chagrin Falls, Chicago Tribune)“McCullough’s dialogue is straightforward but often contains vivid depictions of tenderness and terror that occur offstage to great effect” (Review for Since Africa, Theater Pizzazz)Other Ways You Can HelpWe understand that not everyone can afford to donate, but you can still help if you like the sound of our project. Please follow our progress here and on social media, share our posts or a link to this page, and tell anyone you think might be interested! Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

Welcome to our campaign, and thank you for taking a look. We are Nicky Coelho, Deanna Gooding, and Eve Schulte, all dance artists currently based in Minneapolis, Minnesota. We are presenting an evening of new and renewed dance works, to include:

  • ​A new duet featuring Deanna and Brian Evans, with live strings accompaniment by Jack Rice.
  • Another new duet by Deanna, featuring Nicky Coelho dancing and husband Altamir Coelho playing a new composition, live, on bass guitar.
  • A new solo work choreographed and danced by Eve.
  • A re-staging of Eve's work Any Offered None, which premiered last February in JSB's Ballet Works Project and was nominated for a 2016 MN Sage Award for Outstanding Performance. Featuring dancers Deanna Gooding, Nicky Coelho, Shohei Iwahama, Jordan Lefton, and Sam Feipel.

Lighting design and direction will be by Twin Cities renowned Mike Grogan.

What We Need

Our goal of $5250 will be divided as such:

  • Artist compensation. Any amount reached beyond our goal will be given directly to the artists. We hope to unlock a stretch goal or two!
  • Space rental, for both rehearsals and performances.
  • Printing costs for advertising, Indiegogo perk photos, and show programs.
  • Fees associated with ticketing and Indiegogo.

What You Get

Now to the fun stuff! ALL BACKERS will receive credit in our show program, in addition to the following options:

  • $1+ - copious amounts of GRATITUDE to all who give, and credit in our show program
  • $20+ -  Shout out on Facebook
  • $30 - Thirty second improv, performed to a song of your choice, delivered via Vimeo link
  • $50 - 4x6 Bill Cameron print (see options below)
  • $75 - Thirty second improv AND 4x6 print
  • $100 - Two tickets AND 8x10 print
  • $150 - Two tickets, 8x10 print AND three blank cards with designs by Deanna
  • $200 - Conditioning class with Nicky, 8x10 print, and two tickets
  • $200 - Private ballet lesson with Eve, 8x10 print, and two tickets
  • $300 - Painted pet portrait by Deanna
  • $300 - Invitation to open rehearsal 
  • $400 - Improv jam with Deanna Gooding and two of your friends, plus 2 tickets
  • $500 - Ballerina. Birthday. Party.
  • $1000 - a mostly firm, slightly limp handshake from Sam Feipel
  • $1500 - pick two of the above perks
  • $2000 - pick three of the above perks

Dang, ain't that a good-looking perk list?! Let's break down some of those options.

Thirty second improv: you choose the song, we get our groove on! We will deliver a private Vimeo link with 1-3 dancers doing their thing to the song you request.

Tickets: We will reserve the best seats for the evening of your choosing (Friday April 14th or Saturday April 15th). Tickets will be held at will call under your name at the Cowles Center box office.

Photography by Bill Cameron: multiple options and levels of giving covered here. Beloved Twin Cities-based photographer Bill Cameron is partnering with us to provide stunning images for your viewing pleasure! You pick your image from the below options:

A - Nicky guitar

B - Nicky shadow

C - Eve

D - Dee & Brian

E - Dee & Jordan

Conditioning class with Nicky: One hour conditioning class for you and one friend. Class can be tailored to fit whatever you would like to work on; a home workout regimen, strengthening, stretching, how to release muscles with a foam roller and tennis ball, or just a great workout session!

Private ballet lesson with Eve: Treat yourself, or give as a gift! Eve will lead a 1.5 hour-long private ballet class for up to three participants. To be scheduled between the months of May and August 2017. Located at the Cowles Center or other Twin Cities area studio.

Painted pet portrait: Ohh! Haven't you always wanted a painting of your cute cuddly companion hanging in your bedroom? Deanna will paint a portrait of your pet.

Invitation to open rehearsal: See us in action, in preparation for this special evening of dance.

Improv jam: A time to sweat, smile and get your groove on with up to twelve wonderful people of your choosing. A dance jam to great music in a big space led by Deanna.

Ballerina Birthday Party: An hour and a half of two professional dancers making someone's birthday unforgettable! One 45-minute ballet lesson, pointe shoe demo along with an autographed pair of pointe shoes for the birthday girl or boy, 5-minute performance by the professional dancers, and finishing with crafts!

A mostly firm, slightly limp handshake from Sam Feipel: That's right folks. There is a limited quantity of these available, so act now. Will you be one of the lucky few to experience the full glory of this perk?

The Impact

Your contribution helps in the following ways:

  • Supports an evening of engaging, physical, investigative expression that will touch every single audience member. Dance is an ephemeral, 3-D form, and the emotional arc and in-the-moment magic is not easily captured on video. We have high ambitions for this evening. To piggy-back on that, Any Offered None has already proven itself to be a piece of emotional force. Eve and the dancers still (a year after it's debut) hear feedback from people who were transported, who had cathartic experiences, who deeply hope to see it again.
  • Provides financial compensation to artists in a time when arts funding and education is arguably not at it's most vibrant.

Who We Are

Deanna Gooding has been in the Twin Cities for two and a half years and enjoys spending time being creative. She started dancing at Londonderry Dance Academy in New Hampshire. After high school Deanna studied at the San Francisco Conservatory of Dance under the direction of Summer Lee Rhatigan. She currently dances for James Sewell Ballet.

Eve Schulte is a dance performer and instructor based in Minneapolis, MN. She grew up at Minnesota Dance Theatre, is in her eighth season with the James Sewell Ballet, and is a frequent collaborator with Live Action Set. More info at eveschulte.com!

Nicky Coelho grew up in Charlottesville, VA and began dancing at the age of five. She studied with the Virginia School of the Arts, Dance Theater of Lynchburg, Maryland Youth Ballet, and Joffrey Ballet’s summer intensive in New York for five years. She has been dancing professionally on and off since 2003 and has danced for James Sewell Ballet for the past six years.

Brian J. Evans is a Professional Performing Human. Evans places high value in process and product, having had most of his training out in the 'Arts field' of the Twin Cities, working with over 50 artistic directors on more than 200 projects from solo endeavors to collaborating as a self-employed professional performer & teaching artist. Brian J. Evans is a recipient of a 2015 McKnight Dance Fellowship, administrated by The Cowles Center and funded by The McKnight Foundation. Primarily as a principle dancer, musical director & teaching artist for Stuart Pimsler Dance & Theater, Evans has continued to investigate the idea that connections exist between us all and it's the responsibility of the Arts to rediscover those connections, highlight them to allow us to feel holistically human.

Sam Feipel is in his fourteenth season at the Minnesota Dance Theatre. He was a recipient of the 2009 McKnight Fellowship for Dancers.

Shohei Iwahama began dancing in Tokyo under the tutelage of Miyako Kato in 2002. He has been dancing in Minneapolis where he performs with James Sewell Ballet since 2014. Shohei was named one of Houston Press’ 100 Creatives for 2013 and is a recipient of a 2015 SAGE Award for Outstanding Dancer Performer.

Jordan Lefton is a native of West Palm Beach where he started dancing at the age of five. He attended Alexander W. Dreyfoos School of the Arts and Graduated from The Juilliard School in 2015. Jordan has been dancing professionally for two years with James Sewell Ballet.

Altamir Coelho is originally from Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and was hired in 2009 as studio manager at Giant Leap Studios in Bloomington, MN. He has toured in over 150 cities in four different countries, has recorded electric bass on over one hundred CD-tracks, and has collaborated on several albums. Altamir is the founder and music director of Viva Brazil, a Brazilian jazz, funk, samba, and fusion band in the twin cities which held a two year run of monthly appearances at The Dakota Jazz Club - Downtown Minneapolis, MN.

Jack Rice resides in Colorado Springs and attends UCCS majoring in computer science. He received his high school diploma from North Carolina School of the Arts, learning from Joseph Pecoraro, and also studied at SF Conservatory of Music with Sergio Assad.

Mike Grogan has been active in the Twin Cities arts scene since 1990. In that time he has designed for numerous dance companies including James Sewell Ballet, Ballet of the Dolls, Contempo Physical Dance and Joe Chvala and the Flying Foot Forum. Mike was a 2012 and 2014 SAGE Dance Award recipient for outstanding design. Mike is currently a Freelance Lighting Designer in the Twin Cities area.

Risks & Challenges

This is the first show we three directors have independently run, but we share a wealth of knowledge regarding performance and administration, and we have a group full of experts in the field working with us.

We already have the performance space and dates secured, and have contracts with the artists.

Other Ways You Can Help

Perhaps you just can't contribute here, but want to be involved:

  • Spread the word! Post/send/share the heck out of this campaign.
  • Be an audience member! Ticket sales will go live once we've completed the Indiegogo campaign.

Thank you for your consideration.

story:
EXPERIMENT IN THREE PARTS

Experiment In Three Parts is an ongoing work in progress blending, exploring, and blurring the boundaries between music and how we move to it. Choreographed and directed by Rebecca Green, this work looks to the dancers as active intellectual participants and to the audience as active contributors.  We aim for quality, risk, relevance, specificity and relate-ability in this work.

 

Where Does Your Money Go?


$2500 - Payment for 4 dancers and 1 sound collaborator 
$2500 - Studio rental fees for Approx. 3 - 4 months of rehearsal.

Any money raised beyond our goal will go to documentation for the performance, staging, lighting, and costuming for the performers! 

​
 

The Impact

 

Your contribution not only helps us create this work, but also contributes to the art community.  By donating you make a statement that art is a valuable part of society and you send a message of optimism and potential to other up incoming artists who want to make and present work!  You say: opportunity does exist if you make it happen.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Every donation of any size helps us reach our goal, but just as important as donations is getting the word out about this campaign!  Please share this with your friends over Facebook, instagram, email and any other social media platform.  The more people we can reach, the better our chance of making this work a reality. 

 

About The Artist

 

Rebecca is a choreographer and performer who began her formal training in Seattle, Washington At Cornish College of the Arts. She studied with movement artists such as Michele Miller, Wade Madsen and performed in Alia Swersky’s site specific work Beneath Our Own Immensity.  Rebecca then began her training at California Institute of the Arts in 2012.   Along with several stage works, she also devised, directed and choreographed two large-scale multimedia dance productions which she received an Interdisciplinary Arts Grant to create. Her work has been presented at Redcat, Pieter space, and Highways Performance Space along with dance for camera works presented internationally. 

 

For more info about Rebecca Green click here:

http://rebeccagreenmoves.wixsite.com/rebeccagreen/about

story:
What is "The Yellow Wallpaper" Summary

“He asked me all sorts of questions, pretending to be very loving and kind.”

The Yellow Wallpaper was first developed last year in a one-night-only run at Dixon Place on their MainStage. We are now remounting the piece in 2019 with a new perspective. Andrew Watkins' adaptation is a multimedia staging of Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s searing indictment of the 19th century medical community. This new adaptation and multimedia staging provides an intimate look at a deteriorating mental state and how the world of medicine has and continually doubts women.

The cast will be led by Sam Morales* (Miranda in The Public Mobile Unit’s Tempest) and will also star Jacob Fishel* (Fiddler on the Roof and TFANA’s King Lear) and Lindsey Sagrera. The script will be adapted and directed by Andrew Watkins (Network, Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune). The production will feature sets by Vincent Gunn; costumes by Christopher Metzger; lighting by Dallas Estes; video by Cinthia Chen; original music and sound design by Sam Kaseta and stage managed by Katherine Bolynn*.

We are raising money for the IRT 3B Development series incarnation of this piece. Performances will run October 4th-13th (specific times and dates below). The producers are passionately contributing time, skills and resources to this project out of passion for the concept. However, they need your help compensating the brilliant artists involved.

We are functioning as an equity showcase. Your contributions will help you support talented artists in a grassroots theatre laboratory to produce a new and important incarnation of a historical piece of feminist literature. 

The Team

Director/Adaptor: Andrew Watkins - www.andrewwatkinstheatre.com

Producers: Becky Abramowitz and Andrew Watkins

Associate Director: Anna Michael - www.annacmichael.com

Scenic Design: Vincent Gunn - www.vincentgunn.com

Costume Design: Christopher Metzger - www.christophermetzgerdesign.com 

Lighting Design: Dallas Estes - www.dallasestes.com

Original Music and Sound Design: Sam Kaseta - www.samkaseta.com 

Video Design: Cinthia Chen - www.cinthiachen.com

Performers: Sam Morales*, Jacob Fishel*, Lindsey Segrera

Stage Manager: Kathryn Bolynn*

*Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association 

What We Need 

Personnel in theatre are rarely compensated appropriately for their work. We are trying our best to compensate our artists. While we cannot put a price on their work, our budget is broken down by what we estimate that we can afford with your help. This includes our administrative team (Stage Manager), Technical Artists (Lighting, Video, Sound, Set, Costumes), skilled hands for load-in and load-out, board operators, etc. And not to mention, our very talented cast! 

Other Expenses include the space rental for rehearsal, art and production materials (Lighting, Video, Sound, Set, Costumes) and marketing and promotion (graphic design and digital media) 

The Impact

We set out to find a project that would represent depression in a truthful and impactful way. We found that most explorations within similar plays were about the loved ones of a person suffering from depression, and not about the experience itself. Either that, or they were a depiction of violence and fear. The Yellow Wallpaper is a truthful expression of the suffering of mental illness.

This project had a successful developmental show at Dixon Place. We are returning with the project's original director, assistant director, producing team and lead actor. 

Risks & Challenges

The immersive video is a huge endeavor for this group, as the technology involved in creating a multimedia piece is very expensive and temperamental. We have taken great care between our first staging of this piece and now to come up with a solution and develop a plan to realize our goals within our budget. However, even with our careful planning, we need your support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, you can still help:

Share our instagram @yellowwallpapernyc

Share the Indiegogo on facebook/twitter/etc.

Buy tickets to the show! 

Thank you so much for your help and support!
story_txt:
What is "The Yellow Wallpaper" Summary
“He asked me all sorts of questions, pretending to be very loving and kind.”
The Yellow Wallpaper was first developed last year in a one-night-only run at Dixon Place on their MainStage. We are now remounting the piece in 2019 with a new perspective. Andrew Watkins' adaptation is a multimedia staging of Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s searing indictment of the 19th century medical community. This new adaptation and multimedia staging provides an intimate look at a deteriorating mental state and how the world of medicine has and continually doubts women.
The cast will be led by Sam Morales* (Miranda in The Public Mobile Unit’s Tempest) and will also star Jacob Fishel* (Fiddler on the Roof and TFANA’s King Lear) and Lindsey Sagrera. The script will be adapted and directed by Andrew Watkins (Network, Frankie and Johnny in the Claire de Lune). The production will feature sets by Vincent Gunn; costumes by Christopher Metzger; lighting by Dallas Estes; video by Cinthia Chen; original music and sound design by Sam Kaseta and stage managed by Katherine Bolynn*.
We are raising money for the IRT 3B Development series incarnation of this piece. Performances will run October 4th-13th (specific times and dates below). The producers are passionately contributing time, skills and resources to this project out of passion for the concept. However, they need your help compensating the brilliant artists involved.
We are functioning as an equity showcase. Your contributions will help you support talented artists in a grassroots theatre laboratory to produce a new and important incarnation of a historical piece of feminist literature. 
The Team
Director/Adaptor: Andrew Watkins - www.andrewwatkinstheatre.com
Producers: Becky Abramowitz and Andrew Watkins
Associate Director: Anna Michael - www.annacmichael.com
Scenic Design: Vincent Gunn - www.vincentgunn.com
Costume Design: Christopher Metzger - www.christophermetzgerdesign.com 
Lighting Design: Dallas Estes - www.dallasestes.com
Original Music and Sound Design: Sam Kaseta - www.samkaseta.com 
Video Design: Cinthia Chen - www.cinthiachen.com
Performers: Sam Morales*, Jacob Fishel*, Lindsey Segrera
Stage Manager: Kathryn Bolynn*
*Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association 
What We Need 
Personnel in theatre are rarely compensated appropriately for their work. We are trying our best to compensate our artists. While we cannot put a price on their work, our budget is broken down by what we estimate that we can afford with your help. This includes our administrative team (Stage Manager), Technical Artists (Lighting, Video, Sound, Set, Costumes), skilled hands for load-in and load-out, board operators, etc. And not to mention, our very talented cast! 
Other Expenses include the space rental for rehearsal, art and production materials (Lighting, Video, Sound, Set, Costumes) and marketing and promotion (graphic design and digital media) 
The Impact
We set out to find a project that would represent depression in a truthful and impactful way. We found that most explorations within similar plays were about the loved ones of a person suffering from depression, and not about the experience itself. Either that, or they were a depiction of violence and fear. The Yellow Wallpaper is a truthful expression of the suffering of mental illness.
This project had a successful developmental show at Dixon Place. We are returning with the project's original director, assistant director, producing team and lead actor. 
Risks & Challenges
The immersive video is a huge endeavor for this group, as the technology involved in creating a multimedia piece is very expensive and temperamental. We have taken great care between our first staging of this piece and now to come up with a solution and develop a plan to realize our goals within our budget. However, even with our careful planning, we need your support.
Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can't contribute, you can still help:
Share our instagram @yellowwallpapernyc
Share the Indiegogo on facebook/twitter/etc.
Buy tickets to the show! 
Thank you so much for your help and support!

story:
Hey There!

My name's John. I'm a theatre artist and drag performer living in NYC. This April, I'm launching a new Queer variety show titled The Pansy Parlor. Premiering at The Triad Theater in New York City, it's an intimate evening of Drag, Burlesque, Comedy and more...produced by and for Queer Artists!

The Pansy Parlor isn't really a drag show, nor is it burlesque. It's not strictly comedy either! What it is, is a platform for Queer, Trans, AFAB and Non-Conforming performers of all disciplines to express themselves. Hosted by drag queens Caia Campbell and Zenadia Mars, it's a positively peculiar evening broadcast live from the Queer imagination. 

Unlike traditional Queer nightlife, The Pansy Parlor is a true variety show, giving equal time for all artists. Sometimes drag queens get all the love. It's not fair, but it's true. At The Pansy Parlor, we're featuring drag queens, kings, burlesque performers, comedians, puppeteers, musicians and more! All performers are valid and deserve to be celebrated! Our goal is to foster creative risk taking, community, and appreciation for these art forms...art forms that have been around for 100s of years.

The Pansy What? 

The show takes inspiration from "The Pansy Craze" of the 1930s, but what does that mean?
I'm glad you asked!

Let’s imagine. It’s 1930 and Prohibition's in full swing. People and cultures are mixing like never before, in search of a good time. These changing times meant, for the first time, Queer culture was seen and celebrated on a widespread scale!

LGBTQ artists and entertainers found unheard of commercial success. Entertainers such as Rae Bourbon, Gladys Bentley, and Karyl Norman performed to sold out audiences across the US. Yet, as quickly as this Queer subculture rose to prominence, it was ushered underground at the end of the 1930s.

Why Now? 

Today we express ourselves much more freely. Yet, outside of television, Queer performance art is still relatively underground. 

Amazing artists perform in venues without stages, dressing rooms, or even proper lighting...right here in New York City. Frankly, this lack of production value is disheartening! We've created The Pansy Parlor to honor the rich history of these art forms and provide an immersive theatrical experience that artists and audiences deserve. 

What We Need

Independent artists and producers in NYC face many challenges. Production, creation, and performance are investments of time, energy, and funds. We need contributors like you to ensure The Pansy Parlor is a success! Here's where that money goes: 

  • Paying Artists
  • Production Staff
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Marketing
  • Printed Materials
  • Insurance and Operational Expenses

Any funds raised above and beyond $2,000 will go toward future iterations of The Pansy Parlor, as well as increased stipends for artists.

What You Get

We'd be BEYOND grateful for your support. Some support levels come with added bonuses, like a signed copy of the program, an official poster, or even a Plant Your Own Pansy flower kit. Take a look!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute, we understand! It's 2020 and the rent is just too darn high...BUT, that doesn't mean you can't support us in other ways!

    • Support us by SHARING this campaign, let's get the word out and meet our goal!
      • ​Send to your friends, colleagues, heck...even your enemies!
    • BUY A TICKET! Come see The Pansy Parlor on April 4th, 2020 at The Triad Theater. 
      • For Tickets: https://bit.ly/30RIumy
    • Follow us on Social Media to keep up-to-date with our progress!
      • Caia Campbell's instagram: (@CaiaCampbell)
      • The Pansy Parlor instagram: (@ThePansyParlor)
      • The Pansy Parlor Facebook: (www.facebook.com/ThePansyParlor)

Caia Campbell's instagram: (@CaiaCampbell)
The Pansy Parlor instagram: (@ThePansyParlor)
The Pansy Parlor Facebook: (www.facebook.com/ThePansyParlor)

story:
Introduce yourself in your background

My name is Carolyn Arnold and I have been creating performances, theater, music and art since I was a small child, and through my youth and in college I danced, acted, sang and played musical instruments. I got my BA in dance and theater from the Evergreen State College in Olympia Washington in 2007. During college and the year after college I was the producer and choreographer of my own dance company. In 2012, I moved to the East Bay area of California where I have been since, writing songs and performing with my solo song writing project, producing house concerts, and being an active part of the East Bay Contact Improvisation dance community.

In the summer of 2017, I started my own small business teaching people how to sing. I got back into theater in the summer of 2019, began performing drag in the fall of 2019, and in the winter of 2020 performed the role of Laura in the Glass Menagerie with the Ross Valley Players in Marin County. During Covid this past year, I decided to go for it and make my performing dreams come alive and applied to MFA in acting programs.

 

My Vision:

Now more than ever we need artists in the world who are committed to helping our human and environmental situations which are in dire straits. The role of the artist in society is to hold up a mirror and show people who live in that society the inhuman and harsh behaviors that are the "norm" so are not able to be seen. This mirror provides a necessary perspective that is vital for the survival of the human spirit, and the survival of humans on this planet.

If one theater artist is funded, her work in the world will have a ripple effect by nature of the work itself; the work of the theater artist is by its nature in community, so she will naturally inspire and uplift those around her if she herself is uplifted and supported.

 

Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you:

My campaign involves raising money to help me pay for graduate school. I will be attending the Pig Iron School which is the creation of the Pig Iron Theater Company, and affiliated with the University of the Arts in Philadelphia, to get an MFA in devised performance.

I am raising this money so that I can spend all of my time and energy focused on the MFA program and my learning, and so that I don’t have to spread myself thin by having to work a job in addition to being in school 9 to 5 every day. This will help me be to able to be more successful as an artist when I leave school and go out into the world of creating life and world changing theater performances.  

Being able to focus 100% on this MFA program without needing to take out as much loan money to pay for school would make a huge difference in my peace of mind and also in my effectiveness as a graduate student in theater. The theater arts are already a challenging field in which to embark on a new career, so I figured that having additional financial support would help me realize my goals of bringing meaningful, fun, and world changing theater into existence in my post graduate career.

 

What I need and what you get:

My goal is to raise a minimum of $8,400 and a maximum of $26,400. The $8,400 minimum would cover the additional cost of living expenses for the year not covered by loans (which is about $1,500/mo), as well paying for the interest on my loans which is $179/mo. The maximum of $26,400 would cover the total cost of living expenses so that I don't have to use any loan money to live on, and I will have $12,000 less in debt to pay off after I graduate, as well as cover the payment of interest ($179/mo).


Risks and challenges:

This is perhaps the most risky and yet the most important step I have made yet in my life. I am willing to completely embody the role of a theater artist and trust that stepping into it will make me feel fully alive and will open doorways, allowing me to grow personally, as an artist, and as a member of a society that needs deep healing.

As you may be well aware, choosing a path of an artist, especially a theater artist, is probably one of the most financially risky decisions a person can make. This is not a lucrative art form, and everyone who goes into this field knows that they are stepping into a extremely competitive world. This requires audacity, drive, motivation, and a deep love and passion for one’s art.

I am qualified for these risks and challenges because I have been making a living as a musician and a performer for many years. Most recently, I ran my own business as a vocal instructor, and was a successful business owner connecting people to their bodies, their creativity, and their voices. Even during the pandemic on zoom!

My plan for solving the challenges of becoming a post graduate theater artist, is to do the thing I have always done in order to survive and thrive in my art: to continue to connect with people and form meaningful and lasting relationships that are based upon trust and mutual respect. After many years of figuring out how to make a living as an artist, I know that building lasting, trusting relationships is the core and the key to a successful and meaningful career.


Otherwise you can help:

If you can’t contribute money, you can help me in other ways! You can tell your friends and family about my campaign, and you can also become an audience member of my work. Artists and performers of all kinds need faithful audience members who care about their work. This is just as important as a financial contribution.

story:
PWR Presents: Bioslam

Party World Rasslin' is Austin, Texas's biggest and most ballistic wrestling party. Comedy, action, and superb beer create a Triforce of power that we can all enjoy together! If you were at our last show, you saw a cybernetic gameshow host destroyed by a magical puppet. Chants of "He's  real boy!" filled our throats, echoing deep and overwhelming truth. Justice prevailed, and the journey of MOTHER WORM intensified! Woah, what?! What am I even talking about?! This is Party Violence...this is PARTY WORLD RASSLIN'!

SUMMER SLAMDOWN VI: BIOSLAM

Summer is the time for partying. That's for sure. And we want to throw the most insane and unhinged party Austin has ever seen!  The date is June 15th, the place is 4th Tap Brewing Co-op! Our 21st show in 5 years will lay bare the trve heart of summer. We thought... what could be the best place we could go to honor the spirit of summer? Summer is the time of liquids, friends and life-changing trips. So what unlikely place would we go next? How about INSIDE THE HUMAN BODY! Or better yet, how about inside the BODY OF A GIANT SNAKE?! That sounds good. We'll be fully transforming 4th Tap Brewing Co-Op into a biological paradise full of colorful organs, branching tubes, and throbbing walkways! There, in the HEART of the giant snake, MOTHER WORM, we'll battle in a massive ring made of bone and tendons! This ring will be illuminated with a full professional lighting system, and broadcast on 3 screens and beyond with a sweet 3-camera video setup!

It wasn't always like this, though. Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—this thing has become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In 5 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring to the glorious spectacle we know today.  We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs. 


THE STORY SO FAR

PWR's CHAMPIONSHIP MANTLE has fallen upon a tiny, felt-covered boy. A Jim Henson-esque little guy who rides on the arm of his uncle: PUGGIN'HEAD! Passive observers would call him a puppet, but we call him a REAL BOY and PWR'S PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPION!

Puggin'head has defeated challenge after challenge. From besting the horned warlord of the  Necro-realm, to redeeming Randy Eagleman, to besting a cyborg at his own sick gameshow, Puggy has proven himself to be one of PWR's GREATEST CHAMPIONS OF ALL TIME!

Meanwhile, our precious deity, Teen Worm, has grown into a monstrous creature: MOTHER WORM! She's been eating everything she can find, and allowing her food to have insane parties in her organ systems!

But something's caught in her craw...

A man with worldly ambitions is attempting to take over Mother Worm from within! BIG DADDY BOLERO has torn through the competition, developing property wherever he sets foot to turn EVERYTHING into a Dallas-esque hell-scape!! His machinations are making Mother Worm sick, and we've got to stop him! This falls on the shoulders of the PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPION, and only WE can give him the SCREAM-FUEL he needs to defeat this challenge and help Mother Worm grow! Can the Multiverse resist the charge of a bad man's unrestrained, cynical ambition?!

The answer will be revealed! Expect to see some BRAND NEW body-oriented competitors, as well as the usual PARTY ATHLETES: Dan "the Man" Ziglar, Luigi Primo, Bull DeCroix,  The Dumpster Babes, Alexandra Cage, Sweetie Tuff, Crybaby, Dock Master, Pastaman, Bench Horse, Ralph Machiatto, Sprida , Arbitro Obscuro, Hot Dog, and MORE!

What is this money used for?

$6000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?

First, an important recitation: PWR's quarterly Austin shows are free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.

PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on one of the largest free events in Texas. Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spend north of $10,000 on each of our shows.

We diligently budget and carefully save so that we can ask for an amount that is sustainable. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; our rigorous planning -- combined with your support -- have allowed us to do this without our costs ballooning to a hellish degree! It's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than five years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHT

Some of the cool things your donations will help us do include:

  • Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a living Greek ruin at our last show! This time, we're recreating the systems of the human and inhuman body, and making them big enough to walk inside! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.

  • Air Conditioning. The huge space we have the ring in isn't air conditioned, so we build our own cooling system for the summer shows! We rent swamp coolers and hoist them onto huge risers that we built. This, combined with about $700 worth of fans we've collected over the years and a clever air-pathing layout keep the ring area comfortable in the Summer!

  • Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.

  • Safer space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.

  • Projection and lighting. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We always have tweaks to make to reach towards our goal of TV-quality lighting. If you saw our lights at the last show, you know how shockingly powerful our latest generation is! Also, our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options! Plus, we now STREAM our shows over twitch, and your support helps us improve the quality of it

  • Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  

  • Profit split: after we cover all our costs, we take 20% of our profits and reinvest it in PWR. We split up whatever is left among performers and staff who worked on the show.

For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.

Show Expenses: $3058.00:

Art Supplies: $500.00

Equipment Rental and Accessories (AC units, Video/Sound, Generators, etc): $1150.00

Construction Supplies: $100.0

Insurance: $467.58

Performer Assistance Fund: $150.00

Ring Maintenance: $50.00

Office Supplies: $60.00

Props/Costume: $100.00

Security Expenses: $60.00

Transportation: $350.00

Service Subscriptions: $70

Operational Expenses: $4035:

Artist and Staff Pay: $3635

New Projects Capital: $400.00

Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $2846.00
Indiegogo and credit card fees: $583.00

 

Extremely Hype Swag

As usual, we've got awesome merch rewards you can get if you contribute to the Indiegogo. This includes a brand new design by Nat Bradford!  Available in both Tee and Tank, and BLACK and SUMMER TIME PINK!



For true maniacs, we've got a BANDANA by Zeke Guadiana! Here's the draft version:

But check out this MEDALLION you can get, designed and manufactured with vinyl by Tracy Hunt and Justin Meise! Gain the power...


And check ye this ENAMEL PIN:



Or maybe you want something to put on the wall, maybe you want a POSTER! Here's one, by Rory Blank!


With all the PWR patches and pins we've done over the years, I know what you're thinking. You're thinking, "I need a back piece to tie it all together." Good news! Nat Bradford has screenprinted this image on huge sheets of fabric!

Risks and Challenges

As PWR continues its evolution from backyard party to professional art-collective, we never want to lose the heart of partying and stupidness that makes it good. We aim to balance a relentless work ethic with a light touch and and inviting environment for our attendants, volunteers and staff. It's hard wrangling 80 people to put on a huge free show, but knowing others will join us to reap the rewards makes it worth it one million times. Rest assured we're working tirelessly to have the time of our lives on June 15th! 


Other Ways You Can Help


If you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and BASH OF THE TITANS!


Here is the Facebook event page:https://www.facebook.com/events/428932364318774/
 

HMW
story_txt:
PWR Presents: BioslamParty World Rasslin' is Austin, Texas's biggest and most ballistic wrestling party. Comedy, action, and superb beer create a Triforce of power that we can all enjoy together! If you were at our last show, you saw a cybernetic gameshow host destroyed by a magical puppet. Chants of "He's  real boy!" filled our throats, echoing deep and overwhelming truth. Justice prevailed, and the journey of MOTHER WORM intensified! Woah, what?! What am I even talking about?! This is Party Violence...this is PARTY WORLD RASSLIN'!SUMMER SLAMDOWN VI: BIOSLAMSummer is the time for partying. That's for sure. And we want to throw the most insane and unhinged party Austin has ever seen!  The date is June 15th, the place is 4th Tap Brewing Co-op! Our 21st show in 5 years will lay bare the trve heart of summer. We thought... what could be the best place we could go to honor the spirit of summer? Summer is the time of liquids, friends and life-changing trips. So what unlikely place would we go next? How about INSIDE THE HUMAN BODY! Or better yet, how about inside the BODY OF A GIANT SNAKE?! That sounds good. We'll be fully transforming 4th Tap Brewing Co-Op into a biological paradise full of colorful organs, branching tubes, and throbbing walkways! There, in the HEART of the giant snake, MOTHER WORM, we'll battle in a massive ring made of bone and tendons! This ring will be illuminated with a full professional lighting system, and broadcast on 3 screens and beyond with a sweet 3-camera video setup!It wasn't always like this, though. Thanks to you—the MULTIVERSE—this thing has become something far beyond what we ever could have imagined. In 5 years we've gone from a handful of people watching a home-made ring to the glorious spectacle we know today.  We continue to do a DIY show that is all-ages and free to the public, even as costs increase. Your continued support allows our core ethos to flourish. It means so much to us. The show remains FREE TO ATTEND, even as we mount mammoth costs. THE STORY SO FARPWR's CHAMPIONSHIP MANTLE has fallen upon a tiny, felt-covered boy. A Jim Henson-esque little guy who rides on the arm of his uncle: PUGGIN'HEAD! Passive observers would call him a puppet, but we call him a REAL BOY and PWR'S PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPION!Puggin'head has defeated challenge after challenge. From besting the horned warlord of the  Necro-realm, to redeeming Randy Eagleman, to besting a cyborg at his own sick gameshow, Puggy has proven himself to be one of PWR's GREATEST CHAMPIONS OF ALL TIME!Meanwhile, our precious deity, Teen Worm, has grown into a monstrous creature: MOTHER WORM! She's been eating everything she can find, and allowing her food to have insane parties in her organ systems!But something's caught in her craw...A man with worldly ambitions is attempting to take over Mother Worm from within! BIG DADDY BOLERO has torn through the competition, developing property wherever he sets foot to turn EVERYTHING into a Dallas-esque hell-scape!! His machinations are making Mother Worm sick, and we've got to stop him! This falls on the shoulders of the PARTYWEIGHT CHAMPION, and only WE can give him the SCREAM-FUEL he needs to defeat this challenge and help Mother Worm grow! Can the Multiverse resist the charge of a bad man's unrestrained, cynical ambition?!The answer will be revealed! Expect to see some BRAND NEW body-oriented competitors, as well as the usual PARTY ATHLETES: Dan "the Man" Ziglar, Luigi Primo, Bull DeCroix,  The Dumpster Babes, Alexandra Cage, Sweetie Tuff, Crybaby, Dock Master, Pastaman, Bench Horse, Ralph Machiatto, Sprida , Arbitro Obscuro, Hot Dog, and MORE!What is this money used for?$6000 is a lot of money! What’s it going toward?First, an important recitation: PWR's quarterly Austin shows are free. PWR is for everyone, even if they can't afford to pay cover at a show. We'd like to keep from having to charge admission for as long as we can.PWR is also now a 80-person organization putting on one of the largest free events in Texas. Increased expectations beget increased (and wholly worthwhile) costs: we spend north of $10,000 on each of our shows.We diligently budget and carefully save so that we can ask for an amount that is sustainable. We are continuously able to improve the show and make it grander; our rigorous planning -- combined with your support -- have allowed us to do this without our costs ballooning to a hellish degree! It's all on the backs of our beautiful volunteers who submit themselves to the Multiverse out of love. We've survived more than five years as we've grown into the massive wrestling party you know today—and we're not slowing down! Accept no impostors! HELL RIGHTSome of the cool things your donations will help us do include:
Art and design. We have an extremely talented team of designers who transform the venue into an art piece by using garbage. 4th Tap was turned into a living Greek ruin at our last show! This time, we're recreating the systems of the human and inhuman body, and making them big enough to walk inside! Though most of our resources are scavenged from trash bins and thrift stores, filling a venue of our size with cool decorations—and the storage to keep them preserved show after show!—costs money.
Air Conditioning. The huge space we have the ring in isn't air conditioned, so we build our own cooling system for the summer shows! We rent swamp coolers and hoist them onto huge risers that we built. This, combined with about $700 worth of fans we've collected over the years and a clever air-pathing layout keep the ring area comfortable in the Summer!
Paying artists. We work hard to make sure everyone who contributes to our production gets some money in exchange—whether our art team, our powerful tech wizards, or our A/V crew.
Safer space/security: PWR is a party for everyone. Our performers have always followed anti-sexist/homophobic/transphobic/racist guidelines, and we wanted to make sure that comfort extends to our audience. We’re proud of our security phone line. Any member of the audience may use this number to report gross behavior at the show, and we resolve the problem. Your support lets us keep reaching toward a goal of ULTIMATE PARTY VIOLENCE for everyone.
Projection and lighting. PWR has some of the most advanced lighting for an independent wrestling show in the country! And we built it ourselves, with your help. We always have tweaks to make to reach towards our goal of TV-quality lighting. If you saw our lights at the last show, you know how shockingly powerful our latest generation is! Also, our projection system allows people to watch the show from 3 different places in the venue, each with different sitting and standing options! Plus, we now STREAM our shows over twitch, and your support helps us improve the quality of it
Training: Party Violence is its own unique sport. We have crafted a training program that makes use of experienced pro-wrestling coaching to help keep our PARTY ATHLETES smooth n' safe.  
Profit split: after we cover all our costs, we take 20% of our profits and reinvest it in PWR. We split up whatever is left among performers and staff who worked on the show.
For transparency: this Indiegogo doesn’t cover all of adolescent PWR’s expenses, but it takes care of a majority of them. Below is our complete budget.Show Expenses: $3058.00:Art Supplies: $500.00Equipment Rental and Accessories (AC units, Video/Sound, Generators, etc): $1150.00Construction Supplies: $100.0Insurance: $467.58Performer Assistance Fund: $150.00Ring Maintenance: $50.00Office Supplies: $60.00Props/Costume: $100.00Security Expenses: $60.00Transportation: $350.00Service Subscriptions: $70Operational Expenses: $4035:Artist and Staff Pay: $3635New Projects Capital: $400.00Indiegogo Reward production and fulfillment: $2846.00Indiegogo and credit card fees: $583.00 
Extremely Hype SwagAs usual, we've got awesome merch rewards you can get if you contribute to the Indiegogo. This includes a brand new design by Nat Bradford!  Available in both Tee and Tank, and BLACK and SUMMER TIME PINK!For true maniacs, we've got a BANDANA by Zeke Guadiana! Here's the draft version:But check out this MEDALLION you can get, designed and manufactured with vinyl by Tracy Hunt and Justin Meise! Gain the power...And check ye this ENAMEL PIN:Or maybe you want something to put on the wall, maybe you want a POSTER! Here's one, by Rory Blank!With all the PWR patches and pins we've done over the years, I know what you're thinking. You're thinking, "I need a back piece to tie it all together." Good news! Nat Bradford has screenprinted this image on huge sheets of fabric!Risks and Challenges
As PWR continues its evolution from backyard party to professional art-collective, we never want to lose the heart of partying and stupidness that makes it good. We aim to balance a relentless work ethic with a light touch and and inviting environment for our attendants, volunteers and staff. It's hard wrangling 80 people to put on a huge free show, but knowing others will join us to reap the rewards makes it worth it one million times. Rest assured we're working tirelessly to have the time of our lives on June 15th! 
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you don't want to donate money you can help us by getting the word out about this campaign and/or just word out about PWR and BASH OF THE TITANS!Here is the Facebook event page:https://www.facebook.com/events/428932364318774/ HMW

story:
Short Summary

We are The Snortwhores: an alternative physical comedy collaboration based in Portland, OR, USA. Over the last two years we have been working together to dream up our project, Disaster Fantasy: an original airplane thriller in drag. The idea started with Emily experiencing recurring nightmares, and Jeff wanting to create a show based off of them, incorporating his newly discovered drag persona. The project was successfully approved for funding from the Regional Arts and Culture Council, and also an artist residency at Lookout Arts Quarry in Bellingham, WA. Like any successful theatre production, we are looking for producers! This will allow us to flesh out our World Premiere in our hometown, and further develop the show to bring to theatre festivals around the world. 

Who We Are

Emily Newton has performed as original comedic characters all over the world. She has hosted events, toured two solo shows, and performed for Terrapin Puppet Theatre, Oregon Children’s Theatre, and Dell’Arte International. Reviewers have called her performances “comedic gold”, “a standout clown”, “complete and beautiful nonsense” and “a solo show that’s actually good”.

Jeff Desautels is a founding member of the comedic trio, Box of Clowns. He has toured to festivals all over North America, appeared on America’s Got Talent and The Gong Show, and has performed with Tears of Joy, CoHo Theatre, and is the Emcee of Sir Cupcake’s Queer Circus. His work has been praised as “infectiously joyful” and “A+ physical comedy”.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $1,000! $1,000 is the cost of our venue. $1,000 is also approximately the cost of hiring our director, lighting designer, and board operators. $1,000 also happens to be about the cost of everything else in this show: our props, costumes, makeup, printing, etc.

Our grant and ticket sales will cover most of it, but we need your help for the rest! 

Oh...you want to know what goodies you will get. I see. Well, here they are:

CARGO- $5

  •  For only 500 pennies, you will get an e-mail with a hand-selected stock photo, and a personalized message from The Snortwhores! 

COACH - $20

  • Donate $20 and get a bespoke sick bag! No, really. This lil' baggie will be illustrated with the Disaster Fantasy logo and filled with fun surprises! (Nice ones, we promise. All fantasies, no disasters.)

BUSINESS CLASS - $50

  • $50 will get you a goodie bag, as well as your own flight pin so you can join our crew. Cyndi and Charlie will also answer all your questions via a video call from their next vacation spot!

FIRST CLASS - $100

  • You get a goodie bag, a flight pin, and Cyndi and Charlie will choreograph and perform to a song of your choice- just for you! 

PILOT - $250

  • Wow! Thanks for flying the plane! You get everything listed above, as well as VIP tickets to our show. If you are too busy jetsetting to travel to PDX, you will receive a video of the performance with a special care package!

story:
New Wave Theater Collective

New Wave Theater Collective was founded in April of 2016 by Sarah Wolff and Jenny Hickman. We believe that theater has the power to spark the discussion to create broader change. New Wave carefully selects timely, contemporary pieces that reflect this belief, and empowers emerging young artists by giving them a platform to produce their work.

NWTC has produced four MainStage productions, including What We're Up Against by Theresa Rebeck, Constellations by Nick Payne, Bull by Mike Bartlett and The New Sincerity by Alena Smith. 

New Wave New Works

A year ago New Wave Theater Collective launched its New Wave New Works series. Once a month we meet and listen to a staged reading of a piece by one of our featured playwrights. The series has given writers the opportunity to hear their works-in-progress read out loud by actors in a supportive environment, at no cost to the playwright. 

Why produce new work?

Mounting productions of new pieces is becoming increasingly challenging, as the cost of performances space and rehearsal studios in New York City is astronomical. Thus, the majority of the shows that have been produced on a large scale within the past few years have been more commercial. Producers tend to feel more comfortable monetarily backing an adaptation of a popular film, or backing a revival of a well-known play. In order for theater to evolve, new work must continue to be brought to the table. New Wave Theater Collective empowers the artists who are creating new pieces for new audiences. 

This upcoming April, we will be launching our first WORLD PREMIERE of a play that we featured in the 2017 New Wave New Works series. Alec Silberblatt's "The Angel of Allegheny County" delighted our audience, and we are so excited to present his work as a fully realized production. 

"The Angel of Allegheny County" by Alec Silberblatt

This dark and twisted comedy centers on four women in a small Pittsburgh community. The town holds an open secret about Nurse Donna, and her questionable past leads a few of the women in town to solicit her help. Life may not be fair, but Nurse Donna might be able to make it all better...

PERFORMANCE SCHEDULE

Tuesday April 24th - 7pm
Wednesday April 25th - 7pm
Thursday April 26th - 7pm
Friday April 27th - 7pm
Saturday April 28th - 2pm & 7pm
Sunday April 29th - 2pm & 4pm

 

The Team


Alec Silberblatt - Playwright

Alec Silberblatt is an actor and playwright based out of New York City. He was commissioned by NYU’s Steinhardt School to write a play for six individuals: three on the autism spectrum and their three caretakers. Rule Breaking premiered November 2015 in New York at the Provincetown Playhouse. His play Room For One was given a workshop production by The Middle Voice Theater Company, directed by Jenna Worsham in 2014. Other plays include: Four Green Walls, Out in the Hills of the West, A Body in the Allgeheny Valley (New Wave Theater Collective’s Reading Series), A Friend (Rising Phoenix Rep’s Cino Nights).  Film: Dog Out Window (writer/producer), The Officers (writer/director), Moving (a limited web series), and Bakery (a web series). Alec was the playwriting lab assistant for MCC Theater’s Youth Company for three years. Member: Middle Voice Theater Company. Training: BFA Acting, CCM. 

Daniella Caggiano - Director

DANIELLA CAGGIANO is a freelance director and native New Yorker. She was named one of The Interval's “Women to Watch” in 2016 and is an alum of Labyrinth’s Ensemble Workshop and the Lincoln Center Directors Lab. She has directed at Joe's Pub, The Flea, Dixon Place, Ugly Rhino, Musical Theatre Factory, Merkin Concert Hall, The Kraine, Le Poisson Rouge, HERE, FringeNYC, and 54 Below among others. Recent assisting: (Not) Water (dir. Daniella Topol), Tumacho and All The Ways To Say I Love You (both dir. Leigh Silverman). MFA The New School for Drama, BA Sarah Lawrence College www.daniellacaggiano.com

Sarah Wolff - Producer, NWTC Co-Founder

Originally from St. Louis, MO (Stages St. Louis: State Fair, Footloose!, Big! The Musical; MUNY: Annie, Peter Pan, Wizard Of Oz, A Night of Gershwin; New Jewish Theater: Unexpected Tenderness), Sarah earned her BFA in Acting from Sir Paul McCartney’s Liverpool Institute for the Performing Arts in Liverpool, England (LIPA: Unprotected, Kindertransport, A Midsummer Nights Dream, Sweet Charity) before moving to London (New End Theatre: A Rude Awakening; Edinburgh Fringe: Next Thing You Know; UK Tour: Aladdin, Cavern Club, Pop Party). She moved back to New York in 2013, (US tour: Alvin and the Chipmunks the Musical; TV: Grave Secrets, Evil Lives Here, True Crime; Film: Package From Santa, Deadbeat), where she co-founded New Wave Theater Collective (Producer/Director: What We’re Up Against; Director:Bull; Costar: Constellations; Producer: The New Sincerity).

Jenny Hickman - Producer, NWTC Co-Founder

Jenny Hickman is an actor, singer and producer based out of New York City. As an actor/singer, she has been seen performing regionally at Ogunquit Playhouse (The Witches of Eastwick), West Virginia Public Theater (Mary Poppins) and the Carnegie Theater (Parade). Film and TV credits include Law and Order: SVU and Discovery ID's "Shattered." She received a League of Cincinnati Theater Award for her performance in "Carrie: the Musical." She co-founded New Wave Theater Collective in 2016 (co-star: What We're Up Against, Director: Constellations, co-star: Bull, producer: The New Sincerity). Jenny holds a BFA in Musical Theater from the University of Cincinnati College- Conservatory of Music. 

What We Need

We are looking to raise $5000 in the next month to cover the following essentials:

$1400 will cover the performance space. To put on a play, one must have a stage! This is our largest single cost. 

$1000 will cover our rehearsal space, which is absolutely essential to preparing a production that is top quality. 

$1300 will cover the stipends for our cast and creative team. We want to make sure our actors, director and designers are compensated for their hard work. 

$1300 will cover the cost of props, costumes, set pieces and marketing materials, all to improve the quality of the production and increase our exposure. 

We depend on the generosity and support from our patrons to continue to produce high-quality art. Help us bring this brand new story to life!

story:
Short Summary

  • "Hi, my name is Alon Fisher, i am 20 years old and have been living in LA for a year now, originally from Australia. I have been passionate about theatre for several years now and have always had a driving passion to direct, Steve Martin's play, Picasso at the Lapin Agile. I am looking to raise money to help me create set, props and costumes for my production. By donating, you will be aiding me pursue my dream of being a director and put on an amazing show and let the world laugh again."
  •  

What We Need

  • We need to raise $2000 (by March 10th) for costumes, lighting, set and props equipment. The money raised will go directly to the production's needs.
  • If we don't reach the goal of $2000, the money raised will STILL go towards production equipment. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Please feel free to share this campaign with your friends and family on social media, as well as spread the word on the show, performance dates March 15th-17th.

Thank you very much

What We Need

We need to raise $2000 (by March 10th) for costumes, lighting, set and props equipment. The money raised will go directly to the production's needs.
If we don't reach the goal of $2000, the money raised will STILL go towards production equipment. 


Other Ways You Can Help
Please feel free to share this campaign with your friends and family on social media, as well as spread the word on the show, performance dates March 15th-17th.
Thank you very much

story:
THE STORY 

America, present. A pleasant suburb begins to form outside a major metropolitan city. Its residents are young, nice, and educated. They’re nothing like their parents— 

 

Save they don’t like when those kids enter their store. And should he really be dating our daughter? And who really is bringing drugs into our city? 

 

— So they decide to do something about it. Save they might go too far. And they may have been mistaken. Or they might have just been racist. And so a cycle of nightmarish violence begins… 

 

Utilizing (and subverting) the tradition of the Greek Chorus, HOUSE ON FIRE intermingles text, dance/movement, and art installation to probe the subtle violence of white supremacy, and the ways in which collective guilt/mania can capture and subvert language and narrative today. 

 

Text and direction by Jack Sullivan, produced by Leigh Honigman, HOUSE ON FIRE is a devised, experimental one act to be performed at the Tank (312 W. 36th St.) in Manhattan on Feb 20, 21, and 23, 2019 

 

WHY IT MATTERS

 

To say that the country is polarized would be an understatement. After what appeared to be a shift in the nation’s social and political views under former President Barack Obama, the sudden turn to the right came as a shock to most people. The virulent racism and xenophobia espoused by President Trump and his supporters — and make no mistake, it is racism and xenophobia — feels as though from another, less-enlightened era. 

 

HOUSE ON FIRE proposes though that nothing really ever changed — those with privilege have just found new vocabulary, new gestures, new buildings, and structures to pave over the dark, poisoned heart of American culture. And if you were to put these people on stage to explain themselves, you might find they’d prove themselves to be just as bad, if not worse, than the monsters that came before them. 

 

HOUSE ON FIRE is a play for today, exposing the ways in which white supremacy twists language and narrative to try to justify its actions. Yet the play is also contemporary in how it was made: with a diverse cast and production team (majority PoC and female actors), a production devised in collaboration from an open performance text by all on the production team, from directors to actor to sound designer. By utilizing this broad set of voices, in such a democratic manner, we hope to subvert the hive mind mentality and inflammatory rhetoric of Trumpian America, and expose it for the babble that it is. 

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES 

 

Live production has all sorts of risks and challenges. The most obvious challenge in New York City is making sure that artists get paid. All of the artists involved in this production work multiple jobs, have loans and rent payments to work about. Just the act of centering artistic production while financially unstable takes a great amount of courage. Another challenge being that the way we are working requires the actors/production teams full attention: each performer, designer, etc., will be involved at every step of the process, necessitating a lot of thought and training both within the rehearsal room, and without. We want to make sure the actors and production team are compensated for their time and effort, so that they may fully commit themselves to exploring the important themes that the text presents. 

 

The final challenge that goes along with that is making sure that artists (actors and production staff) as well as the audience feel that they are in the space that is conducive to conversation. As a production team we want to make sure we have the ability to provide resources for both actors/audiences, and have the wherewithal to be able to reach out to academics/other figures in the community to come in and help facilitate conversation post show.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help

1.) Share our Facebook and Instagram pages!

Facebook: @houseonfire1

Instagram: @hausonfire2

 

2.) Buy tickets to our show!

Feb. 20 (7pm), 21 (930pm), 23 (3pm) at the Tank in Manhattan (212 W. 36th St.)

Ticket link to come soon!

 

3.) Support anti-racism/anti-gentrification organizations!

An incomplete list of links -- 

NAACP: https://www.naacp.org/

Lawyer's Committee for Civil Right Under Law: https://lawyerscommittee.org/

Brooklyn Anti-Gentrification Network: https://bangentrification.org/

Right to the City: https://righttothecity.org/

Families United for Racial and Economic Equality: https://righttothecity.org/

Queens Neighborhoods United: https://www.facebook.com/QueensNeighborhoodsUnited
story_txt:
THE STORY 
America, present. A pleasant suburb begins to form outside a major metropolitan city. Its residents are young, nice, and educated. They’re nothing like their parents— 
 
Save they don’t like when those kids enter their store. And should he really be dating our daughter? And who really is bringing drugs into our city? 
 
— So they decide to do something about it. Save they might go too far. And they may have been mistaken. Or they might have just been racist. And so a cycle of nightmarish violence begins… 
 
Utilizing (and subverting) the tradition of the Greek Chorus, HOUSE ON FIRE intermingles text, dance/movement, and art installation to probe the subtle violence of white supremacy, and the ways in which collective guilt/mania can capture and subvert language and narrative today. 
 
Text and direction by Jack Sullivan, produced by Leigh Honigman, HOUSE ON FIRE is a devised, experimental one act to be performed at the Tank (312 W. 36th St.) in Manhattan on Feb 20, 21, and 23, 2019 

 
WHY IT MATTERS
 
To say that the country is polarized would be an understatement. After what appeared to be a shift in the nation’s social and political views under former President Barack Obama, the sudden turn to the right came as a shock to most people. The virulent racism and xenophobia espoused by President Trump and his supporters — and make no mistake, it is racism and xenophobia — feels as though from another, less-enlightened era.

Instagram: @hausonfire2
 
2.) Buy tickets to our show!

Ticket link to come soon!

story:
SEND COOL GIRAFFES TO HHI 2018

ABOUT

Based out of the Kore Dance Studio in Edmonton, Alberta. Cool Giraffes is a pre-professional dance company that was originated as a dance project founded by Randall Mella in the summer of 2016. The project was developed by Randall to showcase his craft as a choreographer in the competitive circuit as well as dance and to have fun with his group of friends. In the past two years- the team debuted at World of Dance Edmonton, garnered tremendous support by the local dance community, competed across Canada, and has grown to over 35+ members and alumni.  

The team has transitioned into a hip hop company consisting of 28 members who come from different walks of life and range between the ages of 14 to 27. Current directors, Randall Mella and Thomas Boivin, ensure that with dance comes a strong foundation of friendship and hard work. With these values, we are consistently inspired and encouraged to support one another to strive to be the best we can be as dancers and people.

CURRENTLY

It has been an exciting year for the team as the team received first place in the Mega Crew All-Stars Category at Represent Street Dance Competition and competed at Hip-Hop International’s regional qualifiers. The team travelled to Ottawa in June to compete and qualified to represent Canada at Hip Hop International being held in Phoenix, Arizona. The team is honoured to be one of three megacrews to represent Canada at worlds level.

HELP OUT SOME COOL GIRAFFES

To get to the world stage, each member is funding themselves individually and the costs of getting to Hip Hop International has taken a financial strain on each member. To support this trip, any amount helps and we are so incredibly thankful for your support in our journey to compete and represent our country at Hip Hop International World Championship 2018!
