story:
About The Space Above

The Space Above, set to premiere at the Nevada Museum of Art on February 13, 2020, is a multimedia, evening-length dance work in collaboration with Tweaking Reality Studios. The show features poetry by Valerie Padovani, videography by Tweaking Reality Studios, light installations by Jared Clemmensen and choreography by Reno, NV based contemporary dance company, Collateral & Co., and NY based choreographer, Leisa DeCarlo. 


Following six dancers from sunset to sunrise in the Nevada desert, The Space Above explores the vast Nevada sky, the thoughts that exist in our own minds, and attempts to make sense of our place in a world of darkness and light..

About Collateral & Co. 

Collateral & Co. Contemporary Dance Company was founded in May 2017 when Founder and Artistic Director Caitlin McCarty returned home to the Reno, Nevada area after working for New York based Gallim Dance. Collateral & Co. explores the intricacies of the human experience and investigates the nuances of everyday life through exploration of written word, physical and emotional experiences, and bodily expression.

Collateral & Co. Contemporary Dance Company was founded in May 2017 when Founder and Artistic Director Caitlin McCarty returned home to the Reno, Nevada area after working for New York based Gallim Dance. The company’s recent works include performances of “Dust Settled” at Wingfield Park for the 2019 Artown festival,  at the Nevada Museum of Art in April 2019 for "Dust Horizon," the production of The Poetry Movement, a 2018 Artown dance performance at Sundance Books and Music, and their first work, “Gunpowder and Femme” at Reno Little Theater in November 2017. The company has performed site specific works at the Nevada Humanities 2018 and 2019 Literary Crawls and at the Nevada Museum of Art in the Spring of 2019. 

About Tweaking Reality Studios 

James Coleman II, Tweaking Reality Studios Co-founder and Lead Director, has always had a camera in his possession. At eight years old he was using a VHS camcorder to script, direct and produce small films. His passion for filmmaking continued. He attended a career-technical high school, specifically their video production program. During the program he had the opportunity to work for a professional production company, where for two years he produced video content for the City of Reno, independent television shows, award-winning documentaries and much more.

In 2016, with the help of his partner Elspeth Summers (Co-founder and Director), Tweaking Reality Studios was created. They began their company producing small documentaries about local Reno artists. They were captivated by the artists’ passion for creativity in the community. From there they built their business on the principle of consistently producing grounded, professional content for their clients. 

Since the beginning they have been fortunate to work with a wide variety of clients in a wide array of industries. Some of their clients have included University of Nevada Reno, Bishop Manogue High School, Nevada Museum of Art, Carson High School, Carson City Tourism Authority, Truckee Meadows Community College, Carson City LIbrary, the State of Nevada, Nevada Momentum and Sierra Arts Foundation. 

About Leisa DeCarlo

Leisa DeCarlo is a New York-based dancer, choreographer, and arts administrator with a dual B.F.A. in Dance and B.A. in Journalism from Ohio State University. With a diverse history of experience as a dance practitioner as well as in artistic direction, education, fundraising, marketing, and programming, Leisa brings a rare blend of expertise, innovation, and creative curiosity to the arts sector that propels organizations' missions while building relevance, sustainability, and impact. 

Leisa has worked with pillars in the field such as Lorry May, Vera J. Blaine, Noa Zuk, Ohad Fishof, Jacqulyn Buglisi, Bebe Miller, Hernando Cortez, Julia Ehrstrand, Susan Hadley, Dave Covey, Susan Van Pelt Petry, Terence Greene, Abby Zbikowski, Ann Sofie Clemmensen, Olivier Tarpaga, Meghan Durham Wall, and Ronald A. Brown, as well as performed timeless works by Ulysses Dove, Yvonne Rainer, and Anna Sokolow. Leisa has had the immense opportunity to work and perform with companies such as Verb Ballets, Buglisi Dance Theatre at Lincoln Center, ZviDance, Impact Movement Collective, Columbus Moving Company, Kelley Donovan & Dancers, Cleveland Dance Academy, NACHMO, and Ohio Dance Theatre in the Youth America Grand Prix, as well as in dance-for-camera films including Targeted Advertising, directed and filmed by Mitchell Rose/choreographed by Susan Hadley, At Fault, directed and choreographed by Effy Grey, and Impersistence by Jessica Cavendar. Leisa was also featured in the Pelotonia commercial Cancer-Free World.

In 2014, Leisa performed in China as an American cultural ambassador, where she led movement workshops at Ullens Center for Contemporary Art in Beijing, Wuhan University, Changchun and Northeast Normal University, Xinxiang, and Shanghai University, and conducted international research later exhibited at the Denman Research Forum. In 2018, Leisa debuted Ink, a self-choreographed solo presented by New Vision Dance Company, and in 2019, premiered as the dust settles, a work created for her educational residency and commission for Henrico Center for the Arts in Richmond, Virginia.

Leisa’s desire to explore the many facets of the art form have steered her to multigenerational dance company Dances For A Variable Population, an organization that promotes dance as an innovative approach to therapy and empowerment through creative movement with a special focus on senior adults, Peridance Capezio Center in collaboration with Ronald K. Alexander, Dance/NYC as an advocate for the advancement of inclusion, accessibility, and equity at the core of today’s dance/arts culture, and Gallim, under the direction of Andrea Miller, where she curated a series of educational arts programming and was instrumental in the company’s groundbreaking choreographic residency at The Metropolitan Museum of Art as well as its first-ever self-produced Joyce Theater season in NYC. Currently, Leisa serves as the Marketing Coordinator for Ballet Academy East, holds the sole associate position with Amirov Dance Theater, and plays an integral role in the production of dynamic national and international arts marketplaces as Audience Development Manager at Show-Hamptons. In addition to fueling her passion for movement as an independent performer and choreographer, Leisa is a company dancer for Impact Movement Collective and a Dance Instructor at Dance Centre of the Hamptons. Leisa is also a Certified Pilates Mat Instructor.

Why Your Donation Helps

Funding an evening-length dance performance is TOUGH. Here's how we benefit from the generous donation of your hard-earned dollars:

  • Because of you, Collateral & Co. dancers will be justly paid for their time, energy and performance.
  • Because of you, Collateral & Co. will be able to appropriately compensate the guest artist for her commitment, time and travel. 
  • Because of you, Collateral & Co.  will continue to create a platform for local dancers, choreographers and artists to pursue artistic exploration, to culturally and artistically enrich the Reno, Nevada community and engage in partnerships that foster dialogue about dance, art, and the human experience. 

Types of Donations

  • Quick 20: A $20 donation gets you a social media shoutout from the company! 
  • Double your money: A $40 donation gets you a custom designed HOFF Goods sticker. 
  • Triple up: A $60 donation gets you a custom designed HOFF Goods Sticker + a custom designed HOFF Goods Button. 
  • The Bronze Donor: A $100 donation gets you all the aforementioned perks + you'll get a personal thank you from the company. 
  • The Silver Donor: A $150 donation gets you all the perks + you'll get a custom designed HOFF Goods T-Shirt 
  • The Gold Donor: A $200+ donation gets you all the aforementioned perks + you'll get a personal thank you from the company + a shoutout in the show program. This perk is good for local businesses!

All merchandise will be delivered within a month of the culmination of the Indiegogo campaign. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Buy a ticket to the show!  -- TICKETS 
  • Donate via check! Just email: caitlin@collateralandco.com

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Our Story 

Michael and Robert met over 10 years ago in a basement classroom at Circle in the Square Theatre in New York City.  Their bond was forged that first day of class over a soul searching acting exercise.  From that day forward they both knew they were destined to create magic onstage together one day.  That first collaborative opportunity came in 2012 ironically through Michael's wife, Vanessa Lenz Neithardt, and her play, Names of the Dead  ( FringeNYC– at the Connelly Theater.)  On top of co-producing with Vanessa, Michael took on the daunting role of playing a suicidal, PTSD suffering veteran. Just the right director was needed to handle this difficult material with the care and consideration it demanded.  The first person that came to mind was Robert Greene - a.k.a. RG—he jumped at the challenge.  Not only did RG direct the play with amazing grace and help elevate it to its greatest potential, but he also got to act onstage with Michael,  portraying his character's best friend in a poignant scene of the play. 

Cut to 6 years later. After a lot of conversations and ideas flowing,  RG came to Michael with a rough draft of Situations.  Immediately Michael knew that it was something special—a deeply personal journey with a multitude of layers.  And who better to direct RG through this maze than his friend and confidant.  With the FringeNYC festival coming back after a one year hiatus, the timing was perfect. 

Their roles have been shuffled and the trio is back at it again–Robert as writer/actor, Michael as director/producer and Vanessa as producer–all under the Palmy Inn umbrella (Michael's production company) showcasing once again at The New York International Fringe Festival.  Serendipitously, FringeNYC introduced a new program this year, FringeBYOV (Bring Your Own Venue) in order to reach stages and audiences in the outer boroughs.  

Situations is coming home where it belongs—to Brooklyn. 

 

Why we need your support

Palmy Inn is all about transparency and treating artists with respect. We love working in the arts and being surrounded by incredible talent, which should not come free. We work with the best of the best and need to compensate them for their time and artistry.

Our total budget is over $15,000 for the 9 show/three week run. The goal is to fund near 75% of the budget, with the rest being covered by ticket sales.

Summary of our budget line items: 

  • Stage and rehearsal space rental -  $5,000
  • Compensation for the stage manager, lighting designer, set designer, music director, costume designer, director, actor/writer, producer and production assistants - $7,500
  • Marketing and PR - $1,250
  • Misc additional costs - $1,500

Costs add up quickly.  We are grateful for your support in helping us create a memorable, thought-provoking and engaging theater experience. ***all additional proceeds from ticket sales (if any) will go towards future Palmy Inn Theatrical Productions. Supporters will be updated with a final actual for the project**

 

Who we are

Robert Greene is an actor, director and playwright.  He has an MFA in Performance from the University of Louisville and is currently the Assistant Director and Theater Teacher at Kids' Canvas in Brooklyn.  Robert is a member The East Harlem Repertory Company and the creative consultant for Mus-ED Learning.  He has performed and premiered new works at The National Black Theatre Festival, Kentucky Shakespeare Festival, The August Wilson Center in Pittsburg and The International Theatre Festival of Russia.  Recent credits included Mandela (Pregones Theater) The Motown Story (National Black Theater) as well as an adaptation of The Orphan of Chao which toured Singapore. 

Michael  Neithardt  is a Producer, Director and Writer.  Born in Queens, Michael began his career at Miramax Films.  Over the last 20 years, he has worked as a leading producer in the field of theater, film, television and commercials.  As Managing Director of Animus Theatre Company, Michael produced the Theatre Row production of Tennessee William’s Collected Shorts as well as their 2015 Reading Festival of Leslye Headland's Sin Cycle plays and the 2016 Reading Festival of John Patrick Shanley's works at Broadway's Circle in the Square Theatre.  His short film, I'm Happy, was chosen as one of eight finalists at Tropfest 2012  and his short, alive feeling like a buck seventy-five, won best short film at the New Hampshire Film Festival.  Michael ran the NY office of Stardust Studios, was Executive Producer at Psyop and is the founder of the industry leading content production company, Palmy Inn. 

Vanessa Lenz Neithardt is a New York born and bread photographer, producer and playwright. Her portrait and fashion photography has been widely published in Vogue Italia, Martha Stewart Living,  The New York Times, LA Times, BUST Magazine, O Magazine, Essence, amongst others. She has produced multiple off-off Broadway theater in New York City including her own play, Names of the Dead, at the Connelly Theater for FringeNYC.  She co-produced and shot the award winning short films, I'm Happy and alive feeling like a buck seventy-five. 

Allison Raynes (Stage Manager) NYC credits included: A Walk In The Woods, The Thing With Feathers, Muswell Hill, Expecting Isabel, Abigail's Party (The Barrow Group); The Providence of Neighboring Bodies [NYC & Edinburgh Fringe], Latter Days, The Sister [Edinburgh Fringe] (Dutch Kills); Less Than 50% (Dir. Markus Potter, reading), The Gun Show (Project Y. WiT Festival); Half Moon Bay (Lesser America), Pass Over (Cherry Lane, Mentor Project); Connected (Project Y at 59E59)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Of course we need and want your donations but we mostly want to share this incredible show with you.  Bring your friends and family–spread the word.  We won't let you down.  Situations on the way...

Situations Schedule

Where:  *BAX, Brooklyn Arts Exchange–421 Fifth Avenue Brooklyn, NY

When:  October 12th - 27th, Fridays 8PM, Saturdays 7PM and 9PM

Tickets:  $22 on sale here 

 

*This production is being presented through BAX’s Visitors Program, a subsidized performance package rental program, and is a self-production by Palmy Inn
story_txt:
Our Story 
Michael and Robert met over 10 years ago in a basement classroom at Circle in the Square Theatre in New York City.  Their bond was forged that first day of class over a soul searching acting exercise.  From that day forward they both knew they were destined to create magic onstage together one day.  That first collaborative opportunity came in 2012 ironically through Michael's wife, Vanessa Lenz Neithardt, and her play, Names of the Dead  ( FringeNYC– at the Connelly Theater.)  On top of co-producing with Vanessa, Michael took on the daunting role of playing a suicidal, PTSD suffering veteran. Just the right director was needed to handle this difficult material with the care and consideration it demanded.  The first person that came to mind was Robert Greene - a.k.a. RG—he jumped at the challenge.  Not only did RG direct the play with amazing grace and help elevate it to its greatest potential, but he also got to act onstage with Michael,  portraying his character's best friend in a poignant scene of the play. 
Cut to 6 years later. After a lot of conversations and ideas flowing,  RG came to Michael with a rough draft of Situations.  Immediately Michael knew that it was something special—a deeply personal journey with a multitude of layers.  And who better to direct RG through this maze than his friend and confidant.  With the FringeNYC festival coming back after a one year hiatus, the timing was perfect. 
Their roles have been shuffled and the trio is back at it again–Robert as writer/actor, Michael as director/producer and Vanessa as producer–all under the Palmy Inn umbrella (Michael's production company) showcasing once again at The New York International Fringe Festival.  Serendipitously, FringeNYC introduced a new program this year, FringeBYOV (Bring Your Own Venue) in order to reach stages and audiences in the outer boroughs.  
Situations is coming home where it belongs—to Brooklyn. 
 

Why we need your support
Palmy Inn is all about transparency and treating artists with respect. We love working in the arts and being surrounded by incredible talent, which should not come free. We work with the best of the best and need to compensate them for their time and artistry.
Our total budget is over $15,000 for the 9 show/three week run. The goal is to fund near 75% of the budget, with the rest being covered by ticket sales.
Summary of our budget line items: 

Stage and rehearsal space rental -  $5,000

Compensation for the stage manager, lighting designer, set designer, music director, costume designer, director, actor/writer, producer and production assistants - $7,500

Marketing and PR - $1,250

Misc additional costs - $1,500


Costs add up quickly.  We are grateful for your support in helping us create a memorable, thought-provoking and engaging theater experience. ***all additional proceeds from ticket sales (if any) will go towards future Palmy Inn Theatrical Productions. Supporters will be updated with a final actual for the project**
 

Who we are
Robert Greene is an actor, director and playwright.  He has an MFA in Performance from the University of Louisville and is currently the Assistant Director and Theater Teacher at Kids' Canvas in Brooklyn.  Robert is a member The East Harlem Repertory Company and the creative consultant for Mus-ED Learning.  He has performed and premiered new works at The National Black Theatre Festival, Kentucky Shakespeare Festival, The August Wilson Center in Pittsburg and The International Theatre Festival of Russia.  Recent credits included Mandela (Pregones Theater) The Motown Story (National Black Theater) as well as an adaptation of The Orphan of Chao which toured Singapore. 
Michael  Neithardt  is a Producer, Director and Writer.  Born in Queens, Michael began his career at Miramax Films.  Over the last 20 years, he has worked as a leading producer in the field of theater, film, television and commercials.  As Managing Director of Animus Theatre Company, Michael produced the Theatre Row production of Tennessee William’s Collected Shorts as well as their 2015 Reading Festival of Leslye Headland's Sin Cycle plays and the 2016 Reading Festival of John Patrick Shanley's works at Broadway's Circle in the Square Theatre.  His short film, I'm Happy, was chosen as one of eight finalists at Tropfest 2012  and his short, alive feeling like a buck seventy-five, won best short film at the New Hampshire Film Festival.  Michael ran the NY office of Stardust Studios, was Executive Producer at Psyop and is the founder of the industry leading content production company, Palmy Inn. 
Vanessa Lenz Neithardt is a New York born and bread photographer, producer and playwright. Her portrait and fashion photography has been widely published in Vogue Italia, Martha Stewart Living,  The New York Times, LA Times, BUST Magazine, O Magazine, Essence, amongst others. She has produced multiple off-off Broadway theater in New York City including her own play, Names of the Dead, at the Connelly Theater for FringeNYC.  She co-produced and shot the award winning short films, I'm Happy and alive feeling like a buck seventy-five. 
Allison Raynes (Stage Manager) NYC credits included: A Walk In The Woods, The Thing With Feathers, Muswell Hill, Expecting Isabel, Abigail's Party (The Barrow Group); The Providence of Neighboring Bodies [NYC & Edinburgh Fringe], Latter Days, The Sister [Edinburgh Fringe] (Dutch Kills); Less Than 50% (Dir. Markus Potter, reading), The Gun Show (Project Y. WiT Festival); Half Moon Bay (Lesser America), Pass Over (Cherry Lane, Mentor Project); Connected (Project Y at 59E59)

 
Other Ways You Can Help
Of course we need and want your donations but we mostly want to share this incredible show with you.  Bring your friends and family–spread the word.  We won't let you down.  Situations on the way...
Situations Schedule
Where:  *BAX, Brooklyn Arts Exchange–421 Fifth Avenue Brooklyn, NY
When:  October 12th - 27th, Fridays 8PM, Saturdays 7PM and 9PM
Tickets:  $22 on sale here 
 
*This production is being presented through BAX’s Visitors Program, a subsidized performance package rental program, and is a self-production by Palmy Inn

story:
The money we getting for the shows that Kitty Tray and Kelsay Higton help us to set up in Scotland and England does not cover all the expenses we have. Plane tickets real expensive especially! We have to pay for lodging, food, other travel expenses like train tickets, and petrol (that's how you say et right?) because Kelsay she actually driving us around here and there.

 

We are lifelong broke ass artists! Always living on da edge! So many times we way behind in rent, I'm surprised we haven't got kicked out of our haunted house.

So I'm wondering, can you help us? Can you cover the cost of the plane tickets so we can actually not lose money on this kwazy thing? It would be so kewl if you could and we would be super grateful! Help a couple bitches out, eh?

We put a little Indie Go-go together and we have a bunch of really kewl and fun perks you get if you give!

story:
Help us bring Shakedown 12th Night to the stage!

We are an ensemble of eleven theatre artists who want to revive a cancelled dream project: a musical production of Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night. Our best shot is getting a proper workshop, culminating in a showcase to woo interested theatre companies. To put on said workshop we need $3,000.

Give us a hand, won’t you?

The Players

Our cast is comprised of ten actor/musician/etceteras: Ben Euphrat, Will Hand, Nick Medina, Rebecca Pingree, Ari Rampy, Billy Raphael, Deborah Rucker, Terry Rucker, Leah Russo, Jeremy Vik, and, of course, our fearless leader Jon Tracy (writer/director/theatrical-bad-ass). Our collective skill set contains (but is certainly not limited to) juggling, acrobatics, hand springs, hand-balancing, guitar, mandolin, violin, banjo, bouzouki, didgeridoo, ukulele, drums, tambourine, percussion, piano, accordion, and vocals that’ll make your mama cry. Also, we’re pretty into the language of Shakespeare. Which is a musical instrument in and of itself. BAM.

The Vision

As artists, we are always trying to envision the best way to tell a story, but how do you tell one of the best stories ever? Jon has looked towards ritual as inspiration. From that kernel came a landscape of musical narrative, powerful physical storytelling and a heightened realism; a dark, turbulent world which blurs the line between the figurative and the literal.

In Shakedown, the events of the classic story have already passed but every year the people that lived through it commemorate their shared experience with a ritualized retelling. Each character relives their story, but also serves as the audience, the chorus, and the band for the others; each a part of this community bound together by the events of the play.

And check out these images that inspire the look of our world.

The Breakdown

The bare bones minimum we need is a rehearsal space, a showcase venue, a stage manager, and travel stipends for our artists.

Anything we get above our goal will go to recouping our losses from the first part of our rehearsal process, compensating our lovely director, and toward the overall amazingness of our dear, dear Twelfth-Night-that-could.

Nitty gritty details:
Rehearsal space: Octakord Studios. Octakord is an aerial-rigged music studio in Oakland with 40ft ceilings and a sprung floor, perfect for all our tumbling, acrobatic, musical-jamming, visual-storytelling shenanigans. The good people at Octakord, hearing our tale of woe, have generously agreed to charge us a mere $200 for a forty hour workshop process.

Showcase venue: TBD (check back for updates) We are still in talks to secure a venue for a performance on Sunday, August 4th, with a final rehearsal the day before. We need floors safe enough for the acrobatics, space for ten actors and their many instruments, height enough to stand on each others shoulders (literally!) and enough room to seat our eager audience. So far, the venues that meet this criteria and are available will cost about $500 for 2 weekend days of rehearsal and performance.

Stage Manager: TBD. Executing an impressive theatrical showcase is all about logistics, especially for such an ambitious project with this many people to keep in the loop, instruments to keep safe, and locations to be responsible for. Also, we are theatre people. Sweet Jeebus do we need managing. Fortunately, Jon is already in touch with a few experienced folks who are willing to help us for less than their normal rate.

Actors: The Shakedown Ensemble. Our actors originally signed on to the project for a very modest stipend of $450 each, covering 110 hours of rehearsal, 5 performances, and a lengthy commute. At the point at which the production was cancelled, we had completed about 40 hours of rehearsal, and it was clear that there would no longer be compensation for it. We’ve accepted that loss because of how strongly we believe in the project and each other. On the other hand, as kids trying to make it in the theatre, we all live pretty close to the financial edge, so $450 out of our pockets was a bit of a blow. The workshop we propose is 40 hours over two weeks, with a single performance, and we hope to raise $200 dollars for each of our actors, both to give them something for their work and also to offset their transportation and other costs associated with the previous unpaid rehearsal process.

The Bottom Line?
Add about $100 worth of Indiegogo fees and our budget looks like this:

Rehearsal venue                                     200

Performance venue                                 500

Stage Manager                                       200

10 Actors ($200 stipends for each)         2000

Indiegogo Fees (4% if goal is reached)     100

Total Workshop Campaign                    $3000

But wait, you say. What about our Director? Jon Tracy has been directing professionally for many years, with recent shows at The Magic, Shotgun Players, The Aurora, San Francisco Playhouse, and Marin Theatre Company, to name a few. Surely he expects to be paid? Nope. Jon’s priority is to get this project restarted.

For thy sweet love...such wealth brings...

Not everyone can throw cash monies at us and our Shakedown dream but fear not! Your love is powerful stuff. Sharing this post on your facebook page or twitter feed (or just good old-fashioned telling someone about it) will help bring our campaign to more folks attention. Even dropping us a line or giving us a call to convey your support would be downright awesome. If you're especially swamped, telepathy is totally cool, too..i'faith, we can feel it now...

story:
It started as a sudden strange fancy:  Polly Perks needed to join the army to find her lost brother.  Except that in Borogravia, women aren’t allowed to join the army, or do much of anything interesting, really.  A haircut, a change of clothes, and an extra pair of socks later, Polly is now Private Oliver Perks, marching off to war as part of the finest army on the Discworld, joined by a (reformed) vampire with a coffee habit, a lieutenant who cuts himself on his sword hand during practice, and the most legendary sergeant in Borogravia.  And the enemy are looking for them…

Presented at Pauper’s Pub as part of the Site-Specific program at the Toronto Fringe Festival, the show is a raucous, immersive satire of gender roles, army life, and war stories.

Terry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment is the final production of Socratic Theatre Collective’s third season, and our fifth full-length production.  We are a Toronto-based independent theatre company; our mission is to produce theatre that creates a dialogue.  You talk to us in your applause, your presence and we talk back to you. And yes, we often talk about murder, mayhem, ghosts, girls in corsets, and badass ladies with knives, swords and knitting needles but isn’t that what you like talking about too? 

Our previous productions are:  Hamlet, Princess of Denmark; Ismene; The Dark Room; the short play Wrong Number, for which we won the Fresh Spice Award at the 2012 What Are You Doing BACK There?! Festival; Terry Pratchett’s Mort; and the short play Snow, Glass, Apples.  Since our founding in 2010, we have won an award, received critical acclaim, raised funds for charity, collaborated with companies from across Canada, the United States, and Ireland, and produced world and Canadian premieres. If you want more details, have a look at our website, www.socratictheatre.com.  We’re really not shy about what we’ve achieved.

However, as proud as we are of our history, returning to the Toronto Fringe Festival withTerry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment is a huge undertaking for the company.  We are going to be bringing war, mayhem, and a large amount of cross-dressing to Toronto theatre.  And you’re going to help us because who doesn’t want to bring all these things to Toronto?

 

Our campaign goal is $3500.00.  Of that total, here is how it breaks down:

$1000.00 goes to the rental of our rehearsal spaces.

$900.00 goes to the royalties for Terry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment.

$725.00 goes to our participation fee for the Toronto Fringe Festival

$875.00 goes to our props and costumes.

If we don’t reach our full goal, this is the order in which the funds will be prioritized (ie, we will use them to pay for the rental first, then the royalties, etc.).

 

Have a look at our list of perks – you could receive:

A Terry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment postcard signed by the cast and crew!

A listing on our website and programme, so you can show off your generosity!

A free drink or food at Pauper’s Pub during a performance of Terry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment!

Tickets to Terry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment, because you simply can’t miss it!

If you represent a business, we can also provide advertising space in our show programme in addition to all these perks!

WEAR THE LILAC CAMPAIGN

In honour of Terry Pratchett’s ongoing battle with Alzheimer’s disease, we will be continuing the Wear the Lilac Campaign that began with last year’s fundraising campaign.

Here's how it works:

For any contribution made to this campaign, Socratic Theatre Collective will donate the equivalent of 10% to the Alzheimer Society of Canada.  In other words, if you donate $100 to us, we'll donate $10 to the Alzheimer Society of Canada out of our own pocket.

Last year, the Wear the Lilac campaign raised $171 for the Alzheimer Society of Canada.  Our goal for this year is $300, so help us make it happen!

 

“But wait!” you say, “Aren’t you charging admission?  Why can’t you use that money to pay for all of these things?”  To which we say:  look at the breakdown.  There is no entry for artist fees or wages.  This is because NO-ONE at Socratic Theatre Collective is paid up front; everyone works on the shows on a volunteer basis.  If the campaign for Terry Pratchett’s Monstrous Regiment is fully funded, it means that the box office revenue can be divided between the fourteen cast members and the director and stage manager.  This means that sixteen people will actually get paid a small amount for their hard work and their considerable sacrifice of time and energy.  We all want to keep making theatre, and we want to make sure that Socratic Theatre Collective is able to attract top-quality artists to work with us.  And don’t you want to see us produce more shows like Monstrous Regiment?

 

Remember – even the smallest contribution helps!  And what else helps?  Getting the word out, and telling people about us!  Post our campaign on Facebook, and don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools.

 

Igg.me/at/monstrousregiment

story:
FUNDRAISER ENDS AT MIDNIGHT TONIGHT!!

 

Excuse me for the long update but I have been asked these questions quite a bit and thought it would be helpful if I addressed them to everyone:

"why not raise ticket prices to help with the funding",

"what about buying one projector now and the rest later", 

"what will you do if you don't reach your goal" and

"will you stay in business if you don't reach your goal" 
...


Here goes:

We initially thought about raising the ticket prices but decided not to for a couple of reasons.  First is that we want to stay true to our business model which is to be an affordable family entertainment venue. Raising prices goes against this.  Plus, 35-45% of every dollar we bring in goes to the movie studios so if we raised prices all we would be doing is putting more money in their pocket.  No thanks.

I  wish we could buy the projectors one at a time and spread out the payments but the reason we were forced to turn to crowdsourcing is that film won't be available after this year.  We need to convert all now.

We still have several days left and are still hoping to reach our goal, or get close to it. That said, crowdsourcing is never a guaranteed success. We knew that going into this and we do have a backup plan. If we do not raise the full amount by the 30th, we will do other various fundraising events to close the gap.

The business is solid - we aren't raising money to keep the business afloat because we made poor business decisions - we're raising money to buy projectors we didn't know we'd need when we opened 7 years ago. The money raised is ONLY going to projectors - not to paying our bills. We've promoted the heck out of this thing online and in the media and we are hoping donations will continue to come in between now and the end of the campaign. 

Thank you to everyone who has supported us!  We are blown away by the support and we hope in these last four days, we can keep the momentum and get to our goal!

Thanks, Julie

 

 

 

Overview

Seven years ago, we preserved an important piece of Portland’s cinematic history and helped transform an entire neighborhood in the process.

Now we’re at a crossroads, and we need your help. Simply put, without your financial support, rather than preserving history, we may become history.

Here’s the scoop: For close to a century, the words movie and film have been interchangeable. Soon this won’t be the case. By year’s end, all new Hollywood releases will only be screened digitally, rendering 35mm projection equipment obsolete. 

If the Academy Theater wants to avoid the fate of those who believed “talkies” were simply a fad, we must convert from film to digital equipment as soon as possible. But that's not as easy as it sounds.

 

DIGITAL CONVERSION: Frequently Asked Questions  http://www.academytheaterpdx.com/digital-conversion-fundraising/

 

What We Need & What You Get

Unfortunately, new equipment is incredibly expensive. Upgrading to digital projectors in all three theaters will cost approximately $96,000. Installation costs and necessary sound system upgrades will require an additional $21,000. As you can imagine, this is an enormous financial burden for a small independent theater.

Our (admittedly) ambitious goal is to raise $75,000 (or more!) by September 30, 2013. This amount will help cover the total cost of three new digital projectors, sound system upgrades, installation charges and Indiegogo processing fees. You can help us reach this goal by making a donation today. 

In exchange for your contribution, we will reward you with one of the many fabulous incentives listed on the right hand side of this page. 

Any amount, however small, helps push us closer to our goal. 

Assuming we reach this goal, digital conversion will happen immediately (although installation of new equipment may take several days.) And once new projectors are installed, our movies will look and sound better than ever!

 

The Impact

When we decided to restore the Academy, our goal was simple. We wanted to create a friendly neighborhood venue where families looking for a fun night out wouldn’t blow an entire paycheck buying popcorn, soda and a few movie tickets. For the past seven years we’ve sustained that goal by offering our patrons affordable entertainment, food and childcare in a beautiful 1940s setting. And the Montavilla neighborhood has thrived as a result.

We love our community, we love our theater, and we love how our theater has enriched the surrounding neighborhood in ways we never could have predicted. We know that you - the 2000+ patrons who visit the Academy each week - feel the same way. That is why we are hoping that -- with your help – we can continue to be a vital part of the Montavilla neighborhood for many years to come.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute financially, please know that you can help by simply spreading the word! Just share this page with family, friends and colleagues -- or post it to Facebook and Twitter -- and encourage others to do the same. Our fundraising campaign can only be as successful as we are in spreading the word about it. 

In closing, we’d like to thank you, both for your patronage over the past seven years and for taking time to learn about our fundraising campaign. If there’s one message we hope you take away from our campaign, it’s this: 

 

Without your support, we’d be history!

 

About The Academy: Originally launched in 1948, the Academy Theater was a popular Southeast Portland destination until its closure in the 1970s. Three decades of neglect took their toll, but a full-scale renovation was completed in 2006. Great attention was paid to every detail of the project. Using vintage photos of the theater’s first incarnation, the glittering rounded lobby and signature marquee were restored to perfection, imbuing the building with authentic 1940s charm. For more information, please visit our web site at www.academytheaterpdx.com.
story_txt:
FUNDRAISER ENDS AT MIDNIGHT TONIGHT!!
 
Excuse me for the long update but I have been asked these questions quite a bit and thought it would be helpful if I addressed them to everyone:  "why not raise ticket prices to help with the funding",  "what about buying one projector now and the rest later",   "what will you do if you don't reach your goal" and  "will you stay in business if you don't reach your goal"  ... Here goes: We initially thought about raising the ticket prices but decided not to for a couple of reasons.  First is that we want to stay true to our business model which is to be an affordable family entertainment venue. Raising prices goes against this.  Plus, 35-45% of every dollar we bring in goes to the movie studios so if we raised prices all we would be doing is putting more money in their pocket.  No thanks. I  wish we could buy the projectors one at a time and spread out the payments but the reason we were forced to turn to crowdsourcing is that film won't be available after this year.  We need to convert all now. We still have several days left and are still hoping to reach our goal, or get close to it. That said, crowdsourcing is never a guaranteed success. We knew that going into this and we do have a backup plan. If we do not raise the full amount by the 30th, we will do other various fundraising events to close the gap. The business is solid - we aren't raising money to keep the business afloat because we made poor business decisions - we're raising money to buy projectors we didn't know we'd need when we opened 7 years ago. The money raised is ONLY going to projectors - not to paying our bills. We've promoted the heck out of this thing online and in the media and we are hoping donations will continue to come in between now and the end of the campaign.   Thank you to everyone who has supported us!  We are blown away by the support and we hope in these last four days, we can keep the momentum and get to our goal! Thanks, Julie
 
 
 
Overview

Seven years ago, we preserved an important piece of Portland’s cinematic history and helped transform an entire neighborhood in the process.
Now we’re at a crossroads, and we need your help. Simply put, without your financial support, rather than preserving history, we may become history.
Here’s the scoop: For close to a century, the words movie and film have been interchangeable. Soon this won’t be the case. By year’s end, all new Hollywood releases will only be screened digitally, rendering 35mm projection equipment obsolete. 
If the Academy Theater wants to avoid the fate of those who believed “talkies” were simply a fad, we must convert from film to digital equipment as soon as possible. But that's not as easy as it sounds.
 
DIGITAL CONVERSION: Frequently Asked Questions  http://www.academytheaterpdx.com/digital-conversion-fundraising/


 
What We Need & What You Get
Unfortunately, new equipment is incredibly expensive. Upgrading to digital projectors in all three theaters will cost approximately $96,000. Installation costs and necessary sound system upgrades will require an additional $21,000. As you can imagine, this is an enormous financial burden for a small independent theater.
Our (admittedly) ambitious goal is to raise $75,000 (or more!) by September 30, 2013. This amount will help cover the total cost of three new digital projectors, sound system upgrades, installation charges and Indiegogo processing fees. You can help us reach this goal by making a donation today. 
In exchange for your contribution, we will reward you with one of the many fabulous incentives listed on the right hand side of this page. 
Any amount, however small, helps push us closer to our goal. 
Assuming we reach this goal, digital conversion will happen immediately (although installation of new equipment may take several days.) And once new projectors are installed, our movies will look and sound better than ever!
 


The Impact
When we decided to restore the Academy, our goal was simple. We wanted to create a friendly neighborhood venue where families looking for a fun night out wouldn’t blow an entire paycheck buying popcorn, soda and a few movie tickets. For the past seven years we’ve sustained that goal by offering our patrons affordable entertainment, food and childcare in a beautiful 1940s setting. And the Montavilla neighborhood has thrived as a result.
We love our community, we love our theater, and we love how our theater has enriched the surrounding neighborhood in ways we never could have predicted. We know that you - the 2000+ patrons who visit the Academy each week - feel the same way. That is why we are hoping that -- with your help – we can continue to be a vital part of the Montavilla neighborhood for many years to come.
 


Other Ways You Can Help
Even if you can’t contribute financially, please know that you can help by simply spreading the word! Just share this page with family, friends and colleagues -- or post it to Facebook and Twitter -- and encourage others to do the same. Our fundraising campaign can only be as successful as we are in spreading the word about it. 
In closing, we’d like to thank you, both for your patronage over the past seven years and for taking time to learn about our fundraising campaign. If there’s one message we hope you take away from our campaign, it’s this: 
 
Without your support, we’d be history!
 
About The Academy: Originally launched in 1948, the Academy Theater was a popular Southeast Portland destination until its closure in the 1970s. Three decades of neglect took their toll, but a full-scale renovation was completed in 2006. Great attention was paid to every detail of the project. Using vintage photos of the theater’s first incarnation, the glittering rounded lobby and signature marquee were restored to perfection, imbuing the building with authentic 1940s charm. For more information, please visit our web site at www.academytheaterpdx.com.

story:
Short Summary

I grew up in a smaller town in Oklahoma.  I started dancing when I was 6, graduated from the University of Oklahoma with a B.S. in Health and Sport Sciences, and have been tap dancing professionally in Chicago for the last 13 years.  In 2008, I started Dance Profusion Project - an annual weekend of master classes and workshops for dancers in Oklahoma with professional dancers from Chicago.

Dance Profusion Project was founded in 2008 to create cultural impact in Oklahoma by:  

          -   providing quality dance education through master classes and workshops with Chicago-based professional dancers and Directors.

          -  creating career path opportunities in Chicago for Oklahoma dancers.

          -  being an additional resource to increase dance awareness and education in Oklahoma.

          -  reaching dancers who do not have the opportunity to seek continuing education outside of Oklahoma.

This year marks the 6th year of DPP, and the 2nd year of self-producing a dance concert. Contributing to this project will allow DPP to bring at least 2 of Chicago's best tap and rhythmic dance companies to Oklahoma for a performance on October 12th:  Be the Groove, The Cartier Collective, and more!  The performance will also include students from the Tulsa area.  Chicago tap and rhythmic dance companies + 1 night in Tulsa = crazy fun. If you like dance, you'll love this show!  If you don't like dance, you'll love this show.  And that’s all there is to it. Enough said.

This project is important to me because it means I get to share what I do with the folks back home, and I get to provide opportunities for dancers in Oklahoma that I never had growing up.  As a performer, I get to ignite the imaginations of children and adults, help cultivate arts audiences in Oklahoma and help nurture future artists. That's pretty cool. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down! (Did you hear MC Hammer in your head when you just read that?  Did I just date myself with that question?  Yes, yes, I did.)

DPP needs over $10,000 to produce this show.  You know, money for the dancers and technical crew  - yeah, they like to get paid.  And, oh yeah, we have to pay for a space to actually perform in.  Living rooms may have been cool when we were little, but we're talking about some big kid stuff now.

People (like you) who donate to this campaign get cool things like: tickets, autographed posters, time with the performers, etc.  So, why wouldn't you donate?

 

The Impact

Performances always have the opportunity to create ignition moments for the audience members - the possibility of impact with this show will go beyond that theater seat. In addition to creating a life-long appreciation for the arts, it can also create respect and tolerance towards other art forms and cultures. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that's ok!  There are other ways you can help:

          -  Send this to your friends!

          -  Volunteer the night of the show.

story:
Our Story

 Sick Little Productions is in production for its new show  Awkward Levity and we need your help.  SLP is dedicated to bringing you twisted tales sometimes using puppets and sometimes people. This is a people show. In January we open in New York's finest basement theater, Under St. Marks Theater, for six performances of a three short dark comedies.  We open on January 12 and close on January 21.  These new plays will make you want to shower when they're over. We hope to see you all there!  


What We Need

All of us at Sick Little Productions have other jobs that actually pay the bills but we love spending our free time pulling these show together however we don't have money to pay the artists for their time.  That's where you come in.  This campaign is strictly to pay the actors and directors for all the hard work they have and will put in over the next month.  These artists volunteer their time sometimes late into the night and sometimes missing work for the production. We want to pay for transportation and give everyone a stipend that will make a little difference in their bottom line that month.  Shhh...they don't even know we're doing this. 

What You Get

You will get creepy hugs from the entire cast.  You will also rest easy that you have helped the cast and directors pay for their overpriced New York City apartments.  We also have some great perks for you including handmade finger puppets so you can create your own finger puppet theater project! 

The Impact

I think it's safe to say that most of us are struggling these days.  The budgets for our productions come from what we the producers can set aside from our paychecks.  We don't expect to get all of our money back and we don't care!  We do, however, care about the dedicated cast and crew of our shows and we want them to all get a little something that says to them that the world cares about their hard work. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word on any and all appropriate social media outlets!  If you are bold enough and have a t-shirt to spare take a marker and make a cool tee with our show's name on it and walk around the East Village with nothing else on. Okay maybe some shoes...but nothing else.

story:
FIREBIRD RISING - Workshop and Showcase!
Bringing an epic adventure to the stage, Firebird Rising is a high-octane Stravinsky musical mashup with new original Beats where spectacular Theater, awe inspiring Aerial, Ballet, Acrobatics and Circus takes us on a mythic journey of transformation. An amazing team of diverse Artists are coming together to collaborate on this beautiful show. The narrative leads us on a passionate drama where greed and desire collide in a volatile battle with nature and unconditional love overcomes all. We need your support to bring this story to life, with your generous contributions we will rise up from the ashes and take flight!

We are excited to kick off the creation of this fantastic show in Los Angeles, California. We are prepped and ready to hire our dancers and circus performers, lay out the choreography, develop the characters, rent equipment, rehearsal space, make costumes, build giant puppets and get Insurance for the safety of all of our performers. This process will allow us to develop elements of the show as we build and grow towards the full production. Following the rehearsals we will present our work in progress at the El Portal Theatre on May 31st, June 1st and 2nd, as part of the Luminario Ballet Season 4. This showcase will allow us to perform, get feedback, build an audience and gain interest. We need to raise $25,000 to cover these costs, with your generous contributions we can make all of this happen. Please join us and be part of the Firebird Rising Community and bring this story to life.
Thank You!

Backstory
For thousands of years the Firebird myth, folklore and symbol have continued to be part of global culture, passed along from generation to generation. Today the Firebird Rises again to bring a message of hope and rebirth.

About The Firebird Rising Team:
We are an exciting group of artist collaborating on this epic myth. Many of us have created and worked together before and our team keeps growing.
Please check us out!
For more information go to: http://www.firebirdrisingshow.com/

Also go to our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/thefirebirdrising?ref=hl

 

Artistic Director & Producer - Stephen Hues is a Director, Choreographer and Performer fascinated by world mythologies. www.stephenhues.com   or https://www.facebook.com/stephen.hues

Composer - Martin St-Pierre continues to be recognized as a front man for composing and improvised violin in the World Music, Rock, Classical and Heavy Metal communities. http://martinst-pierre.com/

Composer - Alex King-Harris aka Rara Avis is a dedicated master of his craft with over 20 years experience in live performance and music production with a core focus on where the electronic underground, yoga and dance movements collide. http://www.yogi-tunes.com/

Writer & Co-Producer - Susan McIntosh graduated from the University of California at Berkeley with a major in English, then attended Columbia University’s and received her MFA degree in film. Most recently, her original series Tribe, was optioned by Stardust Visions and is currently being shopped by Evolution Entertainment. Last summer, Susan opened for Andy Dick during his residency at the Bar Fedora, downtown, Los Angeles. 

Ballet and Aerial Choreographer & Co-Producer - Judith Flex Helle is the Artistic and Managing Director of Luminario Ballet of Los Angeles. They have performed 3 successful full length repertory show seasons in LA, North Hollywood, Orange County, and Long Beach, as well as numerous guest appearances. http://www.luminarioballet.org/

Set Projections Designer - Yo Suzuki is the Artistic Director of LOVEMUSHROOM, a world renowned Los Angeles based visual design studio creating and performing live image mixing for the music industry, clubs, concerts and outdoor gatherings, as well as museums, live theater and the film industry since 1999. http://www.lovemushroom.com/

Body Mapping - Paul Ackerman is a degreed avant garde artist specializing in body mapping with backgrounds in graphic design + 2/3D Illustration + animation + video pre/post production + dance theater + lasers + multi-media + motion graphics + sculpture + painting and photography.  http://facebook.com/dansebleue

Stilt Choreographer - Starchild is the Artistic Director of Stilt Circus, a collective of highly skilled Stilt and Circus performers bringing spectacular entertainment from up high! Starchild entered the circus world at the turn of the Century when she left the music industry of 9 years, to manage a Seattle based fire performance troupe, MagmaVOX, soon after she became a performer herself. http://www.stiltcircus.com/Stilt_Circus/Welcome.html

Costume Designer: Adele Satori draws inspiration for her designs from diverse areas such as nature, anime, military styling, eras gone by and the underground cirque movement. https://www.facebook.com/pages/Atelier-Satori/87580022862

Production Design-Puppets, Daphne Vega, with a BFA in Painting and Ceramics, has pursued a career in fine and commercial art and currently owns and operates a community arts center in Los Angeles with her partner Yoni Koenig. Her recent exploration in stage design and puppetry is a direct extension of her life long passion for creating 2D/3D design.www.syruploft.com

Singer, Kate St-Pierre was the original singer for Le Reve and featured as such on the soundtrack, performed for Cirque du Soleil in Ka, and has performed all over world singing her trademark throaty belts and ethnic styles. Kate often records for legendary film trailer composer Thomas J. Bergersen of Two Steps From Hell Productions. Kate enjoys working with her husband composer Martin St-Pierre and singing with their 2 daughters.

Production Design-Graphics and Branding, Yoni Koenig specializes in bridging the gap between user experience, technology and business with over 20 years delivering successful interactive media content to the market place. http://www.yonikoenig.com/

Project Manager & Co-Producer - Chico B. is currently a Project Manager/Business Analyst in a financial firm based in Los Angeles. He is also an independent Business Strategic consultant for various production companies by day and a fire dancer by night.

Financial Adviser & Co-Producer - Linus Sora has over 15 years of experience in project management, economic feasibility, and entertainment development. He brings forth a wide variety of talents to the Firdbird Rising project. Starting with an educational background in economics as well as film school, his early career began developing layouts for the science-fiction genre magazine Cinefantastique. His extensive experience includes freelance work as an Assistant Director for independent films, as well as financial analysis for the business operations.

El Portal Theatre - Check out the beautiful theater main stage, where we will be presenting our work in progress May 31st, June 1st and June 2nd, 2013. http://www.elportaltheatre.com/mainstage.html

What have we done so far?
We have been researching the history, folklore and mythology, writing the story, exploring character movement while developing the vision of the Firebird Rising Experience. We have a Website, Facebook page, business presentation, Phase 1 budget and we are developing the full production budget.

Now, all we need is your generous support to make this beautiful project a reality.

Steps to get to the Full Production:
The launching of the show has been divided into 3 phases.

We are in Phase 1 which will allow us to start building the show through a creative workshop which brings a team of experienced artist together to collaborate on the creation of the Firebird Rising show. We will explore the various elements of the show, rehearse and present our work in progress at the El Portal Theatre. Along the way we will build our audience and get feedback, also the creation process and performances will be documented to produce the Firebird Rising Promo DVD and other materials for our PR and Investor package. Your financial support is to cover the cost of Phase 1..

Phase 2: We will continue building the show to fine tune all the elements, expand our audience, gain more interest and follow up with our contacts. We will create the PR and investor package and present excerpts to audiences and investors.

Phase 3: The execution of the full FIREBIRD RISING Experience, which includes the Firebird Rising show; bringing an epic adventure to the stage, a high-octane Stravinsky musical mashup with new original Beats, where spectacular Theater, wild Circus, awe inspiring Aerial, Ballet and Acrobatics takes us on a mythic journey of transformation. The narrative leads us on a passionate drama where greed and desire collide in a volatile battle with nature and unconditional love overcomes all.

It takes a whole community to make this happen and with your support we can bring this story to life. Your contributions will make it possible.l

Where will the money go:
The money will allow us to hire professional dancers, aerialists, stilt walkers and acrobats, pay for insurance, rent space and equipment for rehearsals, buy materials and create: costumes, props, puppets, new music and video images. It will also help pay for our showcase with the Luminario Ballet at the El Portal Theatre in North Hollywood, CA on May 31st, June 1st and 2nd, 2013.

Please support our efforts to bring this Mythical story to life and receive some of our homemade, really cool Perks!! You can pledge any amount and choose your perk. See the listing of Perks!! and pictures in Gallery Tab above.

If we exceed our goal then the extra funds will be used to make FIREBIRD RISING even better. YAY!!!

Thank You!!!

Risk and challenges:
We have formed a team of experienced artists and business professionals to handle the various aspects of the show. We have a project manager and a financial advisor to keep track of the process, expenses and to minimize the impact of any issue that may arise. No projects are done without risks and challenges. We conduct meetings and maintain a close communication as we move forward.

Please Contact us at:
FirebirdRisingShow@gmail.com
We check it and will get back to you!

Other ways to help:
Spread the word and make some noise, please tell everyone you know about FIREBIRD RISING!

http://www.firebirdrisingshow.com/

Like us on Facebook:  http://www.facebook.com/thefirebirdrising

Blog, Twitter and promote the Firebird Rising any way you can think of.


Everything helps!

Thank You!!!
Many Blessings,
Stephen Hues & The Entire Firebird Rising Team

“If art doesn't make us better, then what on earth is it for.”          Alice Walker.

Stilt Choreographer - Starchild is the Artistic Director of Stilt Circus, a collective of highly skilled Stilt and Circus performers bringing spectacular entertainment from up high! Starchild entered the circus world at the turn of the Century when she left the music industry of 9 years, to manage a Seattle based fire performance troupe, MagmaVOX, soon after she became a performer herself. http://www.stiltcircus.com/Stilt_Circus/Welcome.html
Costume Designer: Adele Satori draws inspiration for her designs from diverse areas such as nature, anime, military styling, eras gone by and the underground cirque movement. https://www.facebook.com/pages/Atelier-Satori/87580022862
Production Design-Puppets, Daphne Vega, with a BFA in Painting and Ceramics, has pursued a career in fine and commercial art and currently owns and operates a community arts center in Los Angeles with her partner Yoni Koenig. Her recent exploration in stage design and puppetry is a direct extension of her life long passion for creating 2D/3D design.www.syruploft.com
Singer, Kate St-Pierre was the original singer for Le Reve and featured as such on the soundtrack, performed for Cirque du Soleil in Ka, and has performed all over world singing her trademark throaty belts and ethnic styles. Kate often records for legendary film trailer composer Thomas J. Bergersen of Two Steps From Hell Productions. Kate enjoys working with her husband composer Martin St-Pierre and singing with their 2 daughters.
Production Design-Graphics and Branding, Yoni Koenig specializes in bridging the gap between user experience, technology and business with over 20 years delivering successful interactive media content to the market place. http://www.yonikoenig.com/
Project Manager & Co-Producer - Chico B. is currently a Project Manager/Business Analyst in a financial firm based in Los Angeles. He is also an independent Business Strategic consultant for various production companies by day and a fire dancer by night.
Financial Adviser & Co-Producer - Linus Sora has over 15 years of experience in project management, economic feasibility, and entertainment development. He brings forth a wide variety of talents to the Firdbird Rising project. Starting with an educational background in economics as well as film school, his early career began developing layouts for the science-fiction genre magazine Cinefantastique. His extensive experience includes freelance work as an Assistant Director for independent films, as well as financial analysis for the business operations.El Portal Theatre - Check out the beautiful theater main stage, where we will be presenting our work in progress May 31st, June 1st and June 2nd, 2013. http://www.elportaltheatre.com/mainstage.htmlWhat have we done so far?We have been researching the history, folklore and mythology, writing the story, exploring character movement while developing the vision of the Firebird Rising Experience. We have a Website, Facebook page, business presentation, Phase 1 budget and we are developing the full production budget.Now, all we need is your generous support to make this beautiful project a reality.Steps to get to the Full Production:The launching of the show has been divided into 3 phases. We are in Phase 1 which will allow us to start building the show through a creative workshop which brings a team of experienced artist together to collaborate on the creation of the Firebird Rising show. We will explore the various elements of the show, rehearse and present our work in progress at the El Portal Theatre. Along the way we will build our audience and get feedback, also the creation process and performances will be documented to produce the Firebird Rising Promo DVD and other materials for our PR and Investor package. Your financial support is to cover the cost of Phase 1..Phase 2: We will continue building the show to fine tune all the elements, expand our audience, gain more interest and follow up with our contacts. We will create the PR and investor package and present excerpts to audiences and investors.Phase 3: The execution of the full FIREBIRD RISING Experience, which includes the Firebird Rising show; bringing an epic adventure to the stage, a high-octane Stravinsky musical mashup with new original Beats, where spectacular Theater, wild Circus, awe inspiring Aerial, Ballet and Acrobatics takes us on a mythic journey of transformation. The narrative leads us on a passionate drama where greed and desire collide in a volatile battle with nature and unconditional love overcomes all. It takes a whole community to make this happen and with your support we can bring this story to life. Your contributions will make it possible.lWhere will the money go:The money will allow us to hire professional dancers, aerialists, stilt walkers and acrobats, pay for insurance, rent space and equipment for rehearsals, buy materials and create: costumes, props, puppets, new music and video images. It will also help pay for our showcase with the Luminario Ballet at the El Portal Theatre in North Hollywood, CA on May 31st, June 1st and 2nd, 2013.Please support our efforts to bring this Mythical story to life and receive some of our homemade, really cool Perks!! You can pledge any amount and choose your perk. See the listing of Perks!! and pictures in Gallery Tab above.
If we exceed our goal then the extra funds will be used to make FIREBIRD RISING even better. YAY!!!Thank You!!!Risk and challenges:We have formed a team of experienced artists and business professionals to handle the various aspects of the show. We have a project manager and a financial advisor to keep track of the process, expenses and to minimize the impact of any issue that may arise. No projects are done without risks and challenges. We conduct meetings and maintain a close communication as we move forward.Please Contact us at:FirebirdRisingShow@gmail.comWe check it and will get back to you!Other ways to help: Spread the word and make some noise, please tell everyone you know about FIREBIRD RISING! 
 http://www.firebirdrisingshow.com/
Like us on Facebook:  http://www.facebook.com/thefirebirdrising
Blog, Twitter and promote the Firebird Rising any way you can think of. 
Everything helps!Thank You!!!Many Blessings,Stephen Hues & The Entire Firebird Rising Team“If art doesn't make us better, then what on earth is it for.”          Alice Walker.

story:
Overview

I am a UChicago student who will be directing Stephen Dolginoff's acclaimed musical Thrill Me: The Leopold & Loeb Story for Classical Entertainment Society's winter quarter play festival. Unfortunately, the rights to the show cost over $600, six times my entire budget of $100 (which includes my budget for props, set, and costumes in addition to the rights). We are unaffiliated with University Theater or TAPS and cannot receive funding from them. As Leopold and Loeb were UChicago students, there is no better place to put on the musical than here, so please help me bring this musical to a UChicago stage!

Thrill Me: The Leopold and Loeb Story

The musical explores the relationship between 1920's teenage thrill killers Nathan Leopold and Richard Loeb, two friends, lovers, and University of Chicago law students who wished to commit the perfect murder. They were brilliant, precocious, and isolated from their peers, and they had found each other. To demonstrate their intellectual superiority, Richard wanted to commit a perfect murder; as Nathan was madly in love with him, he agreed to be his accomplice in exchange for sexual favors. Together, they murdered Bobby Franks in what was known as the crime of the century.

How to Help

If I don't reach my goal amount, you will not be charged, and I will not receive any of the money. I would really appreciate donations of any amount, and even if you can't donate, please help me spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, etc. Thank you!

story:
The Story

This book campaign “Between Darkness and Light” represents “Phase One” of Shaun Singh Productions, Inc.'s fundraising efforts.  It is part of our long-term plan in the reprisal of the production: “RANG: Shades of My Soul” (Tentatively  scheduled for 2016 Off-Broadway).


The Book

“Between Darkness and Light” is Shaun Singh’s book of personal photography and writings while on the island of Puerto Rico. This revealing and uplifting work will take you on one man’s journey through the healing process after divorce.

The concept for the book, “Between Darkness and Light” is also inspired by the numerous requests of Shaun’s Facebook and Instagram followers for his photographs, the story behind his encouraging and inspiring posts and his next production. As a child, Shaun witnessed the abuse of his mother and the abuse of other women close to him. He is also a survivor of abuse. The real message is that beauty can emerge from the darkness of life. 


The Impact

 “Between Darkness and Light” is Shaun’s attempt to creatively and artistically connect the dots of the long-term effects of his abuse and his life decisions as an adult.  He hopes that by sharing his experiences it will help connect the dots for other survivors of abuse.

Shaun’s motivation also continues to be the larger picture of making his production of “Rang: Shades of My Soul” a reality.

We cannot do this without your donation, it's the only way we will be able to make a true impact. 


What we need & what you get

Phase One’s estimated budget is $25,000, which includes the creation and production of the book and Indiegogo.com fees. In the event the actual expenses are lower or we exceed our financial goal, all funds will go towards the upcoming Off-Broadway production of “Rang: Shade of My Soul.”

·  Book production: $22,000

·  Indiegogo.com fees: 4% or 9% depending on reaching our fundraising goals.

By collaborating with us, you can be assured in that you are a part of a movement that is making a difference. Your dollars will bring us one step closer to producing an amazing dance piece that is both entertaining and educational at the same time, as creating awareness of abuse (physical, emotional and mental) is key. By investing in our project, you are investing in a VIOLENCE FREE FUTURE for our young people. In return, we have designed some packages so that as a supporter, you are included in this truly meaningful project.

Perk options (see perks gallery) range from a personalized thank you email to a chance for you to present the entire publication. We are also prepared to present the exclusive opportunity of becoming an Associate Producer on our upcoming Off-Broadway production.


Other ways you can make a difference

We believe that “Rang: The Dance Movement for Change... can indeed be the vehicle for change" and if you are reading this, you are already a part of this change.

Your financial help is necessary and we also understand that not everyone can contribute financially; however, you can still help by spreading the word. You can do your part by sharing our campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, your blog, and/or website. In addition, if you have any access to media outlets: Writers, Editors, Bloggers, TV, & etc., please refer us.  We need all the help possible to make an impact!

Thank You!
Shaun Singh

story:
In 2012, we noticed something wrong on Twitter. A cult, known as "Directioners", often tweeted to Harry Styles about their dead cats. We wanted to know why. Through extensive research, we found out there was more to it than dead cats. Dead dogs. Dead grandmas. Scary cacti. We took this research and presented it at the Edinburgh Fringe in 2013 to three sell-out audiences. After this, the documentation was taken on the road and shared to sell-out audiences in London, Newcastle and Manchester. 

Since then, we've only come across worse.

We want to present our new findings. Costumes, Twitter Wars, Fandom, drawings, more pictures of dead pets, and a conclusion so shocking: there is a group of people worse than the One Direction fandom.

We'd like to present our new show, Harry, My Cat Died 2: WHY AREN'T YOU FOLLOWING ME YET I HATE YOU I LOVE YOU PLEASE DON'T DIE <3 x1734 to you. Last time, we did a flexible funding campaign: every £80 raised, another City would be added to the tour. We ended up raising enough to take the show to ten cities. And we'd very much like to take this rand new show on the road too. With guests, chat, audience interaction and a few twists along the way. This is Harry, My Cat Died 2. And it needs to be seen.

We'd like to make it a Summer Tour. Starting in June and ending in August. Over these three months, we'd love to visit at least 10-12 cities. But the basic plan is, for every £80 raised, we take the show to another city within the UK. That covers travel, we'll worry about our own venue hire and hotel rooms. If you donate, make sure you tell us which city is nearest to you, and we'll put it on a massive chart or something.

Harry, My Cat Died 2: WHY AREN'T YOU FOLLOWING ME YET I HATE YOU I LOVE YOU PLEASE DON'T DIE <3 x1734 . Coming Summer 2014.

Harry, My Cat Died is a Twitter project ran by Stephen Frizzle. The tour has been reviews in NARC, The Sun and Gigglebeats. He has also provided articles about the project for PopBitch and ITN.

story:
Numinous Flux is a contemporary dance company based out of Nashville, TN. The vision of our shows as well as our work offstage is to enable individuals to live more beautiful stories and to discover their purpose.


We believe that dance is a powerful vehicle that can draw up a personal awakening in the human soul. 

Our dancers, directors, and board donate all of their talents and time as volunteers to invest in the lives that surround us, we don't keep a cent.  The funds we raise by ticket sales at each show go directly into our cause for the particular show. This campaign's purpose is to raise the initial funding we need to bring our shows to light. Your contributions will go towards initial production costs, advertising, merchandise, and the remainder will be donated to our cause. 

The first showing of "Illustrated" on August 23, 2014 will scholarship a child's full dance tuition for one year. The dance student will then be mentored in writing an anonymous blog for the duration of the scholarship about dance and its impact and influence in their life. The link to the blog will be posted on our website so you can share in their joy .

 Be moved. Become an ambassador of love. YOU can help! We greatly appreciate and admire your support.

story:
TREASURES FROM THE VAULT was born of the desire to build a culture of sustainable dance. The lifecycle of dance is unforgivingly short, especially for small companies and independent choreographers. After months or years of work in the studio, we perform once or twice, over one weekend (two if we’re lucky), and then it’s over. This state of affairs means that dance work is often not given a chance to fully develop or to find its audience.

We are two dancemakers based in Brooklyn, New York, who have been collaborating for three years. That collaboration is about to enter a new phase as Tiana moves to Amsterdam for school. We have made a number of dances together over the years, and we decided to proactively create our own platform to perform them one more time. We want to make this opportunity available to other performing artists who, like ourselves, would appreciate and benefit from a platform for their lost works. What happens both to the work and ourselves as we dig back into work with a new perspective? What do you learn about yourself in returning to an old work from a new place? How are we changed by addressing now, work that we made when we were not yet this version of ourselves? How is the work informed by our distance from it and our experience?

We have curated a very exciting evening, featuring the work of Lillie De, Ashley Handel, Kinetic Architecture, Mari Meade Dance Collective, and Jon Zelasko. The show will be Sunday, July 15, 2012, at Triskelion Arts in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. More details here: https://www.facebook.com/events/255276527915170/ Tickets available here: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/258142

IMPACT OF SUPPORT: If you help fund this project, you will be supporting independent artists in New York and a new model of presenting performance work.

The first $500 we raise from this indigogo goes to covering basic production costs. After that goal is reached, every cent goes to paying the amazing creative artists who are sharing their time and work with us.

We are hosting a huge benefit creepy costume party on Friday July 13th as another source of funding for this project. The party will include, live stand up comedy, costume contest, burlesque, live music, DJ’s, The People Watch Project and some unseen work from a new piece that is in the making. DECA, an amazing new event space located at 110 Troutman St. in Bushwick, is generously allowing us to use their space for the evening. Come dressed as your favorite freak and join us at our new favorite haunt. Hope to see you there!

story:
Hi guys,

Following our successful run during March in Manchester, the Dying City Team (Hugo, Hannah and Nick) are taking the show to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival 2014! We are incredibly excited to bring our beloved show to audiences at the Fringe this year but we need your help!

We feel immensely privileged to be able to produce the show, it's a show we think audiences really engage with around a topic which is extremely relevant to the contemporary period, and in case you didn't get a chance to catch it in Manchester here's a cryptic taster:

''When one man goes to war he leaves the city, his wife, and brother. A year later only the wife and brother remain.  

In "Dying City" Christopher Shinn asks what happens when people and events apparently thousands of miles away affect the heart and soul of a city''

We're performing at 'The Space @ Surgeon's Hall Theatre 2' for six performances from the 4th August till the 9th so we hope those who are making the trip up to Edinburgh will be able to catch it!

We're asking for donations to cover the costs involved in taking a production to Edinburgh, this includes venue hire, registration fees and marketing. All your donations, big or small, will be greatly appreciated and make us burst with joy and love and happiness (amongst other nice emotions)!!!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this,

Hugo, Hannah and Nick (Dying City 2014) xxxx

 

Risks and Challenges:

Firstly: performing this complex and emotional piece at 10 o'clock every morning.....yes there are American accents involved. However, having performed the piece before, we feel confident that we can overcome any fatigue!

The main challenges we face are to generate interest/audiences at the incredibly vast festival. We have some exciting publicity ideas coming your way for flyering on the Royal Mile - we will keep our supporters updated with the success of these methods!

Other challenges include Hugo taking on not only the role of the director, but being our lighting at sound man! For those of you who know him personally, we have no doubt of his ability to succeed in these areas. He has also taken part in a one-on-one workshop with lighting and sound extraordinare Mr Dan Power for advise and support.

And of course, another main challenge is funding the entire project ourselves but hopefully you guys can help us slightly with that?!


Other ways you can help out:

Come and see the show in Edinburgh!
