story:
Update: (4/17/14)  My goal has been reduced in half due to Satori having purchased herself an aerial hoop with her tax return this year. Yay Satori!  Thank you to everyone who has donated so far, it is very much appreciated. -Sacha

Satori Spins! 

Satori has been passionately pursuing her love of performance, and more specifically hoop dancing, for the past two and a half years.  Recently Satori has experienced some set backs that will keep her from performing at upcoming shows with her performance group.  Treasured equipment has broken and so needs to be replaced along with other equipment that has needed to be purchased for a while. 


What does Satori need?


  • Future Hoop Pro  


    (Satori no longer needs an aerial hoop as she bought herself one with her tax return that I was unaware of, so our goal is effectively cut in half! update: 4/17/14)

  • Aerial hoop with hook ups

  • Any funds raised will go towards purchase of this equipment.

Inspiration!

I have heard from people numerous times how inspired they have been watching Satori perform.  She has lead many other people into the joy of hula hooping and hoop dancing.  Help her to continue to inspire other youth in this endeavor.

Other Ways You Can Help

You want to help but are unable to contribute?  Visit https://www.facebook.com/SatoriSpins# and like her performance page. Tell your friends about Satori and have them like her page.
story_txt:
Update: (4/17/14)  My goal has been reduced in half due to Satori having purchased herself an aerial hoop with her tax return this year. Yay Satori!  Thank you to everyone who has donated so far, it is very much appreciated. -SachaSatori Spins!  Satori has been passionately pursuing her love of performance, and more specifically hoop dancing, for the past two and a half years.  Recently Satori has experienced some set backs that will keep her from performing at upcoming shows with her performance group.  Treasured equipment has broken and so needs to be replaced along with other equipment that has needed to be purchased for a while.  What does Satori need?
Future Hoop Pro   
(Satori no longer needs an aerial hoop as she bought herself one with her tax return that I was unaware of, so our goal is effectively cut in half! update: 4/17/14)

Aerial hoop with hook ups





Any funds raised will go towards purchase of this equipment.

story:
Our Story


Theatre of NOTE will kick off its 30th season with the world premiere of B. Walker Sampson's Alceste, a magical re-telling of Euripides' Alcestis. We have a wonderful cast and design team in place. Please support this beautiful show and become a part of Team Alceste.


A free adaptation from Euripides, Alceste pits together gods, ghosts, and superheroes with ordinary so-and-sos who make extraordinary sacrifices to try to tell the Future to consider itself. Objects are too brightly colored to see without squinting, while others remind us of people we're trying to forget. Boats and bathtubs roll in to where they have no business, and there's a terrible hissing that sounds like the end of things.

(The shadowy so-and-sos cock their rifles.)
"Aha. I see you've all cocked. Let me fill you in about the bullets. My heart has a steel orb
circling it. My tummy: encased with iron. My skull and everything in it has been forged
with solid gold, dripped into my head by giants who work in the earth's fiery core. And
just in case you aim low, I wear a chastity belt—just for combat—that has a big ol'
combination lock, strategically placed. Welded by some metal they discovered on Mars.
So fire away, boys."


Cast, Crew, and Supporters include:

Lorianne Hill, Trevor Olsen, Julia Prud'homme, Ezra Buzzington, Esther Williams Kalbfleisch, Jennifer Flack, Lynn Odell, Cat Davis, Jamie Silberhartz, Justin Alston, Wendi West, Bebe Herrera, Ryan Brodkin, Mike Roman, Takashi Morimoto, Naomi Kasahara, Jennings Turner, Andy Rohr, Darin Dahms, David Bickford, Rick Steadman, Lauren Dobbins Webb, and YOU!


Theatre of NOTE is a non-profit democratic company that stagedives the arena of the theater arts. Founded in 1981, our ensemble-based organization is dedicated to providing a creative environment in which to collaborate on and develop maverick theater.


NOTE produces an average of four mainstage shows a year, with a focus on world, West Coast, California and Los Angeles premieres (world premiere adaptation of Bertolt Brecht's The Duchess of Malfi ; Los Angeles premiere of Tony Kushner's A Bright Room Called Day ). NOTE also produces the famous annual Hollywood Performance Marathon, late night original 5-Minute One-Act Play Series, the NOTEworthy new play development workshops, and our educational outreach program The Young Writers Project.


NOTE has earned consistent commendation from the Los Angeles press and national acclaim from such publications as American Theatre magazine, as well as dozens of accolades, nominations and honors from every award-granting theater alliance in Southern California.


The Impact

We at Theatre of NOTE are an enduring ensemble of diverse theatre artists in the heart of
Hollywood who inspire, inform, and ignite our audiences by discovering courageous voices and creating entertaining, provocative, and revelatory theatrical works.


Theatre of NOTE stands for an ability and willingness to take artististic risks. We find a strong sense of communal self in our generosity, integrity, respect, diversity, and the democracy of our organization. We choose plays that illuminate universal truths of emotional honesty, passion, and humanity through theatrical extremes, and Alceste demonstrates that through a beautiful and moving story about love, loss, and everything in between.


What We Need & What You Get

Through generous donations and other successful fundraisers, we are very close to meeting our fundraising goal for the production of Alceste. Please make a contribution so that we can be sure to give this world premiere play the production it deserves. No donation is too small. Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)3 non-profit, so all donations are tax-deductible.


A donation to Alceste will get you thanks in our program, in our lobby display, and a chance to be a part of theatre history!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please use the IndieGoGo share tools or email, facebook, twitter, and/or messenger pigeon to spread the word about donating to Alceste. And please come see the show you are a part of - Alceste opens February 4th, 2011!

story:
About:

CoreDance Contemporary is an Emerging Australian Based Modern Dance Company residing in New York City and looking for an opportunity to put itself on the Map.  Founded by Artistic Director Rebecca McCormac on the 14th of March, 2011, the company is comprised of seven female dance artists who bring different cultural and dance backgrounds to the fore, to form a hardworking and dedicated ensemble.CoreDances' objective is to investigate choreographically, different and oft times contradictory movement vocabulary through the physicality of one’s kinetics and to explore the realization of this physicality as it takes form in the space. Ms McCormac has an interdisciplinary approach to her work drawing ideas both contextually and visually to create work that is engaging for herself and her audience.CoreDance has previously presented work at:  Chelsea Studios, JT Lotus Choreographic Showcase, Fertile Ground at Green Space, Wax Works, Steps Performance Lab Series, Green Space Blooms Festival and NYC10.

Campaign:

The CoreDance in Performance Campaign is being launched to assist the company produce and present it's first Evening Length Work.  This venture is an important goal at this stage in the company's timeline as we are trying to make a name for ourselves in the ever competitive dance industry that is New York City.  Contributions will help pay for:

    • Studio Space Rental

    • Costume Design and Manufacture

    • Graphic Design and Printing for Marketing Purposes

    • Theatre Rental

    • Sound and Lighting Design

Goal:

Our goal is to raise $550.00 to help with production values.  If our goal is not reached the amount obtained will be used solely for Theatre Rental at Triskelion Arts in Brooklyn, NY.

Perks:

We are offering a Complimentary Ticket to our performance on July 7th to anyone who contributies $25.00.

We are providing an opportunity to observe CoreDance Contemporary in Rehearsal as well as a Complimentary Ticket to our performance on July 7th to anyone who contributes $50.00.

Any contribution is helpful, so even if you can't make one of monetary value we would just love it if you could spread the word and make some noise about our campaign. 

You can find us at www.facebook/CoreDanceContemporary and or use the Indiegogo Share Tools!

 

Thanks so much for showing your interest in our campaign.

 

Artistic Director:  Rebecca McCormac

Dance Artists:  Kate Bishop, Rose Buis, Sarah Campanelli, Martha Dobbs, Natalia Duong, Morgana Phlaum, Alexandra Shieron

story:
Studio Theatre at Theatre Row

410 West 42nd Street, NYC

July 31 - August 05, 2012


THE COMPANY

Black Moon Theatre Company nationally and internationally acclaimed style of performance and multimedia work that blend film and theatre have been hailed as a "text book example of how to blend live performance and film." (Kafka's The Metamorphosis - Scotsman Edinburgh International Fringe Festival" and "...flirts with aesthetic perfection..." (Backstage - Dante's Inferno).   In 2001, Black Moon incorporated as a non-profit in NYC in North Brooklyn where it immediately gained the support of the community. Productions include The Bakkhai by Euripides (2001), Madman and the Nun by Witkiewitcz (Community Performance 2002), The Metamorphosis by Kafka (2002-2006), Servant of Two Masters by Goldoni (Educational Outreach Program, 2001-Present), The Trial by Kafka (2006), Fragments (2009), Dante’s Divina Commedia-Inferno (2009-10), Oscar Wilde's Salome (2011), and The Maids by Jean Genet (2011). Black Moon Theatre Company’s Expressionism Realism performance style was developed over the years by Artistic Director René Migliaccio.  Constantly evolving, the style has been called “Brechtian” “visually stunning,” and “stark as it is beautiful”. Black Moon Theatre Company has achieved critical recognition in Germany, India, UK, Scotland, Czech Republic, Norway, and the USA.

THE PLAY

Charles Ponzi - A Dollar and a Scheme is a biographical play on the life of Italian born swindler Charles Ponzi (1882 - 1949), inventor of the notorious Ponzi Scheme*.
It starts in the year 1948, in a hospital in Rio de Janeiro, where Ponzi spent the end of his life in semi-blindness, confined to a wheel-chair and completely penniless. The play is a journey through the fascinating experiences Ponzi had from the day he decided to leave his native country for the U.S.A. to the time he achieved fame and prosperity at the expense of fifty thousand people, and was arrested as a result. Ponzi was a self-confident, charismatic and educated young man who came from a northern Italian middle class family. In 1920 he found a way to exploit the very rules of capitalism and rapidly emerged as one of the wealthiest capitalists in America. Investment frauds tied to the Ponzi scheme have become daily front-page news.

This play is an advocacy against the evils of capitalistic venture when in the hands of a-moral organizations and/or individuals; it exposes the mindset of a class of society that is geared towards profits without the regulating processes of law, decency and civil responsibility. Think subprime mortgage experiment (a Ponzi scheme) and the financial meltdown it created left in its trails: economic inequality, foreclosures, unemployment, loss of living standards, while corporate profits are soaring.

*A Ponzi scheme is a fraudulent investing scam that pays high rates of return to investors using the funds of subsequent investors. This operation is commonly described as "robbing Peter to pay Paul".

 THE PRODUCTION

A production directed by René Migliaccio, written and performed by Alessio Bordoni on Stage and on Film. Black and white film and theatre interact simultaneously, as all characters in Ponzi's life appear on film - projections and creations of his own fragmented psycho-social reality - and enter in a direct dialogue with Ponzi on the stage. The play starts on film, at the end of Ponzi's life, months before his death, and is constructed like a biographical story- telling - interspersed with newsreel, actual images from Ponzi's life and his surroundings - in which Ponzi looks back on his life and his accomplishments, which for him were incomparable in American history. Close up fills the screen, and theatre and film create an expressionistic dreamlike quality of the mnemonic environment.

YOUR CONTRIBUTIONS

This play is made possible in part by NYSCA (the National Council on the Arts) and the Lucky Star Foundation.

Your gift will help Black Moon Theatre Company create an production to be premiered at Theatre Row, New York, in July, 2012.

Your gift participation/donation is the driving force that will give voice and fulfill the vision of a theatre production that challenges the menace that is embedded in a system based on financial profit to the detriment of social and economic justice, and engages the mind to strive for a better world.

WHAT WE NEED

Every contribution is deeply appreciated and will make a difference. Every contribution is tax-deductible.

THANK YOU FOR HELPING US REALIZE OUR VISION.

A budget breakdown is available upon request.

Salaries - Artistic, Technical, Front of House: 15% 12 actors • Director • Designers (Set, Lighting, Costumes, Props) • Playwright  • Stage Manager • House Manager • Technical Director • Carpenter(s) • Light and Sound Board Operators • Running Crew

Performance Space • Rehearsal Space: 50%

Materials: 10% Set Materials • Costume Materials • Prop Materials

 Publicity: 25% Publicist • Photographer • Posters/ Flyers/ Postcard Design and Printing • Website Design and Maintenance.

 

 

 

 

 

.

story:
The Rage of the Stage Players are attempting to raise $7,000 to produce the world premiere of James Michael Shobergâ€™s latest stage adaptation, which will be a grim, violent twist on J. M. Barrieâ€™s novel, Peter and Wendy, set in a bleak, futuristic London. The piece, aptly entitled, Hooked, will take our audiences into an unsettling, grimy future, where societal decay has left London a ruined husk of the city it once was, overwrought with crime and drugs. When an injured young anti-hero, referring to himself only as "Pan," crosses paths with a young girl, Wendy Darling, she and her two brothers, Michael and John, are drawn deep into the heart of the city, where even the junkies, prostitutes, street gangs, and piratical thugs have something to fear...a young, disfigured drug lord named James...better known in the streets as "Hook." The piece will also feature characters such as a chemist named Mr. Smee; a gay, male escort called Tinker Bell, and Princess Tiger Lily, a madam at a local brothel.

 

Your gift will allow The Rage of the Stage Players to proceed with our plans for our upcoming 2012 season. It will allow Western Pennsylvanians to see new and extremely visceral theatre, and allow actors and production crew to continue to practice and share their work with audiences. All gifts are tax-deductible to the full extent of the law. Every gift is deeply appreciated and makes a huge difference. 



Who We Are

 

The Rage of the Stage Players are a not-for-profit fringe theatre group that produces original works, with predominantly dark and mature themes. We are, in fact, the only group in Western Pennsylvania that performs such material not merely as seasonal Halloween fareâ€¦but instead, as the core of our companyâ€™s productions. The Rage of the Stage Players extend the opportunity to any student (18 years of age and older) or adult in the community, who wishes to apply an artistic skill in a theatrical setting. We strive to satisfy darker tastes in art, and thusly, have developed a fan-base composed of those who seek it.

 

 

When I was traveling from West Chester to work with Rage, I was commuting about 350 miles. There are a lot of reasons that I was willing to do this, but two were most prominent. Firstly, it was the most fun Iâ€™ve consistently had to this day. The people I met through Rage quickly became, and still are, some of my closest friends. And secondly, our shows were fantastic. The attention to detail in the scripts, costumes, set designs, props, etc., made it feel like a different world. I was excited for every show to go up, because I was proud of all the things we did. I couldnâ€™t wait for my friends and family to see what we had been creating.

 

-Sean Michael Gallaher, Actor

 

 

I keep coming to Rage performances because the company never fails to deliver creative, witty, edgy and delightfully deviant theater.  It makes me smile and shake my head at the same time, with its unique twists on familiar stories and hilarious takes on the darkest sides of life.  It's entertaining in the most inappropriate ways, and I really love that.

 

-David Giesler, Patron

 

 

When I returned to Pittsburgh after ten years, I had been annihilated by â€œAnnie,â€ beaten by Beckett, shaken from Shakespeare, and rocked from â€œThe Rocky Horror Show.â€ I wanted something fringe, frightening, and fresh. I chose The Rage of the Stage Players and luckily, they chose me, too.

 

-Lori Howsare, Actress/Artistic Director of One Mom Productions

 

 

Rage has made every mile I traveled worth it. There is simply no other theatre company that puts such immense detail, not only into the original writing, but into creating the magical world, which appears on that page. Every stroke of makeup, fabric of a costume, and board of scenery is so beautifully crafted, that there is no other comparable theatre experience. You arenâ€™t just acting in a playâ€¦you are, for at least a brief period, living in this fantastical world of make-believe.

 

-Alyssa Herron, Actress

 


I started working with Rage because of the intense creativity and passion that they put into every show. I'm a traditionally and classically trained actor and a lot of that training can make us complacent and a little stale as artists. Rage challenges me to think differently and to use my skills in new and unusual ways. It's just a lot of fun!

 

-Dek Ingraham, Actor/Managing Artistic Director of Phase 3 Productions

 

 

Rage consistently promises visually and emotionally engaging productions. Having known the Founders/Producers for many years, I hold them to that promise.  While other theatre groups may fall short, Rage never fails to draw me in, while immersing me in their twisted, dark, and humorous world.  Having personally been able to participate in one of their shows (even in a small capacity), I can say their level of professionalism and dedication to the craft is fantastic. Not to mention, the experience was a lot of fun as well! A few years ago I moved away from Pittsburgh. However, I still make every attempt to return home and catch one of Rage's new productions. Recently I flew home from Florida to attend their production of "The Hamiltons," and was blown away, as usual. I will continue to support Rage in the future and am proud to tell people about the great work Jim and Carrie do. I am looking forward to the next time I can escape for a few hours, forget about life's troubles and enjoy the show.

 

-Douglas Talotta, Patron

 

 

This is your chance to become part of the dark magic that is The Rage of the Stage Players. Donate now, and join our carnival of theatrical artistry. Every gift, no matter how large or small, makes an impact on our local fringe theatre troupe.

 

James Michael and Carrie L. Shoberg co-founded The Rage of the Stage Players in 2001. Our independent group is comprised of fringe artists, who travel long distances from within Pennsylvania and the Tri-state area to work with us. Lovers of our unique brand of theatre, these artists volunteer hundreds of hours to making The Rage of the Stage Players a success. They appreciate the opportunity to hone their various talents in a theatrical setting. This is best illustrated in the case of The Rage of the Stage Playersâ€™ makeup and special effects designer, Greg Lightner, another of our volunteers, who was recently chosen to compete on the second season of  the SyFy Channelâ€™s makeup/special effects reality show, â€œFace Off.â€

 


 

I really have to thank Jim Shoberg, personally, for believing in me, and coming up with these amazing concepts for Rage. I was really only ever an instrument, a medium to realize his vision. In the end, it was Jim, who was muse to me, and inspired every creation. I can take credit for the makeup and designs, but they would be nothing without him, his creativity, and dare I say, genius? Yes, I dare. I love the synergy that we have together.

 

-Greg Lightner, Makeup/Special Effects Designer  

 

Throughout the companyâ€™s ten-year history, most of the productions have been original works conceived by Co-Executive Producer and Artistic Director, James Michael Shoberg.  We have, however, had the occasion and privilege to debut the writing of other local playwrights, as well. This past fall, James received permission fromThe Butcher Brothers and Lionsgate Films, to adapt their award-winning, independent horror film, The Hamiltons, into a live stage play. The Rage of the Stage Players overwhelmingly well-received production of The Hamiltons was featured in Fangoria.com, Pittsburgh Exhumed, Pittsburgh Magazine, and Rue Morgue Magazine. (See Recent Media Coverage below.)

 

Additionally, The Rage of the Stage Players are an annual participant in The Pittsburgh New Works Festival, the only one-act play festival of its kind, helping other playwrights to improve their plays through the process of a first full production. 

 

We Need Your Help


The Rage of the Stage Players, supported solely from ticket sales and individual donations since our inception in 2001, have never received grant money.  Ticket sales cover only 25% of our costs.  We depend on people just like you to donate the rest of the money to help us bring our vision of theatre to the stage. Our seasons are comprised of two shows, one in the spring and one in the fall. Monies made from each production are used to mount the next, with the success of each, determining the scale of the one to follow. The actors and production crew work on a strictly-voluntary basis, donating both time and talent. Though weâ€™ve proceeded independently without significant outside financial support over the past ten years, The Rage of the Stage Players are now in need of funding to continue creating a brand of theatre that is uniquely our own. That is why we are embarking on our first large fundraising campaign. 


Recent Media Coverage

 

Fangoria.com

http://www.fangoria.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5829:writerdirector-talks-qthe-hamiltonsq-on-stage&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=167

 

Pittsburgh Exhumed

http://pghexhumed.blogspot.com/

 

Pittsburgh Magazine

http://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/Pittsburgh-Magazine/October-2011/Chiller-Theater/


Producer Biographies


JAMES MICHAEL SHOBERG is Co-Executive Producer and Artistic Director of The Rage of the Stage Players fringe theatre company. He has many years of diverse experience, as illustrated by his work as an award-winning actor; a designer; a director; and a writer, with numerous plays and a collection of monologues to his credit. He is well-recognized for his unique work, and two of his plays, Aliceâ€™s Adventures in â€œWonderlandâ€ (a gritty adaptation set in a depraved city) and Dorothy in Oz (a darkly comedic adaptation set in a mental hospital) have been produced on the West Coast; in New York City; and this February, will debut internationally in Canada. James serves annually as a producer for The Pittsburgh New Works Festival, where he also volunteers his time to request the donation of goods and services from local businesses, for the festivalâ€™s various fundraising efforts.

 

CARRIE L. SHOBERG is Co-Executive Producer and Production Manager of The Rage of the Stage Players, handling the bulk of the companyâ€™s administrative duties. She is also a designer of costumes, makeup, and props. She frequently appears in Rage productions, having originated multiple roles in premieres, including, Miss Tuttle in Aliceâ€™s Adventures in â€œWonderland,â€ and Glinda/Mrs. Goode in Dorothy in Oz. Both plays have since been produced outside of Pittsburgh. Carrie served as a director for South Park Childrenâ€™s Theatre for ten years, taught both English and Theatre Arts in the public school system, and was on the board of The Washington County Theatre Festival. She currently apprentices with Lightko Studios, acts in local film projects, and is a producer for The Pittsburgh New Works Festival.



*All tickets sold separately.
story_txt:
The Rage of the Stage Players are attempting to raise $7,000
to produce the world premiere of James Michael Shobergâ€™s latest stage
adaptation, which will be a grim, violent twist on J. M. Barrieâ€™s novel, Peter and Wendy, set in a bleak,
futuristic London. The piece, aptly entitled, Hooked, will take our audiences into an unsettling, grimy
future, where societal decay has left London a ruined husk of the city it once
was, overwrought with crime and drugs. When an injured young anti-hero,
referring to himself only as "Pan," crosses paths with a young girl,
Wendy Darling, she and her two brothers, Michael and John, are drawn deep into
the heart of the city, where even the junkies, prostitutes, street gangs, and
piratical thugs have something to fear...a young, disfigured drug lord named
James...better known in the streets as "Hook." The
piece will also feature characters such as a chemist named Mr. Smee; a gay,
male escort called Tinker Bell, and Princess Tiger Lily, a madam at a local
brothel.
 
Your gift will allow The Rage of the Stage Players to
proceed with our plans for our upcoming 2012 season. It will allow Western
Pennsylvanians to see new and extremely visceral theatre, and allow actors and
production crew to continue to practice and share their work with audiences.
All gifts are tax-deductible to the
full extent of the law. Every gift is deeply appreciated and makes a huge
difference. Who We Are
 
The Rage of the Stage Players are a not-for-profit fringe theatre
group that produces original works, with predominantly dark and mature themes. We
are, in fact, the only group in Western Pennsylvania that performs such
material not merely as seasonal Halloween fareâ€¦but instead, as the core of our
companyâ€™s productions. The Rage of the Stage Players extend the opportunity to
any student (18 years of age and older) or adult in the community, who wishes
to apply an artistic skill in a theatrical setting. We strive to
satisfy darker tastes in art, and thusly, have developed a fan-base
composed of those who seek it. 
 
 
When I was traveling from
West Chester to work with Rage, I was commuting about 350 miles. There are a
lot of reasons that I was willing to do this, but two were most prominent. Firstly,
it was the most fun Iâ€™ve consistently had to this day. The people I met through
Rage quickly became, and still are, some of my closest friends. And secondly,
our shows were fantastic. The attention to detail in the scripts, costumes, set
designs, props, etc., made it feel like a different world. I was excited for
every show to go up, because I was proud of all the things we did. I couldnâ€™t
wait for my friends and family to see what we had been creating.
 
-Sean Michael Gallaher,
Actor
 
 
I keep coming to Rage
performances because the company never fails to deliver creative, witty, edgy
and delightfully deviant theater.  It makes me smile and shake my head at
the same time, with its unique twists on familiar stories and hilarious takes
on the darkest sides of life.  It's entertaining in the most inappropriate
ways, and I really love that.
 
-David Giesler, Patron
 
 
When I returned to
Pittsburgh after ten years, I had been annihilated by â€œAnnie,â€ beaten by
Beckett, shaken from Shakespeare, and rocked from â€œThe Rocky Horror Show.â€ I
wanted something fringe, frightening, and fresh. I chose The Rage of the Stage
Players and luckily, they chose me, too.
 
-Lori Howsare,
Actress/Artistic Director of One Mom Productions
 
 
Rage has made every mile I
traveled worth it. There is simply no other theatre company that puts such
immense detail, not only into the original writing, but into creating the
magical world, which appears on that page. Every stroke of makeup, fabric of a costume,
and board of scenery is so beautifully crafted, that there is no other
comparable theatre experience. You arenâ€™t just acting in a playâ€¦you are, for at
least a brief period, living in this fantastical world of make-believe.
 
-Alyssa Herron, Actress
 
I started working with Rage because of the intense creativity and passion that they put into every show. I'm a traditionally and classically trained actor and a lot of that training can make us complacent and a little stale as artists. Rage challenges me to think differently and to use my skills in new and unusual ways. It's just a lot of fun!
 
-Dek Ingraham,
Actor/Managing Artistic Director of Phase 3 Productions
 
 
Rage consistently promises
visually and emotionally engaging productions. Having known the Founders/Producers
for many years, I hold them to that promise.  While other
theatre groups may fall short, Rage never fails to draw me in, while immersing
me in their twisted, dark, and humorous world. 
Having personally been able to participate in one of their shows (even in a
small capacity), I can say their level of professionalism and dedication to the
craft is fantastic. Not to mention, the experience was a lot
of fun as well! A few years ago I moved away from Pittsburgh. However, I still
make every attempt to return home and catch one of Rage's new productions.
Recently I flew home from Florida to attend their production of "The
Hamiltons," and was blown away, as usual. I will continue
to support Rage in the future and am proud to tell people about the great work
Jim and Carrie do. I am looking forward to the next time I can escape for a few
hours, forget about life's troubles and enjoy the show.
 
-Douglas Talotta,
Patron
 
 
This is your
chance to become part of the dark magic that is The Rage of the Stage Players. Donate
now, and join our carnival of theatrical artistry. Every gift, no matter how large or small, makes
an impact on our local fringe theatre troupe.
 
James Michael and Carrie L. Shoberg co-founded The Rage of
the Stage Players in 2001. Our independent group is comprised of fringe
artists, who travel long distances from within Pennsylvania and the Tri-state
area to work with us. Lovers of our unique brand of theatre, these artists
volunteer hundreds of hours to making The Rage of the Stage Players a success.
They appreciate the opportunity to hone their various talents in a theatrical
setting. This is best illustrated in the case of The Rage of the Stage Playersâ€™
makeup and special effects designer, Greg Lightner, another of our volunteers, who
was recently chosen to compete on the second season of  the SyFy Channelâ€™s makeup/special effects
reality show, â€œFace Off.â€ 
 
 
I really have to thank Jim
Shoberg, personally, for believing in me, and coming up with these amazing
concepts for Rage. I was really only ever an instrument, a medium to realize
his vision. In the end, it was Jim, who was muse to me, and inspired every
creation. I can take credit for the makeup and designs, but they would be
nothing without him, his creativity, and dare I say, genius? Yes, I dare. I
love the synergy that we have together.
 
-Greg Lightner,
Makeup/Special Effects Designer   
 
Throughout the companyâ€™s ten-year history, most of the
productions have been original works conceived by Co-Executive Producer and
Artistic Director, James Michael Shoberg.  We have, however, had the occasion and
privilege to debut the writing of other local playwrights, as well. This past
fall, James received permission fromThe Butcher Brothers and Lionsgate Films,
to adapt their award-winning, independent horror film, The Hamiltons, into a live stage play. The Rage of the Stage
Players overwhelmingly well-received production of The Hamiltons was featured in Fangoria.com, Pittsburgh Exhumed,
Pittsburgh Magazine, and Rue Morgue Magazine. (See Recent Media Coverage below.)
 
Additionally, The Rage of the Stage Players are an annual participant
in The Pittsburgh New Works Festival, the only one-act play festival of its
kind, helping other playwrights to improve their plays through the process of a
first full production. 
 
We Need Your Help
The Rage of the Stage Players, supported solely from ticket
sales and individual donations since our inception in 2001, have never received
grant money.  Ticket sales cover only 25%
of our costs.  We depend on people just
like you to donate the rest of the money to help us bring our vision of theatre
to the stage. Our seasons are comprised of two shows, one in the spring and one
in the fall. Monies made from each production are used to mount the next, with
the success of each, determining the scale of the one to follow. The actors and
production crew work on a strictly-voluntary basis, donating both time and
talent. Though weâ€™ve proceeded independently without significant outside
financial support over the past ten years, The Rage of the Stage Players are
now in need of funding to continue creating a brand of theatre that is uniquely
our own. That is why we are embarking on our first large fundraising campaign. Recent Media Coverage
 
Fangoria.com
http://www.fangoria.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5829:writerdirector-talks-qthe-hamiltonsq-on-stage&catid=1:latest-news&Itemid=167
 
Pittsburgh Exhumed

story:
INTRODUCING ‘WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC’
My name is Charlotte Bydwell and I am the creator of WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC, an evening-length solo show based on my experiences as an emerging artist in New York City. 
 
A whimsical combination of dance and theatre, WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC depicts a young woman’s quest to find balance in a life where every achievement brings further uncertainty. It finds humor in the heroine’s struggle to remain financially stable, creatively productive, physically fit, romantically satisfied, and still standing.
 
 

THE ROAD TO FRINGE NYC
WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC premiered at 9th Space (P.S. 122) in May 2011 as part of the 8th Annual soloNOVA Festival and was nominated for a New York Innovative Theatre Award for Outstanding Performance Art Production. After seeing a subsequent performance at the Center for Performance Research, Heber Villergas translated the work into Spanish and it was produced in Mexico by an all new cast and crew.

The show is now returning to NYC for a run at the 2013 International Fringe Festival and I couldn’t be more excited to share it with new audiences! The magic of this piece is in how relatable it is; audience members of every age recognize and have a chance to laugh at their own neurotic tendencies while watching this character lose herself in a whirlwind of indecision. I cannot wait to introduce more people to this crazy lady!


WE ALL NEED PEOPLE TO LEAN ON
I’m thrilled to announce that the terraNOVA Collective will be producing WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC at FringeNYC. Under the artistic direction of Jennifer Darling, terraNOVA hosted the show's premiere back in 2011 and they’ve continued to be an incredible source of support to me. Eva Scanlan will be our official terraNOVA correspondent for FringeNYC and I know that she will be a huge asset in making our run at the FringeNYC a success.
 
I also couldn’t have made this show without the help of my incredible collaborators; Erica Evans (costumes) and Carlye Eckert (dramaturge). These two ladies have helped me turn real panic into a great performance.
 
**Special thanks to the incredible David Fishel for making the trailer you see above!
 

MONEY MATTERS
In order to present WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC at FringeNYC, I need to raise $8,000. This may seem like a lot for a show that uses a paper phone and laptop, my childhood dress-up skirt, a roll of white butcher paper and some black sharpies, but the costs of participating in this international-level festival add up quickly. From the initial participation fee to fireproofing all the scenic elements (butcher paper included!), the numbers just keep climbing.

If you would like to review a detailed budget, please visit the link below:
http://womanofleisureandpanic.tumblr.com/support

 
BOTTOM LINE
I want people to see this piece and I want them to see it at its best. Any amount that you can contribute towards making this happen will truly be a game changer.
 

THINKING ABOUT DONATING?
Thanks to terraNOVA's involvement in this production, all donations are tax deductible. You will receive a receipt from terraNOVA as proof of yor contribution.
 

PANICKING?
If you are not in a position to donate funds, take a deep breath and help spread the word instead! Share this campaign on Facebook and encourage your friends/family to check out my work.

 
NEED MORE INFORMATION?
Want to learn more about me and what else I’ve done?
charlottebydwell.weebly.com

Want to read the WOMAN OF LEISURE AND PANIC blog?
Womanofleisureandpanic.tumblr.com

Want to read a review from the soloNOVA run?
http://showbusinessweekly.com/article-1784-woman-of-leisure-and-panic.html 
 
 
THANK YOU!
 
** Photos by Matt Sundin

story:
About The Theater and Evil Dead The Musical

The Alley has been around for 21 years, providing Louisville with some of the best alternative and pop-culture theater around.  

Evil Dead The Musical is a loving send up of horror films, musicals, and the front 4 rows are guaranteed to leave the show drenched in blood!

The Alley Theater was the only theatre in the region that dared to premiere Evil Dead The Musical.  The response was great and the   reviews were amazing    .

    In 2011 we brought back the show to more sold out crowds and   more fantastic reviews   .

      This year the Alley moved to a brand new home at 633 West Main Street in the heart of the Downtown Theater and Museum district.  The location is better, but it means we have a much smaller space. 

      With so many fewer seats, we cannot produce Evil Dead The Musical at the level it deserves based on ticket sales alone.  That’s why we need your collective help to make this show great, and to keep ticket prices down for all of us, so no-one has to miss out on this great experience.

        What We Need

        We don't want to sacrifice the quality of the production that the audience has become accustomed to, but we need more than just ticket sales to keep at the level we previously achieved: we have plans to make it better than ever!

        What your money will help to pay for is:

        • Royalties to the Authors via their agency (Samuel French):  They wrote an amazing show and deserve to be paid for it!
        • Printing costs: Full programs, posters, and advertising materials:  The more audience there is, the more fun to be shared!
        • Set Construction: We need to build a car, a cabin in the woods, the woods themselves, talking animals and perhaps a flying money or beaver or something.
        • Blood: LOTS of Blood!
        • Costumes: We considered having the actors perform naked, but then we'd have to charge you extra for tickets to cover all the fines and lawsuits.
        • More Blood: LOTS AND LOTS of Blood!
        • Props: Shotguns, chainsaws and severed body parts aren't cheap!
        • Did I mention Blood? LOTS AND LOTS AND LOTS of Blood!


          What's in it for you?

          We have a number of exclusive perks to thank you for helping to make this happen - every donation makes a difference.   
          Your contribution goes to help local artists and the local arts, which in turn helps to make more shows like this possible in the future.  It also helps to make Louisville a better place.  Aiding this production means helping to keep ticket prices down for one of the most fun shows in town.
          The Alley Theater is a 501(c)(3) non-profit, and all gifts are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law (less the cash value of any perks).

          (Exclusive Contributor T-Shirt)

          What's in it for us?

          We get to bring the best and most entertaining production we can to the public at a price they can afford, and watch the smiles and laughs from a packed house of zombie musical loving folks, some of whom will be covered in blood.  And we can continue to do so in the future.

          Other Ways You Can Help

          If you can't contribute, we understand that.. heck, we're asking for money here so obviously WE aren't loaded either..   but that doesn't mean that you can't help support your local arts.  You could help us by

          • Make some noise about this campaign!  Share it on Facebook, twitter, fax-o-gram or go door to door!
          • Use the IndieGoGo share tools to make it easy!
          • Of course, come see Evil Dead: The Musical and other fantastic shows at The Alley Theater!

          Thank you for your support!

story:
My name is Ana Mendez and I am a Miami-based performance artist and choreographer. I am developing two original productions in 2014 and need your help.

These projects were developed during my residency in the Everglades National Park, through the Artist in Residence in the Everglades (AIRIE) program. They will be funded in part by Bas Fisher Invitational, an artist-run space in downtown Miami, and the Miami Light Project. With this campaign, I am hoping to raise up to $12,000 for additional but vital costs to pay designers and artists, rent equipment, book rehearsal space, and purchase materials. You'll find a total breakdown of each project and its costs below.

No matter how big or small your contribution, your help will strengthen the integrity and creative process of the work.  In appreciation of your support, I would like to offer several unique perks, some of which include tickets to the Here and Now Festival 2014, an invitation to preview rehearsals, a sincere and public thank you on Facebook, and printed photos of the performances.

PROJECT 1
On 4/4/14 at the Bas Fisher Invitational, I will present my first-ever sculptural installation, Fortress. I will also curate a Weird Miami Bus Tour that takes visitors to a site-specific performance in the Everglades, entitled Wilderness.

http://www.basfisherinvitational.com/

$1000 Dancer Rehearsal and Performance Fees
$200 Rental of PA system
$150 Sound operator
$600 Photo/Video Documentarians
$250 Costume and Makeup
$800 Rehearsal Space Rental
$1000 Installation Materials
  $4000 GRAND TOTAL


PROJECT 2
My second piece, Portal, will take place on 5/8/14 through 5/17/14 at Miami Light Project's Here and Now 2014 festival. This performance will feature many exciting collaborators, including jazz musicians Steven Bristol with Ed Wilcox from the Sun Ra Arkestra; dancers Shira Abergel and Keisha Whitfield; stylist Sarah Freidin; sound designer and artist Richard Vergez; and light designers Sevim Abaza and Terrence Brunn.

http://www.miamilightproject.com/

$2800 Dancer Rehearsal and Performance Fees
$1500 Musicians and Sound Designer Fees
$300 Costume Stylist/Designer Fee
$1000 Costume and Makeup
$800 Rehearsal Space Rental
$835 Set Materials
  $7235 GRAND TOTAL

The remaining $765 will pay for all the perks and fees associated with Indiegogo.

I cannot express how the success of this campaign will change my life. The support and excitement of the community is an amazing source of the strength for my process and for the general support of art in our lives. In a world where many people are overworked and dreams seem so distant, it is incredibly important to support one another in manifesting the biggest dreams possible.


We need to create the world we want to experience. Please help us build a strong community of support!

I am developing two original productions in 2014 and need your help.These projects were developed during my residency in the Everglades National Park, through the Artist in Residence in the Everglades (AIRIE) program. They will be funded in part by Bas Fisher Invitational, an artist-run space in downtown Miami, and the Miami Light Project. With this campaign, I am hoping to raise up to $12,000 for additional but vital costs to pay designers and artists, rent equipment, book rehearsal space, and purchase materials. You'll find a total breakdown of each project and its costs below.No matter how big or small your contribution, your help will strengthen the integrity and creative process of the work.  In appreciation of your support, I would like to offer several unique perks, some of which include tickets to the Here and Now Festival 2014, an invitation to preview rehearsals, a sincere and public thank you on Facebook, and printed photos of the performances.PROJECT 1On 4/4/14 at the Bas Fisher Invitational, I will present my first-ever sculptural installation, Fortress. I will also curate a Weird Miami Bus Tour that takes visitors to a site-specific performance in the Everglades, entitled Wilderness.http://www.basfisherinvitational.com/$1000 Dancer Rehearsal and Performance Fees$200 Rental of PA system$150 Sound operator$600 Photo/Video Documentarians$250 Costume and Makeup$800 Rehearsal Space Rental$1000 Installation Materials  $4000 GRAND TOTALPROJECT 2My second piece, Portal, will take place on 5/8/14 through 5/17/14 at Miami Light Project's Here and Now 2014 festival. This performance will feature many exciting collaborators, including jazz musicians Steven Bristol with Ed Wilcox from the Sun Ra Arkestra; dancers Shira Abergel and Keisha Whitfield; stylist Sarah Freidin; sound designer and artist Richard Vergez; and light designers Sevim Abaza and Terrence Brunn.http://www.miamilightproject.com/$2800 Dancer Rehearsal and Performance Fees$1500 Musicians and Sound Designer Fees$300 Costume Stylist/Designer Fee$1000 Costume and Makeup$800 Rehearsal Space Rental$835 Set Materials  $7235 GRAND TOTALThe remaining $765 will pay for all the perks and fees associated with Indiegogo.I cannot express how the success of this campaign will change my life. The support and excitement of the community is an amazing source of the strength for my process and for the general support of art in our lives. In a world where many people are overworked and dreams seem so distant, it is incredibly important to support one another in manifesting the biggest dreams possible.We need to create the world we want to experience. Please help us build a strong community of support!
